plain language summary: At least 70 million people have been infected with HIV since the beginning of the epidemic and an effective vaccine remains elusive. The high mutation rate and diversity of HIV strains enables the virus to effectively evade host immune responses, presenting a significant challenge for HIV vaccine design. We have developed an approach to translate clinical databases of HIV sequences into mathematical models quantifying the capacity of the virus to replicate as a function of mutations within its genome. We have previously shown how such “fitness landscapes” can be used to guide the design of vaccines to attack vulnerable regions from which it is difficult for the virus to escape by mutation. Here, using new modeling approaches, we have improved on our previous models of HIV fitness landscape by accounting for undersampling of HIV sequences and the specific identity of mutant amino acids. We experimentally tested the accuracy of the improved models to predict the fitness of HIV with multiple mutations in the Gag protein. The experimental data are in strong agreement with model predictions, supporting the value of these models as a novel approach for determining mutational vulnerabilities of HIV-1, which, in turn, can inform vaccine design.
generated_summary: Viral immune evasion and sequence variation are a major hindrance to HIV-1 vaccine design. To address this challenge, a group developed a computational model, rooted in physics, which aims to predict the fitness landscape of HIV-infected proteins in order to design vaccine immunogens that lead to impaired viral fitness, blocking viable escape routes. In order to address these limitations, we directly test the model predictions in in vitro fitness measurements of HIV strains containing multiple Gag mutations. We incorporated a regularization model fitting procedure to address finite sampling. Our developed model accounts for the specific identity of mutant amino acids (Potts model), generalizing the previous approach (Ising model) and is unable to distinguish between different mutant amino acid sequences. Our results support the ability of computational models to robustly predict relative fitness of mutant viral strains, and indicate a potential value for understanding viral immune evasion, harnessing knowledge of immunogen design.

abstract: present new modeling computational tool computes rigorous summaries network dynamics large sets parameter values . summaries , organized database , searched observed dynamics , e.g. , bistability hysteresis , discover parameter regimes supported . illustrate approach networks underlying restriction point cell cycle humans yeast . rank networks robustly support hysteresis , observed phenotype . find best 6 - node human network yeast network share similar topology robustness hysteresis , spite having homology corresponding nodes network . approach provides new tool linking network structure dynamics .
plain language summary: To summarize our understanding of how genes, their products and other cellular actors interact with each other, we often employ networks to describe their interactions. However, networks do not fully specify how the underlying biological system behaves in different conditions, nor how such response evolves in time. We present a new modeling and computational approach that allows us to compute and collect summaries of network dynamics for large sets of parameter values. We can then search these summaries for all observed behavior. We illustrate our approach on networks that govern entry to the cell cycle in humans and yeast. We rank networks based on how robustly they exhibit the experimentally observed behavior of hysteresis. We find similarities in network structure of the best ranked networks in yeast and humans, which are not explained by a common ancestry. Our approach provides a tool linking network structure and the behavior of the underlying system.
generated_summary: We present a new modeling computational tool that computes rigorous summaries of network dynamics using large sets of parameter values. The summaries are organized into a database, searched for observed dynamics, e.g. bistability and hysteresis, and discover which parameter regimes are supported by the observed phenotype. We illustrate this approach by identifying the networks underlying the restriction point cell cycle in humans and yeast. We find that the best 6-node human network yeast network share similar topology and robustness to the corresponding nodes in the network. Our approach provides a new tool linking network structure dynamics and dynamics.

Previous genome - wide screens global proteomics approaches Tomato bushy stunt tombusvirus ( TBSV ) yeast model host revealed involvement cyclophilins , large family host prolyl isomerases , TBSV replication . paper , identified members large cyclophilin family interacted viral replication proteins inhibited TBSV replication . characterization effective cyclophilin , Cyp40 - like Cpr7p , revealed strongly inhibits steps TBSV replication cell - free replication assay . steps include viral RNA recruitment inhibited binding Cpr7p RNA - binding region viral replication protein ; assembly viral replicase complex viral RNA synthesis . plain language summary: Replication of plus-stranded RNA viruses, which are important pathogens of humans, animals and plants, can be inhibited by host-coded proteins. In this paper, the authors show that the Cyp40-like Cpr7p prolyl isomerase of yeast can effectively inhibit tombusvirus replication. This inhibition is due to binding of the TPR (tetratricopeptide repeats) domain of Cpr7p to the RNA-binding region of the tombusvirus replication proteins that leads to inhibition of RNA binding by the viral replication proteins, interference with the assembly of the viral replicase and blocking viral RNA synthesis. Cpr7p is also effective against the distantly-related alfanodaviruses of insects. Overall, this work reveals a role for a Cyp40-like protein as a regulator of RNA virus replication. This function of Cyp40 during RNA virus infection seems to be conserved between yeast and plants.
generated_summary: Replication of plus-stranded RNA viruses is greatly affected by numerous host-coded proteins acting as susceptibility and resistance factors. Previous genome-wide screens of global proteomics approaches using Tomato bushy stunt tombusvirus (TBSV) in the yeast model host revealed the involvement of cyclophilins, a large family of host prolyl isomerases, in TBSV replication. In this paper, we identified members of the large cyclophilain family that interacted with viral replication proteins and inhibited TbsV replication in vitro. Our characterization of the effective cytoplasmic protein Cyp40-like Cpr7p, revealed that Cyp40 strongly inhibits the steps of viral replication in a cell-free replication assay. These steps include viral RNA recruitment, which inhibited the binding of the CPR7p RNA-binding region to the viral replication protein; assembly of the viral replicase complex; and viral RNA synthesis. Our results suggest that Cyp 40-like proteins are important regulators of TBSv replication.

plain language summary: Implantation in mammals requires a complex crosstalk between the conceptus (the embryo and associated membranes) and the uterus. An imbalanced regulation of the factors contributing to these interactions has negative impacts on the attachment of the fetus, the progression of the pregnancy, and the progeny. Focusing on paired conceptus–endometrium analyses of individual pregnancies in cows, we have determined that communication at implantation encompasses synchronized genome-wide coregulation of genes. Gene regulatory interactions between one conceptus and the surrounding maternal tissue vary between endometrial regions containing or lacking glands. Our data reveal new insights, to our knowledge, on the coordination of molecular mechanisms that contribute to implantation and pregnancy establishment in mammals. We conclude that the biological response of the endometrium is embryo-specific, a phenomenon that deserves further investigation in the context of assisted reproductive technologies.
generated_summary: The embryo and endometrium are essential for the development of the placenta and the progression of pregnancy. However, it remains unclear whether the interactions between the conceptus and the endometria are coordinated at the level of individual pregnancy. To test the hypothesis that gene expression in the embryo is dependent on the gene expression of extraembryonic tissues, we performed integrative analysis of transcriptome profiles paired with extraEmbryonic tissue from pregnancies initiated by artificial insemination. We quantified strong dependence ( |r| > 0.95, empirical false discovery rate [eFDR] < 0.01) on the transcript abundance of genes expressed in the endostrium and the coexpression patterns of genes in the caruncular and intercaruncular areas of the ectopic embryo. We found that the coexpressing modules were remarkably specific to the caruuncular intercuncular area of the endoembryrium. Our quantitative association of genes with genes expressed at the endofometrium emphasize coordinated communication between these entities in mammals. Our findings provide evidence that implantation of mammalian pregnancy relies on the ability of the embryo to develop a fine-tuned adaptive response to the characteristic pregnancy.

plain language summary: The repeated infection that causes trachoma is spread from person to person via infected ocular and nasal secretions. The World Health Organization (WHO) strategy for trachoma control includes keeping children’s faces clean of discharges, yet “clean faces” are not measured in most of the district surveys that evaluate the impact of programs. We studied the reliability of assessing “clean faces” in 60 children in a village in Tanzania, using trained Tanzania staff with a variety of educational backgrounds. When assessing the same child twice after 50 minutes, the staff showed substantial agreement with themselves. The agreement between a senior grader and each staff member was also excellent. The data suggest that clean faces in children can be reliably assessed, and should be added to district surveys that are measuring the impact of programs on control of trachoma.
generated_summary: The SAFE strategy for trachoma is to assess the cleanliness of children’s faces, regardless of the number of times washed to achieve the endpoint. The issue of reliability rests on reproducibility of graders to assess clean face in a field trial in Kongwa, Tanzania. Seven graders were trained to assess whether the presence of absence of nasal ocular discharge in children's faces was reliable. The children ages 1–7 years were recruited to the community and evaluated independently of seven graders, 50 minutes later. Intra-inter- observer variation was calculated using unweighted kappa statistics. The average intra- observer agreement was 0.72, average inter-observer agreement kappa = 0.78. The results suggest that the assessment of clean faces in trained Tanzania staff represent a variety of educational backgrounds, and reflect the effort of families to clean their faces.

Robust BDR – dependent NAHR demonstrates sequences distal DSBs effectively compete proximal sequences repair break . addition , analysis NAHR partner choice Ty repeats shows intrachromosomal Ty partners preferred despite abundance potential interchromosomal Ty partners share higher sequence identity . competitive advantage intrachromosomal Tys results relative efficiencies different NAHR repair pathways . Finally , NAHR generates deleterious rearrangements frequently DSBs occur outside Ty repeat . findings yield insights mechanisms repeat - mediated genome rearrangements associated evolution cancer .
plain language summary: The human genome is structurally dynamic, frequently undergoing loss, duplication, and rearrangement of large chromosome segments. These structural changes occur both in normal and in cancerous cells and are thought to cause both benign and deleterious changes in cell function. Many of these structural alterations are generated when two dispersed repeated DNA sequences at non-allelic sites recombine during non-allelic homologous recombination (NAHR). Here we study NAHR on a genome-wide scale using the experimentally tractable budding yeast as a eukaryotic model genome with its fully sequenced family of repeated DNA elements, the Ty retrotransposons. With our novel system, we simultaneously measure the effects of known recombination parameters on the frequency of NAHR to understand which parameters most influence the occurrence of rearrangements between repetitive sequences. These findings provide a basic framework for interpreting how structural changes observed in the human genome may have arisen.
generated_summary: Genome rearrangements result from non-allelic homologous recombination (NAHR) between repetitive DNA elements dispersed throughout the genome. In this study, we systematically analyze the NAHR of Ty retrotransposons in a genome-wide approach that exploits unique features of Saccharomyces cerevisiae and purebred S. bayanus hybrid diploids. We find that DNA double-strand breaks (DSBs) induce NAHR–dependent rearrangement of Ty elements located at 12 48 kilobases at the distal break site. We also find that the break-distal recombination pathway is frequently used to repair a break in a Ty homolog. Robust BDR–dependent NAHR demonstrates that sequences of distal DSBs can effectively compete with the proximal sequences of the repair break. In addition, our analysis of NAHR partner choice between Ty repeats shows that intrachromosomal Ty partners are preferred despite the abundance of potential interchromosomal Tys that share higher sequence identity. Our findings provide insights into the mechanisms by which repeat-mediated genome rearranging is associated with evolution of cancer.

PntP1 downstream effector EGF signaling , findings provide insight Hox factor trigger potentiate EGF signal promote essential cell fate body plan .
plain language summary: Hox genes encode a conserved family of transcription factors that regulate unique cell types within the distinct morphological structures that arise along the body plan of animals. Hox transcription factors specify different cell fates by regulating the expression of downstream genes, many of which are part of cell signaling pathways. For example, a Hox factor that is only expressed in the Drosophila abdomen (Abdominal-A) activates the release of a signaling molecule (Epidermal Growth Factor, EGF) from a specific neural precursor cell. The cells that receive the signal are induced to become essential hepatocyte-like cells required for metabolism and animal growth. Here, we show that this same Hox factor is not only required for sending the EGF signal, but it also enhances the strength of the signal within the developing hepatocyte-like cells. Importantly, the thoracic Hox factor fails to both induce and enhance the signal, thereby providing a better understanding of how these abdomen-specific cells are generated and distinct morphological structures become regionalized to specific segments of the embryo.
generated_summary: Hox transcription factors specify distinct cell types on the anterior-posterior axis of metazoans by regulating target genes and modulating signaling pathways. A well-established example of induction of Epidermal Growth Factor (EGF) signaling is the Abdominal- (Ab-) Hox complex specification of Drosophila hepatocyte-like cells (Oenocytes). Previous studies have revealed that the Abd-Hox complex is autonomously required to promote oenocyte fate by directly activating a gene (rhomboid) that triggers EGF secretion in sensory organ precursor (SOP) cells. Here, we show that Abd- plays a cell autonomous role in inducing oenocytes fate by activating the expression of Pointed-P1 (PntP1) and the ETS transcription factor downstream of EGF signaling. Our findings provide insight into how the Hox factor can trigger potentiate EGF signal to promote essential cell fate in the body plan.

abstract: Isolation profoundly influences social behavior animals . humans , isolation effects health . Drosophila melanogaster powerful model study small - scale , temporally - transient social behavior . , longer - term analysis large groups flies hampered lack effective reliable tools . built new imaging arena improved existing tracking algorithm reliably follow large number flies simultaneously . , based automatic classification touch graph - based social network analysis , designed algorithm quantify changes social network response prior social isolation . observed isolation significantly swiftly enhanced individual local social network parameters depicting near - neighbor relationships . explored genome - wide molecular correlates behavioral changes found behavior changed days isolation , gene expression alterations occurred largely day . changes occurred metabolic genes , verified metabolic changes showing increase lipid content isolated flies . summary , describe highly reliable tracking analysis pipeline large groups flies use unravel behavioral , molecular physiological impact isolation social network dynamics Drosophila .
plain language summary: Social isolation severely affects the behavior and physiology of social animals, including humans. The fruit fly is a powerful model for studying the mechanisms of development, health and disease and is also used to study social behaviors such as mating and aggression. However, these studies are limited to examining few individuals for shorts amounts of time, due to the lack of effective computational tools for the analysis of large groups over prolonged time. To overcome this hurdle, we built a new behavioral arena and developed new software that accurately tracks many flies simultaneously over long time periods. The arena is cheap and easy to build and the software works with low resolution videos. Using these improved tools, we studied social isolation in groups of male flies. We found that isolation caused flies to form stronger interactions with neighboring flies in their social network. These behavioral changes were preceded by transient changes in the expression of metabolism genes and eventually resulted in isolated flies accumulating fat, as has been previously observed in studies in mice and humans. Our study opens the door for the use of fruit flies in future studies of social isolation.
generated_summary: Isolation profoundly influences social behavior in animals. In humans, isolation effects health and is a powerful model to study small-scale, temporally-translational social behavior. However, longer-term analysis of large groups of flies is hampered by lack of effective reliable tools. We built a new imaging arena and improved our existing tracking algorithm to reliably follow a large number of flies simultaneously. We developed an automatic classification of touch graph-based social network analysis, designed to quantify changes in social network response prior to social isolation. We observed that isolation significantly swiftly enhanced individual local social network parameters depicting near-neighbors and relationships. We also explored genome-wide molecular correlates of behavioral changes. We found that behavior changed significantly in days after isolation, and gene expression alterations occurred largely on the day of isolation. These changes occurred in metabolic genes, and verified metabolic changes showing an increase in lipid content in isolated flies. In summary, we describe a highly reliable tracking analysis pipeline for large groups and use it to unravel the behavioral, molecular, and physiological impact of isolation on social network dynamics in Drosophila.

Flow cytometry data confirmed PCR array Th17 - related genes ( IL-17 family members , IL-6 , IL-1β IL-22 ) Th2 - related ( IL-4 , IL-13 , STAT6 ) genes significantly - regulated HO individuals . addition , stronger Onchocerca volvulus - specific Th2 responses , especially IL-13 , observed vitro hyperreactive individuals compared GEO EN groups . study provides initial evidence elevated frequencies Th17 Th2 cells form immune network instigating development severe onchocerciasis .
plain language summary: Onchocerciasis, also known as river blindness is a tropical disease causing health and socioeconomic problems in endemic communities especially sub-Saharan Africa. The disease is transmitted by a filarial nematode called Onchocerca volvulus, which is spread by the bite of infected Simulium black flies. Characteristic disease symptoms include dermatological disorders and eye lesions that can lead to blindness. Two polar forms of clinical manifestations can occur: generalized onchocerciasis (GEO) presenting mild skin disease or the hyperreactive form (HO) exhibiting severe skin disorders and inflammation. The immunological determinants behind such disease polarization are still not fully clarified. Here, we compared the immune profiles of individuals presenting these two polar forms with those of endemic normals (EN): individuals who have no clinical or parasitological evidence of infection despite ongoing exposure to the infectious agent. We could show that HO individuals, in contrast to GEO and EN, simultaneously presented elevated Th17 and Th2 profiles which were accompanied by reduced numbers of Foxp3+ regulatory T cells. This study provides initial evidence that elevated frequencies of Th17 and Th2 cells form part of the immune network associated with severe onchocerciasis.
generated_summary: Onchocerciasis (GEO) is a rare and severe form of the disease caused by the Onchocerca volvulus. The disease pathogenesis is associated with host inflammatory reactions. We investigated Th17 responses related to aggravated pathology of HO in individuals presenting with polar forms of infection endemic normals (EN). In addition to elevated frequencies of memory CD4+ T cells, individuals with HO showed accentuated Th17 Th2 profiles and decreased levels of CD25hiFoxp3+ regulatory T cells. These profiles included increased IL-17A+, IL-4+, RORC2+ and GATA3+CD4 + T cell populations. Flow cytometry data confirmed PCR array Th17-related genes and Th2-related (IL-17 family members and IL-6, IL-, IL-1β IL-22) and Th1β and STAT6 genes significantly-regulated in HO individuals compared to GEO EN groups. In addition, stronger Th2 responses, especially IL-13, were observed in in vitro hyperreactive individuals compared with GEOEN groups. Our study provides the first evidence that elevated frequencies and Th17s in Th2 cells form an immune network instigating the development of severe onchocericciasis.

Typhimurium , experimentally validated . apply method predict secreted effectors genetically intractable human pathogen Chlamydia trachomatis , identifying majority known secreted proteins addition providing number novel predictions . approach provides new way identify secreted effectors broad range pathogenic bacteria experimental characterization provides insight nature type III secretion signal .
plain language summary: Pathogenic bacteria release a number of different proteins that function to interfere with host defenses and allow bacterial invasion, persistence, and replication in the host. In many bacterial pathogens, the type III secretion system is used to inject these virulence factors directly to the cytoplasm of the host cell. The secreted proteins do not have well-conserved sequences and do not have any kind of common identifiable signal sequence to target them for secretion. This makes it very difficult to identify secreted proteins of this kind without experimental investigation, as can be done in other secretion systems. In this study, we develop a computational approach to detect secreted virulence factors from genomic protein sequences. We use this method to compare the N-terminal regions of proteins from S. Typhimurium and a plant pathogen, P. syringae, and show that this approach is the most effective method of computational identification of type III secreted proteins to date. We further use this approach to identify a sequence pattern in these proteins that presumably helps direct virulence proteins to the type III secretion apparatus. We provide novel predictions of secreted proteins in these two organisms, as well as in the human pathogen C. trachomatis. Better understanding of secreted virulence factors in pathogens will lead to new ways of combating important infectious diseases and provide understanding of the complex interaction between pathogen and host.
generated_summary: The type III secretion system is an essential component of virulence of Gram-negative bacteria. The components of the secretion system are conserved, but the substrates—effector proteins—are not. We developed a novel computational approach to confidently identify new secreted effectors integrating protein sequence-based features, including evolutionary measures of the pattern of homologs in a range of organisms, G+C content, amino acid composition, and N-terminal 30 residues of protein sequence. Our method trained known effectors from the plant pathogen Pseudomonas syringae and validated a set of effectors for the animal pathogen Salmonella enterica serovar Typhimurium (S. Typhimsurium) by eliminating effectors with detectable sequence similarity. Our approach was able to predict known secreted effectsors with high specificity and sensitivity. Furthermore, considering a large set effectors in multiple organisms, we computationally identify the most common putative secretion signal in the sequence of 20 residues of the secreted proteins, suggesting that a real, shared signal may be applicable to the type III secreted signal.

abstract: Effective immune responses require directed migration leukocytes vasculature site injury infection . immune cells “ find ” site extravasation remains largely obscure . , identified previously unrecognized role platelets pathfinders guiding leukocytes exit points microvasculature : onset inflammation , circulating platelets found immediately adhere distinct sites venular microvessels enabling cellular blood components capture neutrophils , turn , inflammatory monocytes CD40 - CD40L - dependent interactions . cellular crosstalk , ligation PSGL-1 P - selectin leads ERK1/2 MAPK - dependent conformational changes leukocyte integrins , promote successive extravasation neutrophils monocytes perivascular tissue . Conversely , blockade cellular partnership resulted misguided , inefficient leukocyte responses . experimental data uncover platelet - directed , spatiotemporally organized , multicellular crosstalk essential effective trafficking leukocytes site inflammation .
plain language summary: White blood cells (leukocytes) are the effector cells of the immune system. The movement (extravasation) of leukocytes from the bloodstream to the surrounding tissue is a prerequisite for proper host defense. Platelets are anucleate cell particles that circulate in the blood and play a fundamental role in hemostasis. Here, we report a previously unrecognized function of platelets as "pathfinders" guiding leukocytes to their site of extravasation. Upon onset of the inflammatory response, platelets were found to immediately adhere to specific sites in the smallest venular microvessels. At these "hot spots", platelets capture intravascularly crawling neutrophils and, in turn, inflammatory monocytes. The cellular crosstalk arising from these interactions leads to conformational changes of distinct adhesion molecules on the surface of leukocytes, subsequently promoting the extravasation of these immune cells to the inflamed tissue. Conversely, blockade of this cellular partnership leads to misguided and inefficient leukocyte responses. Thus, platelet-directed guidance of leukocytes to confined sites of extravasation appears to be a critical step in the recruitment process of immune cells, which might emerge as a promising therapeutic target for the prevention and treatment of inflammatory pathologies.
generated_summary: Infection is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. The immune response to an infection requires the migration of leukocytes from the vasculature to the site of injury. However, how immune cells “find” the “right” site of extravasation remains largely obscure. Here, we identified previously unrecognized roles of platelets as pathfinders guiding leukocyte exit points from the microvasculature: onset of inflammation, circulating platelets are found to immediately adhere to distinct sites of venular microvessels enabling cellular blood components to capture neutrophils, in turn, inflammatory monocytes and CD40-CD40L-dependent interactions. We found that cellular crosstalk, ligation of PSGL-1 and P-selectin leads to ERK1/2 and MAPK-dependent conformational changes in leukeocyte integrins, which promote successive extravasations of neutrophil and monocytes in perivascular tissue. Conversely, blockade of cellular partnership resulted in misguided, inefficient leukocyocyte responses. Our experimental data uncover a platelet-directed, spatiotemporally organized, multicellular crostalk that is essential for effective trafficking of Leukocytes to site inflammation.

Despite clear importance human biology health , molecular mechanisms underlying multiciliated cell differentiation poorly understood . Prior studies implicate distal appendage / transition fiber protein CEP164 central regulator primary ciliogenesis ; , role multiciliogenesis remains unknown . study , generated novel conditional mouse model lacks CEP164 multiciliated tissues testis . mice profound loss airway , ependymal , oviduct multicilia develop hydrocephalus male infertility . primary cultures tracheal multiciliated cells model system , found CEP164 critical multiciliogenesis , , regulation small vesicle recruitment , ciliary vesicle formation , basal body docking . addition , CEP164 necessary proper recruitment distal appendage / transition fiber protein Chibby1 ( Cby1 ) binding partners FAM92A FAM92B ciliary base multiciliated cells . contrast primary ciliogenesis , CEP164 dispensable recruitment intraflagellar transport ( IFT ) components multicilia . Altogether , studies unravel unique requirements CEP164 primary versus multiciliogenesis suggest CEP164 modulates selective transport membrane vesicles cargoes ciliary compartment multiciliated cells . Furthermore , mouse model provides useful tool gain physiological insight diseases associated defective multicilia .
plain language summary: Lining the airways, brain ventricles, and oviducts, multicilia are small hair-like structures that beat in a whip-like motion to propel fluids, such as mucus, over cell surfaces. Dysfunction of multicilia arising from genetic perturbations is most prominently associated with a devastating disorder called primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD). PCD is a rare genetic disease characterized by hydrocephalus, chronic airway infection, and infertility. Furthermore, defective airway multicilia have been implicated in several respiratory diseases, including cystic fibrosis, asthma, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disorder (COPD). While important to human health, the detailed molecular mechanisms of how multiciliated cells develop remain largely unknown. Here, we establish a new mouse model that lacks the key ciliary protein CEP164 in multiciliated cells. These mice recapitulate many symptoms of PCD patients such as hydrocephalus and infertility. We show that, in the absence of CEP164, differentiation of airway multiciliated cells is severely perturbed at multiple steps. Importantly, our data also suggest that CEP164 differentially regulates the proper recruitment of membrane-associated ciliary proteins. In summary, we have developed a powerful mouse model to study diseases affecting multicilia and shed light on novel roles of CEP164 in multiciliogenesis.
generated_summary: Multiciliated cells provide a motive force for mucociliary clearance, cerebrospinal fluid circulation, and ovum transport. Despite the clear importance of human biology and health, the molecular mechanisms underlying multiciliated cell differentiation are poorly understood. Prior studies implicate the distal appendage/transformation fiber protein CEP164 as a central regulator of primary ciliogenesis; however, the role of multiciliogenesis remains unknown. In this study, we generated a conditional mouse model of multiciliated cells in the testis. We found that multicilia have profound loss of airway, ependymal, oviduct and multicilia and develop hydrocephalus and male infertility. Furthermore, we found that Cep164 is required for proper recruitment of small vesicles, ciliary vesicle formation, basal body docking, and ciliary motility. In addition, we show that cEP164 is necessary for the proper recruitment and recruitment of distal and transition fiber protein Chibby1 (Cby1) and its binding partners FAM92A and FAM92B to the ciliary base. These findings provide a useful tool to gain physiological insight into diseases associated with defective multicilia.

abstract: Aberrant protein aggregation hallmark age - related diseases , little known proteins aggregate age non - disease setting . systematic proteomics approach , identified proteins insoluble age multicellular organism Caenorhabditis elegans . proteins predicted significantly enriched β - sheets , promote disease protein aggregation . Strikingly , insoluble proteins highly - represented aggregates found human neurodegeneration . examined proteins vivo confirmed propensity aggregate age . Different proteins aggregated different tissues cellular compartments . Protein insolubility aggregation significantly delayed halted reduced insulin / IGF-1 - signaling , slows aging . found significant overlap proteins insoluble proteins influence lifespan and/or polyglutamine - repeat aggregation . , overexpressing aggregating protein enhanced polyglutamine - repeat pathology . findings indicate widespread protein insolubility aggregation inherent aging influence lifespan neurodegenerative disease .
plain language summary: In neurodegenerative diseases, such as Alzheimer's disease and Huntington's disease, specific proteins escape the cell's quality-control system and associate together, forming insoluble aggregates. Until now, little was known about whether proteins aggregate in a non-disease context. In this study, we discovered that the aging process itself, in the absence of disease, leads to the insolubilization and increased aggregation propensity of several hundred proteins in the roundworm Caenorhabditis elegans. These aggregation-prone proteins have distinct structural and functional proprieties. We asked if this inherent age-dependent protein aggregation impacts neurodegenerative diseases. We found that proteins similar to those aggregating in old worms have also been identified as minor components of human disease aggregates. In addition, we showed that higher levels of inherent protein aggregation aggravated toxicity in a C. elegans Huntington's disease model. Inherent protein aggregation is a new biomarker of aging. Understanding how to modulate it will lead to important insights into the mechanisms that underlie aging and protein aggregation diseases.
generated_summary: Aberrant protein aggregation is a hallmark of age-related diseases, but little is known about how proteins aggregate age in a non-disease setting. Using a systematic proteomics approach, we identified proteins that are insoluble in age in the multicellular organism Caenorhabditis elegans. These proteins were predicted to be significantly enriched in β- sheets, which promote disease protein aggregation. Strikingly, these proteins were highly-represented in aggregates found in human neurodegeneration. We examined proteins in vivo and confirmed their propensity to aggregate age. Different proteins were aggregated in different tissues and cellular compartments. Protein insolubility aggregation was significantly delayed by reduced insulin/IGF-1- signaling, which slows aging. We found that the overlap between proteins and insoluble proteins may influence lifespan and/or polyglutamine-repeat aggregation. We also found that overexpressing an aggregating protein enhanced the pathology of polyglucamine- repeat pathology. These findings indicate that widespread protein insoluble aggregation is inherent to aging and may influence the lifespan of neurodegenative disease.

Typhimurium . enteropathogenic bacterium employs adhesins ( e.g. fim ) type III secretion system 1 ( TTSS-1 ) host cell binding , triggering ruffles invasion . Typically , S. Typhimurium invasion focused subset cells multiple bacteria invade ruffle . remained unclear achieved . studied target - site selection tissue culture time lapse microscopy , movement pattern analysis modeling . Flagellar motility ( chemotaxis ) required reaching host cell surface vitro . Subsequently , physical forces trapped pathogen ∼1.5–3 s “ near surface swimming ” . increased local pathogen density facilitated “ scanning ” host surface topology . observed transient TTSS-1 fim - independent “ stopping ” irreversible TTSS-1 - mediated docking , particular sites prominent topology , i.e. base rounded - cells membrane ruffles . data indicate target site selection cooperative infection membrane ruffles attributable near surface swimming . mechanism general importance understanding infection flagellated bacteria .
plain language summary: The animal body is protected by physical, chemical and immunological barriers. Identification of “promising” target sites is therefore of importance for any pathogen. This crucial step of the infection is still poorly understood. Here, we have studied target site selection by the flagellated Gram-negative gut pathogen Salmonella Typhimurium. Using a well-established tissue culture model system, we found that flagella-driven motility forces the bacterium into a “near surface swimming” mode which facilitates “scanning” of the host cell surface. The near surface swimming was found to target the pathogen towards sites with particular topological features, i.e., rounded cells and membrane ruffles. This explains how S. Typhimurium “identifies” particular target sites and infects membrane ruffles in a cooperative manner. Interestingly, the near surface swimming is attributable to generic physical principles acting on moving particles. Therefore, our findings might be of general importance for the infection by motile pathogens.
generated_summary: S. Typhimurium is an enteropathogenic bacterium that causes a wide range of infections in humans and animals. In this study, we analyzed the target-site selection of S. Typhimerium by tissue culture, time lapse microscopy, and movement pattern analysis modeling. We found that the target site selection is dependent on the host cell surface motility (chemotaxis). Flagellar motility is required for the pathogen to reach the host cells surface in vitro. Subsequently, physical forces were trapped by the bacterium at ∼1.5–3 s “near surface swimming”. This increased local pathogen density facilitated “scanning” host surface topology. We observed transient TTSS-1 fim-independent “ stopping” irreversible TTSs-1-mediated docking, and particular sites with prominent topology, i.e. base rounded-cells and membrane ruffles. Our data indicate that target site-selection is cooperative with the infection of membrane ruffsles attributable to near surface swimming.

abstract: Prions , agents causing transmissible spongiform encephalopathies , colonize brain hosts oral , parenteral , intralingual , transdermal uptake . , prions generally considered airborne . report inbred crossbred wild - type mice , tga20 transgenic mice overexpressing PrPC , efficiently develop scrapie exposure aerosolized prions . NSE - PrP transgenic mice , express PrPC selectively neurons , susceptible airborne prions . Aerogenic infection occurred mice lacking B- T - lymphocytes , NK - cells , follicular dendritic cells complement components . Brains diseased mice contained PrPSc transmitted scrapie inoculated mice . conclude aerogenic exposure prions efficacious lead direct invasion neural pathways obligatory replicative phase lymphoid organs . previously unappreciated risk airborne prion transmission warrant - thinking prion biosafety guidelines research diagnostic laboratories .
plain language summary: Prions, which are the cause of fatal neurodegenerative disorders termed transmissible spongiform encephalopathies (TSEs), can be experimentally or naturally transmitted via prion-contaminated food, blood, milk, saliva, feces and urine. Here we demonstrate that prions can be transmitted through aerosols in mice. This also occurs in the absence of immune cells as demonstrated by experiments with mice lacking B-, T-, follicular dendritic cells (FDCs), lymphotoxin signaling or with complement-deficient mice. Therefore, a functionally intact immune system is not strictly needed for aerogenic prion infection. These results suggest that current biosafety guidelines applied in diagnostic and scientific laboratories ought to include prion aerosols as a potential vector for prion infection.
generated_summary: Prions, agents causing transmissible spongiform encephalopathies, colonize the brain through oral, parenteral, intralingual, and transdermal uptake. However, prions are generally considered airborne. Here, we report that inbred crossbred wild-type mice, tga20 transgenic mice, overexpressing PrPC, efficiently develop scrapie exposure from aerosolized prions. We show that the NSE-PrP transgenic mouse, which express PrPC selectively in neurons, is more susceptible to airborne prions than the uninfected mice. Aerogenic infection occurred in mice lacking B- T- lymphocytes, NK-cells, follicular dendritic cells, and complement components. Brains of diseased mice contained PrPSc transmitted to scrapie inoculated mice. We conclude that aerogenic exposure to prions is efficacious and can lead to direct invasion of neural pathways and the obligatory replicative phase of lymphoid organs. This previously unappreciated risk of airborne prion transmission warrant-thinking prion biosafety guidelines for research and diagnostic laboratories.

Currently , effective pharmacological treatment angiostrongyliasis exists . Peptidases known druggable targets variety diseases essential biological processes parasites . , study aimed systematically characterize peptidase activity A. costaricensis different developmental stages parasitic nematode . library diverse tetradecapeptides incubated cellular lysates adult worms - stage larvae ( L1 ) cleaved peptide products identified mass spectrometry . Peptidase activity major mechanistic classes ( aspartic , metallo , serine cysteine ) detected adult worm lysate , aspartic , metallo serine - peptidases found larval lysates . addition , substrate specificity profile found vary different pH values . proteolytic activities adult worm L1 lysates characterized highly diversified library peptide substrates activity validated selection fluorescent substrates . Taken , peptidase signatures different developmental stages parasite improved understanding disease pathogenesis useful potential drug targets vaccine candidates .
plain language summary: A. costaricensis is a poorly studied nematode that causes abdominal angiostrongyliasis, a human parasitic disease. Peptidases perform several functions in the life cycle of parasites, including nutrition, differentiation and host invasion. The present study characterized the repertoire of peptidases in A. costaricensis lysates using a combination of peptide degradation screening using mass spectrometry and validation of the activity using fluorescent substrates and class-specific peptidase inhibitors. The results improved our understanding of the role of these peptidases in parasite biology, shedding light on the underlying disease mechanisms.
generated_summary: Angiostrongylus costaricensis is a relatively uncharacterized nematode that causes abdominal angiostrabyliasis in Latin America, a human parasitic disease. Currently, no effective pharmacological treatment for angioplasty or other parasitic diseases exists. Peptidases are known to be druggable targets for a variety of diseases essential for the biological processes of parasites. In this study, we aimed to systematically characterize peptidase activity in different developmental stages of the parasite. We used a library of diverse tetradecapeptides incubated in cellular lysates of adult worms-stage larvae (L1) and cleaved peptide products identified by mass spectrometry. Lysates were treated with class specific peptidases inhibitors to determine the enzyme class responsible for proteolytic activity. We found that proteolysis activity of the major mechanistic classes (aspartic, metallo, and serine cysteine) was detected in adult worm lysate, aspartic and metallo serine-peptidase. In addition, substrate specificity profile was found to vary with different pH values. Our results suggest that peptididase signatures are important for the development of drug targets for human parasitic diseases.

Addition glutathione A. fumigatus ΔgliT strains relieved gliotoxin inhibition . , expression gliT appears independently regulated compared cluster components - regulated exogenous gliotoxin presence , transcript protein level . gliotoxin exposure , gliT expressed A. fumigatus ΔgliZ , express genes gliotoxin biosynthetic cluster , indicating gliT primarily responsible protecting strain exogenous gliotoxin . GliT exhibits gliotoxin reductase activity 9 µM gliotoxin appears prevent irreversible depletion intracellular glutathione stores reduction oxidized form gliotoxin . Cross - species resistance exogenous gliotoxin acquired A. nidulans Saccharomyces cerevisiae , respectively , transformed gliT. hypothesise primary role gliotoxin antioxidant addition GliT functionality , gliotoxin secretion component auto - protective mechanism , deployed A. fumigatus protect potent biomolecule .
plain language summary: The pathogenic fungus Aspergillus fumigatus causes disease in immunocompromised individuals such as cancer patients. The fungus makes a small molecule called gliotoxin which helps A. fumigatus bypass the immune system in ill people, and cause disease. Although a small molecule, gliotoxin biosynthesis is enabled by a complex series of enzymes, one of which is called GliT, in A. fumigatus. Amazingly, nobody has really considered that gliotoxin might be toxic to A. fumigatus itself. Here we show that absence of GliT makes A. fumigatus highly sensitive to added gliotoxin and inhibits fungal growth, both of which can be reversed by restoring GliT. Neither can the fungus make or release its own gliotoxin when GliT is missing. We also show that gliotoxin sensitivity can be totally overcome by adding glutathione, which is an important anti-oxidant within cells. We demonstrate that gliotoxin addition increases the production of GliT, and that GliT breaks the disulphide bond in gliotoxin which may be a step in the pathway for gliotoxin protection or release from A. fumigatus. We conclude that gliotoxin may mainly be involved in protecting A. fumigatus against oxidative stress and that it is an accidental toxin.
generated_summary: Aspergillus fumigatus is one of the most virulent fungi in the world. Gliotoxin is an important component of the virulence arsenal of the fungus, and is encoded by multi-gene clusters of biosynthesized fungi that are non-ribosomal and biosynthetic mechanisms. Although it is universally described in terms of toxicity in mammalian cells, gliotoxin has come to come to be considered a component of its virulent arsenal. In this study, we have deleted a single gene, gliT, from the gliotoxins biosynthesis cluster of A. fumagatus strains, which rendered the organism highly sensitive to exogenous gliototoxin. GliT is expressed in A. nidulans and Saccharomyces cerevisiae, respectively, and we show that gliTs is primarily responsible for protecting the strain from exogenous Gliotoxoxins. We also show that GliTs exhibits a gliotoxic reductase activity of 9 µM and that glitoxin appears to prevent irreversible depletion of intracellular glutathione stores by the reduction of the oxidized form of gliotiotoxin. Cross-species resistance of exogenous and non-robotoxins acquired from the same species and from A. vesicularis and A. spp., respectively, was transformed by the addition of gliTS. We hypothesise a primary role for gliotin as an antioxidant in addition to its glitoxins and an auto-protective mechanism, deployed by the fungus to protect the potent biomolecule.

abstract: Sporadic Creutzfeldt - Jakob disease ( sCJD ) prevalent human prion diseases , fatal transmissible neurodegenerative diseases caused infectious prion protein ( PrPSc ) . origin sCJD unknown , initiating event thought stochastic misfolding endogenous prion protein ( PrPC ) infectious PrPSc . contrast , human growth hormone - associated cases iatrogenic CJD ( iCJD ) United Kingdom ( UK ) associated exposure exogenous source PrPSc . forms CJD , heterozygosity residue 129 methionine ( M ) valine ( V ) prion protein gene affect disease phenotype , onset progression . , relative contribution PrPC allotype PrPSc heterozygous cases CJD unknown . mass spectrometry , determined relative abundance PrPSc M V residue 129 brain specimens MV cases sCJD highly variable . result consistent PrPC containing M V residue 129 having similar propensity misfold PrPSc causing sCJD . contrast , PrPSc V residue 129 predominated majority UK human growth hormone associated iCJD cases , consistent exposure infectious PrPSc containing V residue 129 . types CJD , PrPSc allotype ratio correlation CJD type , age clinical onset , disease duration . , factors PrPSc allotype abundance influence clinical progression phenotype heterozygous cases CJD .
plain language summary: In Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD), heterozygosity at residue 129 for methionine or valine in normal prion protein may affect disease phenotype, onset and progression. However, the relative contribution of each prion protein allotype to the infectious, disease associated form of prion protein (PrPSc) is unknown. Here we report the novel observation that in heterozygous cases of sporadic CJD the PrPSc allotype ratio is highly variable. This case-by-case variability is consistent with the origin of sporadic CJD being the spontaneous, but random, misfolding of either host prion protein allotype into infectious PrPSc. By contrast, in heterozygous cases of iatrogenic CJD in the United Kingdom resulting from exposure to contaminated human growth hormone, the PrPSc allotype ratio is much more homogeneous and consistent with exposure to infectious PrPSc containing valine at residue 129. Surprisingly, the PrPSc allotype ratio did not correlate with disease onset or duration in either disease type. Thus, factors other than PrPSc allotype ratio likely influence the clinical progression of heterozygous cases of CJD. Moreover, our results suggest that the ratio of methionine to valine in PrPSc may be a means of determining the origin of prion infection.
generated_summary: Sporadic Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) is one of the most prevalent human prion diseases, and is caused by infectious prion protein (PrPSc). The origin of sCJD is unknown, and the initiating event is thought to be stochastic misfolding of the endogenous prion proteins (PrPC) by infectious PrPSc. In contrast, human growth hormone-associated cases of iatrogenic CJD (iCJD), in the United Kingdom (UK), are associated with exposure to an exogenous source of prPSc, which is known to cause disease phenotype, onset, and disease duration. However, the relative contribution of PrPC allotype to PrCJD in heterozygous cases of CJD is unknown. Using mass spectrometry, we determined the relative abundance of PrPPSc M V residue 129 in brain specimens of MV cases of the UK. We found that PrPC containing M V and 129 having a similar propensity to misfold PrPsc causing sCsJD. In comparison, PrPSC containing V and 124 predominated in the majority of UK human growth hormones associated with iCJD cases, consistent with exposure of infectious PrPsSc containing V or 129. These results suggest that the factors that influence CJD type, age and clinical onset, disease duration, and clinical progression are important for the clinical progression and phenotype of heterozygozygous and non-homozygous CJD cases.

plain language summary: Child development in early childhood lays a foundation for lifelong learning.Risk and protective factors for child development are known to include many issues faced by children growing up in low- and middle-income countries.Studies indicate a difference between boys and girls in terms of impact of factors influencing development, but these have not been evaluated in a sub-Saharan African context.We assessed child development at 2 years of 734 children in the Drakenstein Child Health Study, Western Cape, South Africa.We assessed potential risk and protective factors identified from prior literature to impact child development.We found a number of important risk factors that contributed to poor developmental outcomes in children in this cohort.Boys appear to be at higher risk of poor developmental performance in a high-risk environment.Key protective factors include mothers having at least some secondary school education, better home circumstances, and healthy birth weight, and key risk factors include maternal anaemia in pregnancy, poor maternal health (such as HIV), and maternal mental health problems.Child sex interacts with the associations between key protective and risk factors and developmental outcomes.Understanding the related and interacting roles of factors reported in this study may inform integrated intervention policy design and implementation for supporting development in high-risk environments.
generated_summary: The Drakenstein Child Health Study is a population-based birth cohort of women in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) who are failing to meet their developmental potential. The study was conducted in the Western Cape, South Africa, between 2012 and 2015. We found that children with low household employment (n = 183; 24.9%) and low household income had a high prevalence of maternal psychosocial risk factors including alcohol use, smoking, loss of follow-up or unavailability of a caregiver for the child correct age. We also found a high proportion of children with delayed developmental outcomes. These findings highlight important protective effects of maternal education, birth weight, socioeconomic status and developmental outcomes on sex differences in developmental outcomes and are key risk factors in this group.

abstract: Personal exome genome sequencing provides access loss - - function rare deleterious alleles interpretation expected provide insight individual disease burden . , allele , accurate interpretation effect depend penetrance trait expressivity . regard , important factor modify effect pathogenic coding allele level expression ; factor characteristically changes tissues . better inform degree pathogenic alleles modified expression level multiple tissues , conducted exome , RNA deep , targeted allele - specific expression ( ASE ) sequencing tissues obtained single individual . combining data , report impact rare common loss - - function variants allelic expression exposing stronger allelic bias rare stop - gain variants informing extent rare deleterious coding alleles consistently expressed tissues . study demonstrates potential importance transcriptome data interpretation pathogenic protein - coding variants .
plain language summary: Gene expression is a fundamental cellular process that contributes to phenotypic diversity. Gene expression can vary between alleles of an individual through differences in genomic imprinting or cis-acting regulatory variation. Distinguishing allelic activity is important for informing the abundance of altered mRNA and protein products. Advances in sequencing technologies allow us to quantify patterns of allele-specific expression (ASE) in different individuals and cell-types. Previous studies have identified patterns of ASE across human populations for single cell-types; however the degree of tissue-specificity of ASE has not been deeply characterized. In this study, we compare patterns of ASE across multiple tissues from a single individual using whole transcriptome sequencing (RNA-Seq) and a targeted, high-resolution assay (mmPCR-Seq). We detect patterns of ASE for rare deleterious and loss-of-function protein-coding variants, informing the frequency at which allelic expression could modify the functional impact of personal deleterious protein-coding across tissues. We demonstrate that these interactions occur for one third of such variants however large direction flips in allelic expression are infrequent.
generated_summary: In this study, we report the impact of loss-of-function and rare deleterious alleles on the expression level of pathogenic protein-coding variants in tissues obtained from a single individual. By combining data from exome, RNA deep, targeted and targeted allele-specific expression (ASE) sequencing, we provide insight into the impact on rare common loss-to-function variants and the extent to which rare stop-gain variants are consistently expressed in tissues. This study demonstrates the potential importance of transcriptome data for interpretation of the effect on pathogenic proteins and the role of a factor characteristically changes in tissues in order to better inform the degree to which pathogenic alleles modified expression level in multiple tissues.

abstract: Ypd1 phosphorelay protein central constituent fungal - component signal transduction pathways . Inhibition Ypd1 Saccharomyces cerevisiae Cryptococcus neoformans lethal sustained activation ‘ p38 - related ’ Hog1 stress - activated protein kinase ( SAPK ) . - component signalling proteins found animals , Ypd1 considered prime antifungal target . , major fungal pathogen humans , Candida albicans , survive concomitant sustained activation Hog1 occurs cells lacking YPD1 . sustained activation Hog1 Ypd1 loss mediated Ssk1 response regulator . , present evidence C. albicans survives SAPK activation short - term , following Ypd1 loss , triggering induction protein tyrosine phosphatase - encoding genes prevent accumulation lethal levels phosphorylated Hog1 . addition , studies reveal unpredicted , reversible , mechanism acts substantially reduce levels phosphorylated Hog1 ypd1Δ cells following long - term sustained SAPK activation . , time , ypd1Δ cells phenotypically indistinguishable wild - type cells . Investigating underlying causes increased virulence , revealed drug - mediated repression YPD1 expression promotes hyphal growth murine kidneys , following phagocytosis , increasing efficacy C. albicans kills macrophages . Taken , findings challenge targeting Ypd1 proteins general antifungal strategy reveal novel cellular adaptation mechanisms sustained SAPK activation .
plain language summary: As fungi-attributed human deaths are increasing, there is an urgent need to develop new antifungal treatments. Two-component related proteins, such as the Ypd1 phosphorelay protein, have been heralded as antifungal targets as they are not found in humans and because inactivation of YPD1 in several different fungi causes sustained SAPK activation and cell death. However, we have discovered that inactivation of YPD1 in the major human pathogen, Candida albicans, actually enhances virulence. Furthermore, we reveal that this fungus adapts to the sustained activation of the Hog1 SAPK triggered by Ypd1 loss by mounting distinct mechanisms that actively reduce the level of phosphorylated Hog1. These findings question the validity of Ypd1 proteins as broad-spectrum antifungal targets and provide insights into the cellular adaptation to sustained SAPK activation.
generated_summary: C. albicans is a major fungal pathogen that infects humans and animals. Inhibition of Ypd1 by Saccharomyces cerevisiae and Cryptococcus neoformans results in lethal sustained activation of the ‘p38-related’ Hog1 stress-activated protein kinase (SAPK). In contrast to many other fungal-component signalling proteins found in animals, YPD1 is considered a prime antifungal target. In this study, we show that the ability of C. albinicans to survive concomitant sustained activation by Hog1 occurs in cells lacking YPD 1. In addition, we find that the inhibition of Hog1 by Ypd 1 is mediated by the Ssk1 response regulator. Importantly, we also show that C. Albicans survives sustained SAPK activation in the short-term, following which it is able to induce the induction of protein tyrosine phosphatase-encoded genes that prevent accumulation of lethal levels of phosphorylated Hog1. These findings reveal a novel cellular adaptation mechanism that may be important for the development of effective anti-carcinogenic drugs.

abstract: NF - κB inflammasomes play central roles orchestrating anti - pathogen responses rapidly inducing variety early - response cytokines chemokines following infection . Myxoma virus ( MYXV ) , pathogenic poxvirus rabbits , encodes member cellular pyrin domain ( PYD ) superfamily , called M013 . viral M013 protein previously shown bind host ASC-1 protein inhibit cellular inflammasome complex regulates activation secretion caspase 1 - regulated cytokines IL-1β IL-18 . , report human THP-1 monocytic cells infected MYXV construct deleted M013L gene ( vMyxM013 - KO ) , stark contrast parental MYXV , rapidly induce high levels secreted pro - inflammatory cytokines like TNF , IL-6 , MCP-1 , regulated NF - κB. induction NF - κB regulated cytokines following infection vMyxM013 - KO confirmed vivo THP-1 derived xenografts NOD - SCID mice . vMyxM013 - KO virus infection specifically induced rapid phosphorylation IKK degradation IκBα , followed nuclear translocation NF - κB / p65 . absence virus infection , transiently expressed M013 protein inhibited cellular NF - κB - mediated reporter gene expression nuclear translocation NF - κB / p65 . protein / protein interaction analysis , M013 protein binds directly cellular NF - κB1 , suggesting direct physical functional linkage NF - κB1 ASC-1 . demonstrate inhibition inflammasome caspase-1 inhibitor prevent induction NF - κB regulated cytokines following infection vMyxM013 - KO virus , block activation IL-1β . , poxviral M013 inhibitor exerts dual immuno - subversive role simultaneous co - regulation cellular inflammasome complex NF - κB - mediated pro - inflammatory responses .
plain language summary: Myxoma virus (MYXV), a rabbit-specific poxvirus pathogen, encodes diverse immunomodulatory proteins that can collectively overcome essentially all of the host immune defenses. MYXV-encoded protein M013, a member of the cellular PYRIN domain-containing superfamily of proteins, was previously shown to be important for virus virulence by blocking inflammasome regulated pro-inflammatory cytokine secretion. Here, we report that, in addition to targeting the ASC-1 protein of the host cell inflammasome complex, M013 also blocks activation of NF-κB signaling pathway by interacting with NF-κB1 and preventing nuclear translocation of the transcription factor RelA/p65. MYXV virus lacking a functional M013L gene (vMyxM013-KO) induced the early activation of NF-κB signaling pathway in human monocytic cells, causing the secretion of antiviral pro-inflammatory cytokines in vitro and in vivo. These results demonstrate that MYXV protein M013 is a multifunctional immunosubversive protein that co-regulates both the inflammasome complex and the NF-κB signaling pathway simultaneously.
generated_summary: Myxoma virus (MYXV) encodes a member of the cellular pyrin domain (PYD) superfamily, called M013. The viral M013 protein has previously been shown to bind to the host ASC-1 protein and inhibit the cellular inflammasome complex, which regulates the activation of caspase 1-regulated cytokines IL-1β and IL-18. Here, we report that human THP-1 monocytic cells infected with MYXV construct a deleted M013L gene (vMyxM013-KO) and rapidly induce high levels of secreted pro-inflammatory cytokines like TNF, IL-6, MCP-1, and regulated NF-κB. induction of NF-γκB regulated cytokines following infection with vMyxm013- KO was confirmed in vivo by THP1 derived from xenografts and NOD-SCID mice. We also show that vMYxM012-KO virus infection specifically induced rapid phosphorylation of IKK and degradation of IκBα, followed by nuclear translocation of NF -κB/p65. In the absence of virus infection, transiently expressed M013 proteins inhibited the cellular NF-κB-mediated reporter gene expression and nuclear translocations of NF. These results suggest that the M013 inhibitor exerts a dual immuno-subversive role in simultaneous co-regulation of cellular and inflammaome complex NF- κB and anti-inflammatory responses.

plain language summary: The canid adapted intestinal tapeworms, Echinococcus granulosus, E. multilocularis and E. shuiqucus are well known to be endemic in Northwestern China. The first two species can cause fatal disease in humans. Although E. shiquicus has not been reported to infect humans, all three species can be transmitted by dogs. The very close relationship between dogs and humans can readily lead to human infection. To aid the surveillance and management of echinococcosis, effective diagnostic approaches are urgently needed. We developed a single tube multiplex PCR assay for the accurate identification and discrimination of the three Echinococcus species for use in both clinical diagnosis and epidemiological studies.
generated_summary: Infections of Echinococcus granulosus sensu stricto (s.s), E. multilocularis and E. shiquicus are commonly found in co-endemic Qinghai-Tibet plateau, China. A single-tube multiplex PCR assay has been established to differentiate E. granulococcus species responsible for the infections of intermediate definitive hosts. Primers specific to E. sensu puncto (nad1) were designed based on the sequences of mitochondrial NADH dehydrogenase subunit 1 ( nad5), cytochrome c oxidase (cox1) and genes, respectively. Multiplex PCR accurately detected E. s.s. DNA generating nonspecific reaction products. The PCR products were expected to be sizes of 219 (Nad1), 584 (ncad5) and 471 (cx1), bp. Furthermore, multiplex amplification enabled the diagnosis of multiple infections of DNA protoscoleces and copro-DNA extracted from fecal samples of canine hosts. Specificity of multiplex DNA was 100% evaluated by DNA isolated from cestodes. Sensitivity thresholds were determined by 20 pg DNA of E. ganulosum, 10 pg DNA from E. schiquicus and 10 pg of DNA for E. mnolocularis, 2 eggs in E. grululososus, 1 egg and 1 egg of E., respectively. These results indicate that multiplex-PCR is an efficient tool for the identification of the infection of the larval and adult stages of the E. species.

plain language summary: Genome-Wide Association Studies (GWAS) can reveal genetic-phenotypic relationships, but have limitations. To control false positives, population structure and kinship are incorporated in a fixed and random effect Mixed Linear Model (MLM). However, because of the confounding between population structure, kinship, and quantitative trait nucleotides (QTNs), MLM leads to false negatives, missing some potentially important discoveries. Here, we present a new method, Fixed and random model Circulating Probability Unification (FarmCPU). FarmCPU performs marker tests with associated markers as covariates in a fixed effect model and optimization on the associated covariate markers in a random effect model separately. This process enables efficient computation, removes the confounding, prevents model over-fitting, and controls false positives simultaneously. FarmCPU controls false positives as well as MLM with reductions in both false negatives and computing times. Researchers will not only be able to analyze big data, but will also have greater success with fewer mistakes when mapping genes of interest.
generated_summary: False positives in the Genome-Wide Association Study (GWAS) are effectively controlled by a fixed effect random effect Mixed Linear Model (MLM). The MLM incorporates population structure and kinship to adjust association tests and markers; however, the adjustment compromises true positives. We have developed a modified MLM method, Multiple Loci Linear Mixed Model, which incorporates multiple markers simultaneously and covariates stepwise. We completely eliminate confounding, divided MLMM into two parts: Fixed Effect Model (FEM) and Random Effect Model. The FEM contains testing markers, time, and multiple associated markers to control false positives. To avoid the model-fitting problem of FEM, the associated markers are estimated in a unified iteration. We named a new method, the Fixed random model Circulating Probability Unification (FarmCPU). FarmCPU improves statistical power compared to current methods. Additional benefits include efficient computing of time and linear number of individuals and the number of markers. FarmCPU can be used in a dataset of half million individuals and half million markers analyzed in days.

plain language summary: The molecular mechanisms that underpin the link between scabies and bacterial pathogens were unknown. We proposed that scabies mites play a role in the establishment, proliferation and transmission of opportunistic pathogens. We investigated here the synergy between mites and one of the most recognised mite associated pathogens, Streptococcus pyogenes. As part of the innate immune response mammals have a pre-programmed ability to recognise and immediately act against substances derived from fungal and bacterial microorganisms. This is mediated through a sequential biochemical cascade involving over 30 different proteins (complement system) which as a result of signal amplification triggers a rapid killing response. The complement cascade produces peptides that attract immune cells, increases vascular permeability, coats (opsonises) the surfaces of a pathogen, marking it for destruction, and directly disrupts foreign plasma membranes. To prevent complement mediated damage of their gut cells, scabies mites secrete several classes of complement inhibiting proteins into the mite gut and excrete them into the epidermal mite burrows. Furthermore, these inhibitors also provide protection for S. pyogenes. We verified here specifically the impact of the mite complement inhibitor SMSB4, to identify the molecular mechanisms behind the long recognised tendency of S. pyogenes to infect mite-induced skin lesions.
generated_summary: Scabies is the most common skin disease in the tropics, causing a considerable economic burden for individuals, communities and health systems. There is substantial epidemiological evidence in tropical regions of scabies causing pyoderma and subsequently illness and invasion by opportunistic bacteria. The health burden of scab causing cellulitis, bacteraemia, sepsis, heart and kidney diseases in resource-poor communities is extreme. Co-infections with group streptococcus (GAS) scabies mites are a common phenomenon in tropics. We investigated the relative role of classical (CP), lectin (LP) alternative pathways (AP) and pyodermic GAS in maintaining baseline immunity against GAS. Opsonophagocytosis assays of fresh blood showed baseline immunity to GAS, and the role of innate immunity was investigated by deposition of the complement components of the pathway, specifically C1q, FB and MBL, in normal human serum of GAS isolates. The results indicate that the complement-inhibitory function of SMSB4 promotes the survival of gAS in vitro inferably from the microenvironment of mite-infested skin. Understanding the tripartite interactions between host, parasite and microbial pathogens at the molecular level will serve as the basis to develop improved intervention strategies targeting scabies associated bacterial infections.

plain language summary: Most bacteria live in biofilms, microbial communities that cause more than 80% of human infections. Biofilms have a genetically identical sub-population of dormant cells, named persister cells, which are the well-recognized source of antibiotic resistance. Recently, it was demonstrated that toxins are highly upregulated in persisters and have therefore been postulated to play a role in the persister state. Using an inter-disciplinary approach, we reveal how mqsR, the gene most highly upregulated in persisters, together with mqsA, function: they are the founding members of a new family of toxin:antitoxin (TA) systems. Unexpectedly, the structure of MqsR reveals that it is a ribonuclease, a protein that controls the production of other essential proteins. Moreover, we identified multiple features of this TA system that are so unique that each is a starting point for drug development. Unlike other antitoxins, MqsA is structured throughout its entire sequence, its structure is unchanged between the free and toxin-bound states and it binds zinc. It also binds DNA via its C- and not N-terminal domain. Finally, MqsA binds both its own promoter and additional genes important for E. coli physiology. Taken together, our data provide fundamental new insights into the role of MqsR and MqsA in bacterial persistence and biofilms.
generated_summary: The ability of bacteria to survive environmental stress is essential for the survival of bacterial persisters, a sub-population of genetically identical quiescent cells that exhibit multidrug tolerance to highly enriched bacterial toxins. Recently, Escherichia coli gene mqsR (b3022) was identified as a gene highly upregulated in persisters. Here, we report multiple individual complex-dimensional structures of MqsR and antitoxin MqsA (B3021). We reveal that MqsRs: MqsAs form a novel toxin: antitoxin (TA) pair. MqsS adopts an α/β fold homologous RelE/YoeB family of bacterial ribonuclease toxins. MqA is elongated dimer and neutralizes MqsRS toxicity. Unlike the expected TA pair, MqsB binds to promoter genes important for E. coli physiology (e.g. mcbR, spy) and is structured into an entire sequence, which binds to zinc coordinates in the DNA C-N-terminal domain. These studies reveal that TA systems, especially antitoxins, are significantly diverse and may provide new insights into the role of toxins in maintaining the persister state.
