DNA combing , observed defect replication fork progression Fhit - deficient cells stemmed primarily fork stalling collapse . likely mechanism role Fhit replication fork progression regulation Thymidine kinase 1 expression thymidine triphosphate pool levels ; notably , restoration nucleotide balance rescued DNA replication defects suppressed DNA breakage Fhit - deficient cells . Depletion Fhit activate DNA damage response cause cell cycle arrest , allowing continued cell proliferation ongoing chromosomal instability . finding accord vivo studies , Fhit knockout mouse tissue showed evidence cell cycle arrest senescence exhibited numerous somatic DNA copy number aberrations replication stress - sensitive loci . Furthermore , cells established Fhit knockout tissue showed rapid immortalization selection DNA deletions amplifications , including amplification Mdm2 gene , suggesting Fhit loss - induced genome instability facilitates transformation . propose loss Fhit expression precancerous lesions step initiation genomic instability , linking alterations common fragile sites origin genome instability .
plain language summary: Normal cells have robust mechanisms to maintain the proper sequence of their DNA; in cancer cells these mechanisms are compromised, resulting in complex changes in the DNA of tumors. How this genome instability begins has not been defined, except in cases of familial cancers, which often have mutations in genes called “caretaker” genes, necessary to preserve DNA stability. We have defined a mechanism for genome instability in non-familial tumors that occur sporadically in the population. Certain fragile regions of our DNA are more difficult to duplicate during cell division and are prone to breakage. A fragile region, FRA3B, lies within the FHIT gene, and deletions within FRA3B are common in precancer cells, causing loss of Fhit protein expression. We find that loss of Fhit protein causes defective DNA replication, leading to further DNA breaks. Cells that continue DNA replication in the absence of Fhit develop numerous chromosomal aberrations. Importantly, cells established from tissues of mice that are missing Fhit undergo selection for increasing DNA alterations that can promote immortality, a cancer cell hallmark. Thus, loss of Fhit expression in precancer cells is the first step in the initiation of genomic instability and facilitates cancer development.
generated_summary: Genomic instability drives tumorigenesis, but the origin of genomic instability is unknown. In early preneoplasias, alterations in chromosome fragile sites arise from DNA replication stress. The most frequent, earliest, genetic alteration is the deletion of the fragile FRA3B/FHIT locus, leading to loss of Fhit protein expression. In cancer cells, Fhit loss is a selective advantage that impairs the loss of expression of fragile gene products. In normal, transformed, cancer-derived cell lines Fhit-depletion causes replication stress-induced DNA double-strand breaks. DNA combing, observed that defect in replication fork progression in Fhit deficient cells stemmed primarily from fork stalling and collapse. The likely mechanism of this defect is the regulation of Thymidine kinase 1 expression and thymidine triphosphate pool levels; notably, restoration of nucleotide balance rescued DNA replication defects and suppressed DNA breakage in cells that were not infected with Fhit. We propose that loss-induced genome instability is a step in the initiation of genome instability.

plain language summary: All multicellular organisms have developed mechanisms to defend themselves against predators, parasites and pathogens. As a common mechanism, animals, plants and fungi use a large arsenal of carbohydrate-binding proteins (lectins) to protect themselves from predation and parasitism. The success of this type of innate defence mechanism critically depends on the diversity of specific recognition of foreign carbohydrate structures by the host lectins. In this study, we use NMR structure determination to show that part of this diversity is created by the plasticity of common protein folds. The identified fungal lectin that is toxic to nematodes and insects, adopts a common lectin fold but is remarkable in terms of its specificity and affinity for the recognized foreign carbohydrate structure, the number and location of the carbohydrate binding sites on the protein and the degree of oligomerization. Since the identified in vivo target of the fungal lectin is characteristic for invertebrates, our results may be exploited to develop novel approaches for the control of animal and human parasites.
generated_summary: The innate defence mechanism is mediated by lectins recognizing non-self carbohydrate structures. This defence relies on an arsenal of host lectins with different specificities to target organism carbohydrate structures and their targets. Recently, cytoplasmic lectins isolated from fungal fruiting bodies have been shown to play a role in defence against multicellular fungi and predators. Here, we present a novel fruiting body lectin, CCL2, in the ink cap mushroom Coprinopsis cinerea. We show that the toxicity of lectin Caenorhabditis elegans and Drosophila melanogaster in C. elegans is mediated through the binding of a complex complex of trisaccharide, GlcNAcβ1,4[Fucα1,3]GlcNc, to a single, topologically novel carbohydrate-binding site. Site-directed mutagenesis of mutants resistant to lectin nematotoxicity mediated by binding to the α1,2-fucosylated N-glycan core structures of nematode glycoproteins. The feeding of fluorescently labeled mutants of CCL 2 demonstrates that the glycoepitope is a target glycoprotein that localizes to the intestine. Our results provide a novel mechanism by which lectin-mediated toxicity can be targeted by mammalian immune systems.

plain language summary: Using a dataset of more than 130,000 de novo mutations we show that there is large-scale variation in the mutation rate at the 100KB and 1MB scales. We show that different types of mutation vary in concert and in a manner that is not expected to generate variation in base composition; hence mutation bias is not responsible for the large-scale variation in base composition that is observed across human chromosomes. As expected, large-scale variation in the rate of divergence between species and the variation within species across the genome, are correlated to the rate of mutation, but the correlation between divergence and the mutation rate is not as strong as it could be. We show that biased gene conversion is responsible for weakening the correlation. In contrast, we find that most of the variation across the genome in diversity can be explained by variation in the mutation rate. Finally, we show that the correlation between the rate of mutation in humans and the divergence between humans and other species, weakens as the species become more divergent.
generated_summary: A long suspected rate of mutation varies across the human genome at large scale based on divergence between humans and other species. However, it is not possible to directly investigate the question of the large number of de novo mutations (DNMs) discovered in humans sequencing trios. We investigate the number of questions pertaining to the distribution of mutations in 130,000 DNMs in large datasets. We show that pattern variation differs between datasets at 1 MB and 100 KB scales probably consequence of differences in sequencing technology and processing time. In particular, datasets with different patterns of correlation between genomic variables and replication time are likely to represent true patterns. We find that variation in mutation rate at 100 KB, 1 MB, and 10 MB scales is explained by variation at smaller scales, and that level variation at modest large scales –1 MB scale infer ~90% of regions of mutation rate 50% mean. Different types of mutation with similar levels of variation appear to vary in concert, which suggests that the pattern of mutation is relatively constant in the genome. We also find that genomic features explain 40% of the explainable variance in the rate of DNM. These findings provide evidence that the effect of biased gene conversion probability on mutation rate is fixed. Finally, we find that the correlation between divergence and DNM density declines as increasingly divergent species are considered.

abstract: Novel experimental techniques reveal simultaneous activity larger larger numbers neurons . result increasing interest structure cooperative – correlated – activity neural populations , possible impact correlations neural code . fundamental theoretical challenge understand architecture network connectivity dynamical properties single cells shape magnitude timescale correlations . provide general approach problem extending prior techniques based linear response theory . consider networks general integrate - - fire cells arbitrary architecture , provide explicit expressions approximate cross - correlation constituent cells . correlations depend strongly operating point ( input mean variance ) neurons , connectivity fixed . , approximations admit expansion powers matrices describe network architecture . expansion readily interpreted terms paths different cells . apply results large excitatory - inhibitory networks , demonstrate precise balance – lack thereof – strengths timescales excitatory inhibitory synapses reflected overall correlation structure network . derive explicit expressions average correlation structure randomly connected networks . expressions help identify important factors shape coordinated neural activity networks .
plain language summary: Is neural activity more than the sum of its individual parts? What is the impact of cooperative, or correlated, spiking among multiple cells? We can start addressing these questions, as rapid advances in experimental techniques allow simultaneous recordings from ever-increasing populations. However, we still lack a general understanding of the origin and consequences of the joint activity that is revealed. The challenge is compounded by the fact that both the intrinsic dynamics of single cells and the correlations among then vary depending on the overall state of the network. Here, we develop a toolbox that addresses this issue. Specifically, we show how linear response theory allows for the expression of correlations explicitly in terms of the underlying network connectivity and known single-cell properties – and that the predictions of this theory accurately match simulations of a touchstone, nonlinear model in computational neuroscience, the general integrate-and-fire cell. Thus, our theory should help unlock the relationship between network architecture, single-cell dynamics, and correlated activity in diverse neural circuits.
generated_summary: Neurons have been shown to be highly correlated with each other. However, it is not clear how such correlations can be explained. Here, we address this problem by extending prior techniques based on linear response theory. We provide explicit expressions for the average correlation structure of randomly connected networks. We show that correlations depend strongly on the operating point (the input mean variance) of neurons, and connectivity is fixed. Our approximations admit expansion powers of matrices that describe network architecture. We apply our results to large excitatory-inhibitory networks, and demonstrate that the precise balance between the strengths and the strengths of the timescales of excitsatory and inhibitory synapses reflected in the overall correlation structure in the network. These expressions help identify important factors that shape coordinated neural activity networks.

Following internalization , HCV particles transport GFP - Rab5a positive endosomes , consistent trafficking early endosome . study presents technical advances imaging HCV entry , addition identifying new host cofactors HCV infection , antiviral targets .
plain language summary: Hepatitis C virus (HCV) chronically infects 130 million people and is a major cause of cirrhosis and liver cancer. The current antiviral therapy of pegylated interferon-2 alfa + ribavirin is successful in only half of treated patients. This has led to an intensive effort to design improved therapeutic strategies. The identification of cellular cofactors of HCV infection greatly expands the pool of potential targets for drug design. In this paper, we combine RNA interference analysis of HCV endocytosis with the development of live cell imaging of highly infectious HCV particles. We identify 16 host cofactors of HCV entry, most of which function in sequential stages of clathrin-mediated endocytosis. We observe the trafficking of fluorescent HCV particles with these cellular cofactors and their related pathways, including the actin cytoskeleton, known receptors CD81 and the tight junction protein claudin-1, clathrin, an E3 ubiquitin ligase, and early endosomes. Surprisingly, given the role of tight junction proteins as HCV entry factors, virion entry generally occurred outside of cell-cell junctions. This paper identifies novel host targets for therapeutic development, describes techniques to image HCV entry, and provides insights into HCV-cell interactions in the entry process.
generated_summary: Hepatitis C virus (HCV) enters hepatocytes following a complex set of receptor interactions, culminating in internalization and clathrin-mediated endocytosis. However, aside from receptors, little is known about the cellular molecular requirements for infectious HCV entry. Here, we analyzed the siRNA library of 140 cellular membrane trafficking genes and identified 16 host cofactors that are required for HCV production and pseudoparticle entry. We identified 16 of the 16 host genes required for the entry of HCV into hepatocytes, including components of the Clathrin endocytic machinery, actin polymerization, receptor internalization, sorting, and endosomal acidification. We developed a single particle tracking analysis of highly infectious fluorescent HCV particles to examine the co-translational interactions between HCV virions and cellular proteins. We observe multiple, sequential interactions between the HCV and the actin cytoskeleton, including retraction of filopodia, actins nucleation and internalization. HCV co-localizes with clathr ubiquitin ligase c-Cbl prior to internalization; HCV-claudin-1 interactions are restricted to Huh-7.5 cell-cell junctions. Surprisingly, HCV internalization generally occurred outside Huh-seven.5 and cell-cells junctions, reflecting the poorly polarized nature of current HCV cell culture models. Following internalization in HCV particle transport to GFP-Rab5a positive endosomes, consistent with trafficking into the early endosome. Our study presents technical advances in imaging and HCV infection, in addition to identifying new host genes that may be antiviral targets.

plain language summary: Lymphatic filariasis (LF) is a neglected tropical disease (NTD) that is targeted for elimination and is thought to be potentially eradicable through once yearly mass drug administration (MDA) using drugs that are currently donated to LF endemic countries by the pharmaceutical companies that manufacture them. MDA has proven to be a cost-effective and efficient method of disease control, both for LF and other NTDs. Previously, we developed scale-up scenarios of varying magnitude to reach elimination (elimination of LF in all countries that have previously undertaken MDA) and eradication (local elimination of LF in all LF endemic countries) and estimated the number of associated treatments that would be necessary in each country under each scenario. Here we project the costs—both financial and economic—of each of these scenarios. We use data from a myriad of sources to estimate the cost of various activities, and found that training and advocacy and communication activities comprise the bulk of the costs of the program. Among all scenarios, elimination requires the least total investment. However, in terms of LF eradication, faster rates of MDA scale-up are associated with decreased overall costs.
generated_summary: Lymphatic filariasis (LF) is a neglected tropical disease (NTD) that is preventable by mass drug administration (MDA) and is considered possibly eradicable. Previously developed LF elimination scenarios assume MDA scale-to-end in countries previously undertaken MDA. In contrast, previously developed LF eradication scenarios assume LF endemic countries undertake MDA average (indication), fast (endemic) and instantaneous (induction III) rate scale-based. In this analysis, we use a micro-costing model to project the financial and economic costs of these scenarios in order to provide evidence of decision makers' investment required to eliminate LF. Costing was undertaken from a health system perspective, with a discount rate of 3% applied to calculate the net present value of future costs. Prospective NTD budgets for LF in endemic countries were reviewed preliminarily to determine the activities and resources necessary to undertake the program and eliminate LF at the country level. In consultation with LF program experts, activities resources were reviewed and a refined list of the necessary resources, associated quantities and costs, determined grouped into the following activities: advocacy communication, capacity strengthening, coordination and strengthening of partnerships, data management, ongoing surveillance, monitoring supervision, drug delivery, administration, and monitoring. The costs of mapping, mapping, and undertaking transmission assessment surveys, and the value of donated drugs and volunteer time were accounted for. Our results indicate that the eradication of LF is an accelerated scale-projected best investment.

abstract: Abiotic environmental variables strongly affect outcomes species interactions . example , mutualistic interactions species stronger resources limited . effect indirect : water stress plants lead carbon stress , alter carbon - mediated plant mutualisms . mutualistic ant – plant symbioses , plants host ant colonies defend herbivores . partners ' investments widespread ant – plant symbiosis increase water stress 26 sites Mesoamerican precipitation gradient . lower precipitation levels , Cordia alliodora trees invest carbon Azteca ants phloem - feeding scale insects provide ants sugars , ants provide better defense carbon - producing leaves . water stress , trees smaller carbon pools . model carbon trade - offs mutualistic partners shows observed strategies arise carbon costs rare extreme events herbivory rainy season . , water limitation , risk herbivory , increases strength carbon - based mutualism .
plain language summary: The strength of ecological interactions, measured as the costs or benefits sustained by each species, depends on the environmental context in which the interaction occurs. Stressful environmental conditions should favor trading between species that can produce a given resource or service at the lowest cost. Mutualisms, in which both interacting species incur a net benefit, may thus strengthen under stressful conditions. Here we examine an ant–plant mutualism, in which plants provide food and housing for ants and ants defend plants against leaf-eating insects, along a four-fold annual precipitation gradient comprising tropical sites in Mexico and Central America. We show that the strength of the mutualism, in terms of carbon investment by plants and leaf defense by ants, increases as water availability decreases. Carbon shortages are more frequent where water is scarce and increase the risk that plants will die if all of their leaves are eaten by herbivores. Trees appear to invest more in ant defenders when water is scarce to insure themselves against extreme herbivory. Water availability thus indirectly determines the outcomes of this ant–plant mutualism, which suggests that the increasing frequency of extreme climate events in the tropics will have important ecological consequences.
generated_summary: Ant–plant symbiosis is an important model for understanding how mutualistic interactions affect the outcomes of species interactions. In this study, we show that plant–ant symbioses can increase the strength of carbon-based mutualism. The partners' investments in widespread ant–parasite symbiosis increase water stress at 26 sites in the Mesoamerican precipitation gradient. We show that plants invest carbon in Azteca ants phloem-feeding scale insects, which provide ants sugars, and ants provide better defense against carbon-producing leaves. We also show that the carbon trade-offs between mutualistic partners arise from carbon costs in rare extreme events such as the herbivory rainy season. In contrast, water limitation, the risk of herbivorous, increases the strength and strength of the carbon-driven mutualism in mutualistic relationships.

plain language summary: One role for silent heterochromatin is to preserve the integrity of the genome by stabilizing regions rich in repetitive sequence and mobile elements. Compaction of repetitive sequences by heterochromatin is needed to prevent genome rearrangement and loss of genetic material. Furthermore, uncontrolled movement of mobile elements throughout the genome can result in deleterious mutations. In fission yeast, one important mechanism of heterochromatin establishment occurs through RNA interference, an RNA–dependent gene silencing process. However, it is unclear whether a direct role for RNA silencing in heterochromatin formation is conserved throughout evolution. In the fruit fly, Drosophila melanogaster, which harbors multiple RNA–silencing pathways that are both functionally distinct and spatially restricted, previous studies have suggested the involvement of the endogenous small interfering RNA (endo-siRNA) and Piwi-interacting RNA (piRNA) pathways in heterochromatin formation. These small RNA silencing pathways suppress the expression of mobile elements in the soma or in both somatic and germline tissues, respectively. Utilizing complementary genetic and biochemical approaches, we monitored the heterochromatin state at discrete genomic locations from which both types of these small RNAs originate in endo-siRNA or piRNA pathway mutants. Our results indicate that heterochromatin can form independently of these two small RNA silencing pathways.
generated_summary: Heterochromatin is a highly repetitive transposable element in the genome, which is stabilized in the presence of heterochromat. The direct role of RNA interference in the establishment and establishment of heteroxromatin has been demonstrated in fission yeast and metazoans. However, the mechanisms by which RNA silencing contributes directly to the formation and formation is not clear. Previous studies have suggested that the AGO2-dependent endogenous small interfering RNA (endo-siRNA) and Piwi-interacting RNA (piRNA) silencing pathways are involved in the formation of heterosomes. In this study, we utilized transcriptional reporters and chromatin immunoprecipitation to identify the critical factor Heterochromeatin Protein 1 (HP1). HP1 is a critical factor that is required to monitor the state of piRNA clusters, generate endo-slices, and bulk piRNAs. Surprisingly, we find that mutation of a gene that is involved in HP1 recruitment results in a genome-wide redistribution of HP1 and reduction of silencing at a distant heterochromeatic site, suggesting indirect effects on HP1 formation. Taken together, our results indicate that heterochroma forms independently of endo–siRNA and piRNA pathways.

plain language summary: Opisthorchiasis, caused by the food-borne trematode Opisthorchis viverrini, affects more than 8 million people in Southeast Asia, and in its chronic phase it might lead to cholangiocarcinoma. Praziquantel (PZQ) is the sole drug available to treat the disease and is administered as a racemic mixture of R and S enantiomers, of which R-PZQ is considered active. As PZQ is rapidly metabolized, its disposition and efficacy in patients might considerably vary according to disease state, sex or age. However, pharmacokinetic (PK) studies on the disposition of PZQ enantiomers and its main metabolite, R-trans-4-OH, in diseased patients are lacking. To allow the collection of PK samples in a large number of patients, we implemented a dried blood spot (DBS) technique, which is less invasive than venipuncture. The aim of our study is to provide first data on the disposition of PZQ enantiomers and the main metabolite of PZQ in opisthorchiasis patients and to validate the use of DBS over venous sampling. Standard PZQ treatment was administered to nine O. viverrini infected patients, and plasma, blood and DBS were simultaneously collected within 24 h post-treatment. We observed a 100-fold higher disposition of the metabolite compared to R-PZQ, which questions its role in the opisthorchidal activity of PZQ. DBS sampling appears to be a valid alternative to venous sampling and will be a valuable tool for future PK studies in PZQ-treated patients.
generated_summary: Praziquantel (PZQ) is a treatment choice for Opisthorchis viverrini, a major health problem in Southeast Asia. However, pharmacokinetic (PK) studies investigating the disposition of PZQ enantiomers and their main metabolite, R-trans-4-OH-PUZQ, in diseased patients are lacking. The implementation of dried blood spot (DBS) sampling technique is an important tool to ease the performance of PK studies in remote areas of clinical facilities. The aim of the present study was to validate the use of DBS compared with plasma blood sampling and validate the efficacy of the DBS as a pharmacodynamic (PD) method. DBS was simultaneously collected from patients with 3 oral doses of 25 mg/kg at 4 h intervals. Plasma, blood and DBS were simultaneously collected at selected time points 0 to 24 h post-treatment. The PK parameters were determined by non-compartmental analysis. Drug concentrations in the areas curve (AUC0–24h) were measured using 3 matrices compared to Bland-Altman analysis. Individual drug concentration measurements in patient AUC0-24hs displayed ratios of blood DBS versus plasma of 79–94% and 108–122% of R-S-pZQ and R-Trans-4 -OH, respectively. Pharmacodynamic studies are necessary to correlate PK parameters and efficacy. Dbs appears to be a valid alternative to conventional venous sampling in PZq-treated patients.

plain language summary: Leishmaniases are a set of tropical and sub-tropical diseases caused by protozoan parasites of the genus Leishmania. They affect about 12 million people and cause a high morbidity. Since treatments against all forms of leishmaniasis are limited in number and efficacy, many efforts are made to identify potential drug targets and develop new therapies. Although considerable progress in genetic manipulation of Leishmania parasites have been made, it remains difficult to study molecules or metabolic pathways essential for parasite viability and growth. In the present work, we used a combination of gene deletion and conditional protein destabilization to demonstrate that biosynthesis of the nucleotide sugar UDP-glucose and its derivative UDP-galactose is essential for parasite growth. Addition of a specific ligand to the culture medium of the engineered parasite protected the targeted enzyme from degradation and enabled cell growth and viability. However, removal of the stabilizing compound led to depletion of UDP-glucose and UDP-galactose, growth arrest and cell death. This work thus opens a new possibility for the study of essential proteins.
generated_summary: In Leishmania parasites, the glycoinositolphospholipids galactosylation of nucleotide sugars is regulated by the UDP-glc pyrophosphorylase (UGP). UGP is an enzyme that activates galactose-1-phosphate phosphoglucomutase and is required for the biosynthesis of glucose-6–phosphatase. UGP has previously been shown to affect expression of lipophosphoglycan, resulting in reduced virulence. In this study, we show that deletion of UGP results in the depletion of UDP-Glc and UDP-Gal in vitro, and that UGP does not directly affect the expression of the lipid phosphoglycan. In addition, UGP was able to maintain steady-state pools of nucleotides and preserve the normal glycoinopositolph phospholipid galacto-glycan biosynthesis, at the apparent expense of the lipophilic glycosylation. These results suggest that the absence of the UGP and USP resulted in a reduction in cell death, suggesting that metabolites/essential metabolites are essential.

plain language summary: Prions are infectious agents causing irremediably fatal neurodegenerative diseases in human and in farmed or wild animals. They are thought to be formed from abnormally folded assemblies (PrPSc) of the host-encoded prion protein (PrPC). Different PrPSc conformational variants associated with distinct biological phenotypes, or ‘strains,’ can propagate in the same host. To gain some structural information on the physical relationship between packing order (i.e. quaternary structure) and the strain-specific biological information, we previously subjected PrPSc assemblies from prion strains classified as fast or slow (according to their survival time in susceptible laboratory animals) to sedimentation velocity ultracentrifugation experiments. For the fast strains specifically, the most infectious assemblies sedimented slowly and partitioned from the bulk of PrPSc macromolecular complexes. By changing the solubilization and sedimentation conditions, we established here that a small PrPSc aggregation size and not a low density accounts for these hydrodynamic properties. We further showed that these small assemblies resist proteolytic digestion and outcompete by several orders of magnitude the larger-size assemblies in cell-free prion conversion assays. Thus PrPSc quaternary structure appears to be a determining factor of prion replication dynamics. For certain strains, a discrete subset of PrPSc assemblies appears to be the best template for prion replication.
generated_summary: Prions are proteinaceous infectious agents responsible for fatal neurodegenerative diseases in animals and humans. They are essentially composed of the ubiquitously expressed host-encoded prion protein (PrPC). Stable variations in the PrPSc conformation have been assumed to encode phenotypically tangible prion strains diversity. However, the direct contribution of the prPSc quaternary structure to strain biological information remains unknown. Applying a sedimentation velocity fractionation technique to a panel of ovine prions, classified fast and slow according to incubation time in ovine PrP transgenic mice, we have previously shown that the relationship between prion infectivity and PrPsc quaternaries is univocal. In fast strains specifically, infectivity was sedimented slowly segregated from the bulk proteinase-K resistant PrPs. We carefully separate their respective contributions to size density and hydrodynamic behavior, and performed sedimentation equilibrium under varied solubilization conditions. We found that the density profile and the infectivity of the bulk PrPs tended to overlap with strain, fast slow, leaving size as the main factor for the specific velocity properties of the fast strain infectious component. Our results suggest that the prion quaternarily structure is the most important factor for prion replication dynamics.

plain language summary: Human hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is one of the most common malignancy worldwide and among the leading causes of cancer-related death. HCC is often diagnosed at an advanced stage and there is still no effective therapeutic strategy for non-resectable HCCs. It has been suggested that the therapeutic delivery of certain miRNA(s) has a unique advantage in clinical use. We first find that the plasma levels of miR-101 are significantly down-regulated in HCC patients with distant metastasis and associated closely with HCCs progression and/or worse disease-free survival (DFS). Next, we identify that systemic delivery of lentivirus-mediated miR-101 in an orthotopic liver implanted HCC model of mouse, not only suppresses tumor xenograft growth in the liver, but also substantially blocks intrahepatic metastasis and distant metastasis to the lung and to the mediastinum, resulting in a dramatic abrogation of HCC tumorigenesis and progression in mice without toxicity. Furthermore, functional and/or mechanistic studies of miR-101 demonstrate that miR-101 in HCC cells inhibits Rho/Rac GTPase activation, and blocks HCC cells epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) and angiogenesis, inducing a strong abrogation of HCC tumorigenesis and aggressiveness both in vitro and in vivo.
generated_summary: Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is a cancer caused by the accumulation of small RNAs (miRNAs) in the liver, liver, lung, and mediastinum. In the current study, we observed that plasma levels of miR-101 were significantly lower in distant metastatic HCC patients than in HCCs with distant metastasis. Moreover, in the animal model of HCC, we demonstrated that systemic delivery of lentivirus-mediated microRNA (miRNA) abrogated HCC growth in liver, intrahepatic metastasis, and distant and metastasis in mice, thereby extending life expectancy. Furthermore, enforced overexpression of miRNA by HCC cells decreased EZH2, COX2 and STMN1, directly-regulated a novel target of ROCK2, inhibited Rho/Rho/ Rac GTPase activation, and blocked HCC cell epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) angiogenesis, inducing strong abrogation and tumorigenesis and aggressiveness in vitro and in vivo. These results provide a proof-of-concept for systemic delivery and a powerful anti-HCC therapeutic modality by repressing multiple molecular targets.

plain language summary: The production of red blood cells, platelet-producing megakaryocytes, and immune response-directing granulocytes and monocytes is initiated at an early stage in the developing embryo and continues throughout life. The proportion of each cell type varies depending on the specific needs of the organism. We know that in the mouse embryo, specialized blood progenitor cells emerge in the fetal liver and produce mature blood cells in response to different cues. However, it is difficult to distinguish between red blood cell and white blood cell-producing progenitors with sufficiently high accuracy to study these cues. For example, we know that several childhood blood disorders, such as leukemias, are caused by genetic mutations in blood progenitor cells before birth, but studying the effects of these mutations in a mouse disease model is hampered if we don’t know which blood progenitor cells to collect. We have used different genetic markers to help distinguish red blood cell, megakaryocyte and granulocyte/monocyte-producing progenitor cells with a greater precision than was previously possible. Furthermore, to illustrate how this technique can be used to study blood disorders, we demonstrated that mutations affecting the transcription factor Runx1 impair the abilities of different progenitors to produce mature blood cells in different ways.
generated_summary: In recent years, highly detailed characterization of adult bone marrow (BM) myeloid progenitors has been achieved, as a result, the impact of somatic defects on different hematopoietic lineage fate decisions has been precisely determined. Fetal liver (FL) and hepatocellular progenitor cells (HPCs) have been poorly characterized in comparison, potentially hindering the study of the impact on genetic alterations in midgestation hematoiesis. In this study, we used a dual-triggered mouse model to identify the expression of Runx1-P1-GFP and P2-hCD4 in FL. We found that expression of both genes correlated with expression of endogenous cell surface markers, including CD31 and CD45, providing a new strategy for prospective identification of highly purified fetal HPCs in transgenic mouse models.

plain language summary: Cholera is a potentially deadly diarrheal disease caused by toxin-secreting strains of Vibrio cholerae. The bacterium can trigger severe epidemics in countries with limited access to potable water and sanitation. Hygiene promotion, proper sanitation and improved access to safe drinking water are essential to control cholera. However, very few reports have described and evaluated the implementation of such activities in the field. Since October 2010, Haiti has been affected by one of the most severe cholera epidemics of the past few decades. In this report, we describe and evaluate the implementation of the original nationwide case-area targeted interventions (CATIs) response strategy, which was launched in July 2013 after years of insufficient response coordination and diminishing efforts to control cholera outbreaks in affected communities. Rapid implementation of education sessions, household decontamination, soap distribution and water chlorination in affected communities proved challenging but possible, even in a mountainous and decentralized country such as Haiti with tens of thousands of suspected cholera cases per year. Evaluation of the impact of the CATI-based strategy on the cholera epidemic is underway. Together with other components of a multi-sectoral approach, this rapid response strategy appears to be critical to eventually eliminate cholera in Haiti.
generated_summary: Cholera is a major public health problem in Haiti. In October 2010, Haiti was hit by a large-scale cholera epidemic. The Haitian government, UNICEF and international partners launched an unprecedented nationwide alert-response strategy in July 2013. Coordinated NGOs recruited local rapid response mobile teams to conduct case-area targeted interventions ( CATIs) including education sessions, household decontamination, chlorine spraying, and distribution of chlorine tablets. An innovative red-orange-green alert system was established to monitor the epidemic on a communal scale on a weekly basis. This study aimed to describe the exhaustiveness, intensity, and quality of CATIs in response to chola alerts in Haiti between July 2013 and June 2017. We analyzed the response of 7,856 weekly cholero alerts based on routine surveillance data and severity criteria, based on details of 31,306 notified CATIs. We found that CATI responses carried significantly higher exhaustiveness (aOR, 1.43 [1.38–1.48] per semester) and intensity quality (aIR, 1.,23 [1.,2.2-1.25]) compared to orange alerts. Significantly more complete CATIs carried response to red alerts compared with orange alerts (adjusted incidence ratio (AIR) and 1.85 (1.73–1.,99) per semester. Our results suggest that the implementation of a nationwide case-as-a-targeted rapid response strategy to control Cholera in Haiti is feasible albeit with certain obstacles.

plain language summary: Antiretroviral therapy (ART) does not eradicate HIV-1 in infected individuals due to virus persistence in latently infected reservoir cells, despite apparently effective ART. The persistent virus and can rekindle infection when ART is interrupted. The goal of the “shock and kill” viral clearance strategy is to induce expression of latent proviruses and eliminate the infected cells through viral cytolysis or immune clearance mechanisms. Latency reversing agents (LRAs) tested to date have been reported to have variable effects, both on virus reactivation and on immune functions. We performed in vivo reactivation experiments in SIV-infected RMs that controlled viral replication after a period of ART to evaluate the ability of the histone deacetylase inhibitor romidepsin (RMD) to reactivate SIV and its impact on SIV-specific immune responses. Our results suggest that RMD treatment can increase virus expression in this setting, and that it does not markedly or durably impair the ability of SIV-specific T cells to control viral replication.
generated_summary: Viruses persist despite seemingly effective antiretroviral treatment (ART) to reinitiate infection. However, ART has been stopped to preclude definitive treatment of HIV-1 infected individuals, requiring lifelong ART. Several strategies have been proposed targeting viral reservoirs, including the “shock kill” strategy, which induces the expression of latent proviruses (e.g., histone deacetylase inhibitors (HDACis), resulting in elimination of affected cells and viral cytolysis and immune clearance mechanisms. In this study, we developed a nonhuman primate model of post-treatment control of SIV early after prolonged administration of ART. We evaluated the ability of HDACi romidepsin (RMD) to reactivate SIV and its impact on RMD treatment and SIV-specific T cell responses. RMD was administered to IV-infected SIVsmmFTq, a transmitted-founder infectious molecular clone of the virus, starting 65 days post-infection. We found that the virus rebound was robustly controlled by <10 SIV RNA copies/mL of ART, and viral blips were controlled by CD8+ T cell recovery. These results suggest that RMD may be able to respond to RMD in an in vivo setting post-ART viral control.

plain language summary: The differentiation process has classically been seen as a stereotyped program leading from one progenitor toward a functional cell. This vision was based upon cell population-based analyses averaged over millions of cells. However, new methods have recently emerged that allow interrogation of the molecular content at the single-cell level, challenging this view with a new model suggesting that cell-to-cell gene expression stochasticity could play a key role in differentiation. We took advantage of a physiologically relevant avian cellular model to analyze the expression level of 92 genes in individual cells collected at several time-points during differentiation. We first observed that the process analyzed at the single-cell level is very different and much less well ordered than the population-based average view. Furthermore, we showed that cell-to-cell variability in gene expression peaks transiently before strongly decreasing. This rise in variability precedes two key events: an irreversible commitment to differentiation, followed by a significant increase in cell size variability. Altogether, our results support the idea that differentiation is not a “simple” series of well-ordered molecular events executed identically by all cells in a population but likely results from dynamical behavior of the underlying molecular network.
generated_summary: In recent studies, a view emerged that the stochastic dynamics governing switching cells from one state to another are characterized by peak gene expression variability at the point of fate commitment. We tested this hypothesis at the single-cell level by analyzing the primary chicken erythroid progenitors differentiation process by measuring expression of selected genes at sequential time-points during induction of differentiation. We found that single-cells gene expression data revealed high cell-to-cell variability, masked by averaging. We were able to identify a small group of functionally related genes encoding proteins involved in sterol synthesis, which act as initial drivers of differentiation, and to measure heterogeneity. In order to assess quantitatively the level of gene expression evolution over time, we used Shannon entropy to measure the heterogeneity. We observed that the previous point of maximum entropy precedes the paramount key points: irreversible commitment to differentiation from 24 to 48 h followed by a significant increase in cell size variability at 48 h. Our results indicate that the differentiation process looks different from the classical population average view. These observations are fully compatible with the idea that differentiation is a “simple” program that cells execute identically with the dynamical behavior underlying the molecular network.

plain language summary: Salmonella enterica serovar Typhimurium is a foodborne pathogen that causes gastroenteritis in humans. To successfully trigger infection, S. Typhimurium invades epithelial cells, a process that requires the coordinated expression of a set of genes. HilD is a pivotal regulator of S. Typhimurium pathogenicity, as it activates the expression of the genes required for invasion of intestinal epithelium. Expression and activity of HilD are tightly regulated and respond to several environmental and physiological conditions. In this report, we introduce the transcription elongation as a novel level of regulation of hilD. We describe that the Gre factors, proteins that prevent backtracking of paused RNA polymerase complexes during transcription elongation, are required for the expression of HilD and the subsequent expression of genes involved in the invasion of epithelial cells.
generated_summary: The invasion of epithelial cells by Salmonella enterica serovar Typhimurium is a tightly regulated process. Signaling cascades triggered by different environmental and physiological signals converge to control the expression of virulence factors. The expression of hilD is modulated by steps of the expression process. Here, we report that invasion of the epithelial cell by S. Typhimura strains lacking Gre factors, GreA and GreB, is impaired. We show that Gre factors prevent backtracking of the RNA polymerase, which is required for the initiation of the transcription initiation process. We also show that the 3’-untranslated region (UTR) of hILD is required to regulate the expression and expression of the virulence factor. Our data provide a new insight into the complex regulation of S. typhimura virulence and highlight the role of the 2’UTR as a regulatory motif.

plain language summary: Microorganisms play a crucial role in nutrient biogeochemical cycles. Arsenic is found throughout the environment from both natural and anthropogenic sources. Its inorganic forms are highly toxic and impair the physiology of most higher organisms. Arsenic contamination of groundwater supplies is giving rise to increasingly severe human health problems in both developing and industrial countries. In the present work, we investigated the metabolism of this metalloid in Herminiimonas arsenicoxydans, a representative organism of a novel bacterial genus widespread in aquatic environments. Examination of the genome sequence and experimental evidence revealed that it is remarkably capable of coping with arsenic. Our observations support the existence of multiple strategies allowing arsenic-metabolizing microbes to efficiently colonize toxic environments. In particular, arsenic oxidation and scavenging may have played a crucial role in the development of early stages of life on Earth. Such mechanisms may one day be exploited as part of a potential bioremediation strategy in toxic environments.
generated_summary: Arsenic is one of the most toxic substances in the world, and is a major public health problem in developing and industrial countries. Finding means of preserving natural environments—including ground surface waters—from arsenic constitutes a major challenge facing modern society. While arsenic is ubiquitous on the Earth, far from a bacterium thriving in arsenic-contaminated environments is fully characterized. In this in-depth exploration of the genome of β-proteobacterium Herminiimonas arsenicoxydans, we revealed that the bacterium possesses heretofore unsuspected mechanisms of coping with arsenic. Aside from multiple biochemical processes of arsenic oxidation, reduction, efflux, and chemotaxis, H. arsenicoxidans exhibits positive chemotactic motility and is able to efficiently colonize arsenic-rich environments, extending oxidoreduction reactions. Our results demonstrate that the microbial mechanism of detoxification, possibly exploitable for bioremediation applications at contaminated sites, played a crucial role in the occupation of ancient ecological niches on the earth.

plain language summary: Dietary guidelines promote intakes of polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs) for cardiometabolic health, whereas evidence on PUFAs for pregnant women is scarce.Experimental and observational studies have linked both dietary and circulating fatty acids to the risk of developing type 2 diabetes, insulin resistance, and β-cell dysfunction, but only a few studies did for the risk of developing gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM).In particular, evidence is missing for the associations of individual plasma phospholipid PUFAs, rather than total PUFAs conventionally via dietary assessment, with the risk of subsequent GDM.In this longitudinal study of 107 women with GDM and 214 matched non-GDM women within the prospective National Institute of Child Health and Human Development (NICHD) Fetal Growth Studies–Singleton Cohort in the United States, we evaluated the associations of individual plasma phospholipid PUFAs in early to midpregnancy with a panel of glucose metabolism and cardiometabolic markers and subsequent risk of GDM.Total and individual plasma phospholipid n-3 PUFAs—specifically, diet-derived eicosapentaenoic acid and docosahexaenoic acid—were inversely correlated with insulin-resistance markers but not associated with the risk of GDM.Associations of individual plasma phospholipid n-6 PUFAs with GDM risk were differential, with no associations for the major diet-derived n-6 PUFAs (linolenic acid and arachidonic acid) comprising over 80% of total n-6 PUFAs and with null, positive, or negative associations for minor n-6 PUFAs recognized to be primarily produced from endogenous metabolism of linolenic acid.No significant associations of major diet-derived n-6 PUFAs and significant findings for the other minor n-6 PUFAs known to reflect endogenous metabolism suggest a potential role of circulating levels of plasma phospholipid n-6 PUFAs in pathophysiology of GDM.Furthermore, our findings do not provide strong evidence to suggest beneficial roles of primarily diet-derived n-3 PUFAs in prevention of GDM, although also not excluding the possibility of benefit on glucose–insulin homeostasis given their inverse correlations with insulin-resistance markers. Similarly, our findings suggest neither a harmful nor a beneficial role of diet-derived n-6 PUFA linolenic acid in GDM pathophysiology.Our findings among pregnant women highlight the need to recognize the heterogeneous associations of individual circulating PUFAs with subsequent GDM risk and to investigate the underlying metabolism.
generated_summary: Pregnant women are at increased risk of developing diabetes mellitus (GDM) in the first trimester of pregnancy. Although dietary recommendations for polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs) for cardiometabolic health, the interplay between PUFAs and diabetes risk remain poorly understood. Importantly, data from pregnant women are scarce. Here, we investigated the association between individual plasma phospholipid n-3 and n-6 polyFAs levels in early midpregnancy and the subsequent risk of gestational diabetes and mellitus in pregnancy. We found that individual levels of individual PUFs were significantly associated with the risk of GDM, and that individual concentrations of individual n-4 and n-(6) PUFA were positively correlated with insulin-resistance markers. Our findings highlight the importance of assessing individual circulating PUFs in the gestational window in relation to risk of diabetes and GDM.

plain language summary: During HIV infection, a small proportion of infected cells containing integrated proviral DNA enter a long-lived resting phase, thus creating latent reservoirs of virus. These reservoirs are a major barrier to curing HIV and have been studied intensively in this light. Latent reservoirs might also affect viral dynamics during untreated infection, because they provide an archive of old viral variants that can re-enter circulation at a later time upon activation of latently infected cells. We developed a mathematical model to investigate how reservoir dynamics affect the evolution of the virus within single hosts, and find that the presence of a latent reservoir can severely delay within-host evolutionary dynamics. This delay increases with the relative size of the reservoir and the rate at which latently infected cells proliferate. By nesting this within-host model into an epidemiological model of host population dynamics, we show that the presence of latent reservoirs can also influence the population-level evolution of the virus. In contrast to predictions made by previous models we find that population-level adaptation to maximise transmission between hosts, rather than within-host fitness, can occur, but only if adaptation of the virus within hosts is sufficiently slowed down by the presence of latent reservoirs.
generated_summary: The existence of long-lived reservoirs of latently infected CD4+ T cells is a major barrier to curing HIV, and has been extensively studied in light of light. However, the effect of reservoirs on the evolutionary dynamics of virus has received little attention. Here, we present a present-host quasispecies model that incorporates a long-term reservoir, nest of an epidemiological model of HIV dynamics. We find that the presence of a latent reservoir severely delays evolutionary dynamics in a single host, with longer delays associated with larger relative reservoir sizes and/or homeostatic proliferation of cells in the reservoir. These delays fundamentally change the dynamics of the virus at a virus epidemiological scale. In particular, we show that the delay-in-host evolutionary dynamics is sufficient for the virus to evolve intermediate viral loads consistent with maximising transmission, and that enhanced viruses similar to those that initiate infection preferentially are transmitted. These results depend on strongly-host characteristics relative to reservoir size, and the evolution of intermediate virus loads observed in-host dynamics is sufficiently delayed.

abstract: 200 million people , 600 million risk contracting , schistosomiasis , major neglected tropical diseases . plain language summary: Schistosomes are parasitic worms that infect hundreds of millions of people in developing countries. They cause disease by virtue of the fact that the eggs that they produce, which are intended for release from the host in order to allow transmission of infection, can become trapped in target organs such as the liver, where they induce damaging inflammation. Egg production by female schistosomes is critically dependent on the presence of male parasites, without which females never fully develop, and (counterintuitively) on the contribution of signals from the host's immune system. Very little is understood about the molecular basis of these interactions. Here, we describe a newly discovered schistosome gene, which is expressed in the reproductive tract of the female parasite and in parasite eggs. The protein encoded by this gene is made only when females are paired with males in an immunologically competent setting. Using recently developed tools that allow gene function to be inhibited in schistosomes, we show that the product of this gene plays a crucial role in egg development. Examining how the expression of this gene is controlled has the potential to provide insight into the molecular nature of the interactions between male and female parasites and their hosts. Moreover, the pivotal role of this gene in the egg makes it a potential target for blocking transmission and disease development.
generated_summary: Schistosomiasis is a neglected tropical disease caused by helminth parasites in the genus Schistosoma. The parasite eggs are released from the human host, but they fail to reach the external environment, instead trapped in host tissues and pathological changes caused by immune responses and secreted egg antigens precipitate the disease. Despite the central importance of egg production in transmission of disease, relatively little is known about the molecular processes underlying the development of the key life stage of schistosomes. Here, we describe a novel parasite-encoded TGF-β superfamily member, Schisto mansoni Inhibin/Activin (SmInAct), as a key process in the development and production of the parasite eggs. We show that SmInAct expression is abundantly expressed in the reproductive tissues of the adult female, and that the production of eggs aborts development. Based on real-time RT-PCR analyses, we demonstrate that the transcription of SmInact continues, albeit at a reduced level, in adult worms isolated from single-sex infections, reproduction is absent, and parasites with IL-7R−/− mice, viable egg production is severely compromised. Our results provide new insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying the embryogenesis and development of this important neglected human disease.

Genetic analysis outer core temperature - sensitive mutant demonstrated core functions primarily cytokinesis . inhibition ts - TgSfi1 function high temperature caused loss outer cores severe block budding , time inner core amplified unique spindle pole , indicating inner core spindle pole independent co - regulated . discovery novel bipartite organization parasite centrosome segregates functions karyokinesis cytokinesis provides explanation cell cycle flexibility achieved apicomplexan life cycles .
plain language summary: Apicomplexan parasites infect many different hosts and tissues, causing numerous human diseases, including malaria. These important pathogens have a peculiar cell cycle in which chromosomes sometimes amplify to remarkable levels, followed by concerted cell division—providing an unusual proliferative capacity. This capacity for proliferation, combined with an ability to change the scale of replication when needed, are hallmarks of the cell cycles of these parasites. Yet the molecular mechanism responsible for these peculiar cell cycles remains one of the unsolved mysteries of Apicomplexa biology. Here we show that the centrosome—an organelle that orchestrates several aspects of the cell cycle—of the apicomplexan parasite Toxoplasma gondii contains specialized structures that coordinate parasite cell division. Our findings demonstrate that a two-part centrosomal architecture, comprising an inner and an outer core with distinct protein compositions, segregates the processes of mitosis from the assembly of new daughter parasites. The modular organization of the centrosome offers an explanation for how cell division can be suspended while the parasites amplify their genome to the biotic scale required for their life cycles. It is unknown whether these distinct centrosome core complexes evolved independently in Apicompexa. Another possibility is that the foundations for these mechanisms were present in the original eukaryote, which could explain how the distinct extranuclear centrosome of animal cells and the novel yeast spindle pole body of the nuclear envelope may have evolved from a common ancestor.
generated_summary: Apicomplexan parasites change fundamental features of their cell division and life cycles by suspending cytokinesis, which is needed for changing the proliferative scale of different hosts. The structural molecular basis of this remarkable cell cycle flexibility is not fully understood, but the centrosome serves a key role in determining how replication can occur. Here we describe the discovery of multiple replicating core complexes with distinct protein composition and function in the centroome of Toxoplasma gondii. The outer core complex of the distal nucleus contains a TgCentrin1/TgSfi1 protein pair, cartwheel protein TgSas-6, and a novel Aurora-related kinase. The inner core is closely aligned to the unique spindle pole (centrocone) and holds distant orthologs of the CEP250/C-Nap protein family. In addition, the outer/inner spatial relationship between centrosomes and cores is maintained during the cell cycle. In the metaphase, duplicated cores align opposite sides of the kinetochores in a linear array, ensuring that the daughter parasite inherits the copy type of the core. The discovery of a novel bipartite organization of the parasite centrosom segregates the functions of karyokinesis and cytokineis and provides an explanation for cell cycle versatility achieved by apicomplexans life cycles.

Additional ChIP - Seq analysis showed BldM Group II genes direct targets WhiI vivo binding WhiI promoters depended BldM vice versa . demonstrate BldM WhiI form functional heterodimer controls Group II promoters , serving integrate signals distinct developmental pathways . BldM - WhiI system exemplifies potential response regulator heterodimer formation mechanism expand signaling capabilities bacterial cells .
plain language summary: Two-component signal transduction systems are a primary means of regulating gene expression in bacteria. Recognizing the diversity of mechanisms associated with these systems is therefore critical to understanding the full signaling potential of bacterial cells. We have analyzed the behavior of two orphan, atypical response regulators that play key roles in controlling morphological differentiation in the filamentous bacteria Streptomyces-BldM and WhiI. We demonstrate that BldM activates its Group I target promoters as a homodimer, but that it subsequently activates its Group II target promoters by forming a functional heterodimer with WhiI. BldM-WhiI heterodimer formation thus represents an unusual mechanism for the coactivation of target genes and the integration of regulatory signals at promoters, enhancing the known repertoire of signaling capabilities associated with two-component systems.
generated_summary: Streptomyces cerevisiae is the most important bacterium in the world. It is important to understand the mechanisms by which this bacterium functions. In this study, we have defined the BldM-WhiI system as a functional heterodimer that controls the expression of Group II and Group II genes. We show that Group II gene expression depends on bldM and WhiI, and that Bldm is required for the formation of aerial hyphae and for the differentiation of reproductive structures in mature spores. We also show that the two genes are dependent on each other for their expression. We further show that this system is able to control both the expression and expression of the Group I genes.

plain language summary: Yellow fever is becoming one of the most important re-emerging mosquito-borne viral diseases in many African countries despite the availability of an effective vaccine. Hence, assessing information on what a community knows about Yellow fever would contribute to the design of appropriate control strategies in addition to increasing access for vaccine. In this study, we assessed knowledge, attitudes and practices of local community about Yellow fever in South Omo area, southern Ethiopia, where outbreaks have occurred repeatedly since the 1960s. We found that the study community members had low knowledge about the cause and mode of transmission of the disease though they knew that it is a killer and affects all age groups. More than half of the study participants believed that the disease can be transmitted from a patient to another person through breathing. In the present study area, providing information to community members through community health extension workers regarding the role of mosquitoes in the transmission of this disease, and teaching what to do to minimize mosquitoes bite in understandable way would be helpful to increase their awareness about Yellow fever.
generated_summary: Yellow fever (Yf) is a mosquito-borne disease caused by the bite of a mosquito. Yf has been reported in South Omo in Southern Ethiopia since the 1960s. However, reliable information about the level of community knowledge and attitudes about the disease in the area is not available. In this study, we conducted a community-based cross-sectional survey of 612 randomly selected adults interviewed about Yf. Of the 612 study participants, 508 (83.0%) reported having heard of Yf locally known as “the disease causes vomiting and blood”. Ninety-eight (90.4%) of study participants said Yf is different from malaria and thirteen (41.9%) of participants said that Yf was transmitted to a patient person, 80 (37.6%) mentioned disease transmitted to mosquitoes by bite, and 333 (65.7%) study participants believed Yf to be a preventable disease, 280 (84.1%) mentioned a vaccine as a preventive method. The majority believed the disease killer (97.2%) was newly emerging and 69.4% were newly emerging. Our findings indicate that community members have a low level of overall knowledge about the Yf, especially the cause, mode of transmission and preventive methods.

Adoptive transfer immune sera CD4 + T cells provided partial protection YFV , complete protection achieved transfer immune sera CD4 + T cells . , robust CD4 + T cell activity critical contributor protective immunity elicited highly effective live attenuated vaccines .
plain language summary: The 17D line yellow fever virus (YFV) vaccines are some of the safest and most effective live-attenuated virus vaccines ever produced, protecting recipients for life against deadly yellow fever (YF). As a testament to this safety and efficacy, the 17D line of live-attenuated vaccines has become an important model for the design of future vaccines. However, we still lack a fundamental understanding of the protective immunity elicited against the virulent YFV, a knowledge gap that must be overcome to inform the design of future live-attenuated and subunit vaccines. Humans develop robust antibody and T cell responses following vaccination, leading some to suggest that vaccine-elicited CD8+ T cells are important for protection against virulent YFV. Since this can never be tested in humans, we have used mice to model immunity to the 17D-204 vaccine strain. We found that CD4+ T cells elicited by 17D-204 contributed to protection against virulent YFV, but CD8+ T cells had no effect on the outcomes of survival or disease. Our study is the first to demonstrate that vaccine-elicited CD4+ T cells can protect against YFV infection. These results suggest that vaccine developers should consider the importance of CD4+ T cells when designing vaccines against viruses similar to YFV.
generated_summary: Yellow fever virus (YFV) is one of the most prevalent infectious diseases in the world. It is transmitted by live-attenuated 17D-based yellow fever virus vaccine (VVV) that has been shown to be safe and effective against YFV infection. However, the efficacy of VVV vaccines has not been fully evaluated. Here, we address the question of whether the immune mechanisms that underlie the protective immunity elicited by live attenuated VV vaccines elicited a long-term protection challenge, characterized by high neutralizing antibody titers and a robust T cell response formed by long-lived memory. We show that CD4+ and CD8+ T cells are polyfunctional and cytolytic. Adoptive transfer of immune sera to CD4 + T cells provided partial protection against VV, and complete protection was achieved by transfer of the immun sera from CD4 to T cells. These findings suggest that robust CD4-T cell activity is a critical contributor to protective immunity that elicited highly effective VV vaccine.

plain language summary: Human neurocysticercosis is an infection of the central nervous system caused by the larval stage of the pork tapeworm (Taenia solium). The infection occurs mainly in developing countries and is associated with poverty, poor sanitation and free-range pig management. It is estimated to be responsible for 30% of cases of acquired epilepsy in endemic areas. The limited number of human studies on this infection in Sub-Saharan Africa determined a high occurrence of cysticercosis. This study aimed to learn more about the transmission dynamics of this parasite in a rural endemic area in Eastern Zambia. A longitudinal study was carried out in which 867 participants were blood sampled three times, with a 6-month interval. Samples were analysed for the presence of cysticercal circulating antigens and specific antibodies. Results indicate that about 1 on 3 people get exposed to infection while only 1 on 10 people actually acquire infection. The study shows the dynamic nature of T. solium infections; many of the people at risk become (re)infected due to the high environmental contamination, with a high number turning seronegative within a year after infection. An important number of infections probably never fully establish, leading to short-term antibody and antigen presence.
generated_summary: Cysticercosis is a parasitic disease caused by the protozoan parasite T. solium. It is transmitted to humans by the bite of an infected mosquito. The parasite is transmitted by a single bite of a mosquito, which can cause infection in humans. In this study, we tested the presence of cysticercus antigens using a monoclonal antibody-based enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (sero-Ag-ELISA). A randomly selected sub-sample of 161 samples from the sampling round tested for specific antibodies using a commercial enzyme-based immunoelectrotransfer blot (EITB) assay. Stool samples (n  =  226) were collected for the final round of sampling for taeniosis diagnosis and coproantigen ELISA. Cysticerciasis seroprevalence varied from 12.2% to 14.5% (Sero-A) to 33.5%. Seroreversion rates were 44% and 38.7% in the recorded period. In conclusion, this study has shown the dynamic nature of the parasite in Zambia; people are at risk of re-infected with high environmental contamination, high number of turning seronegative year after infection. This important number of infections probably fully establish, leading to transient antibody responses to short-term antigen presence.

Furthermore , shape association modified rate pathogen evolution , faster pathogen mutation rates selecting increased host MHC copy number , pathogen richness low moderate . , taking account factors pathogen richness help explain wide variation vertebrate species number MHC genes . population , variation number unique MHC variants carried individuals ( INV ) observed parameter combinations , low pathogen richness . variance gave rise positive correlations INV host immunocompetence ( proportion pathogens recognised ) . , - population variation host immunocompetence declined pathogen richness . , counterintuitively , pathogens contribute genetic variance host fitness species exposed fewer pathogen species , consequences predictions “ Hamilton - Zuk ” theory sexual selection .
plain language summary: Highly polymorphic genes of the Major Histocompatibility Complex (MHC) code for proteins responsible for presenting antigens to lymphocytes, thus initiating adaptive immune response. The polymorphism is driven by coevolution with parasites which are selected to evade recognition by MHC proteins. Expressing many MHC molecules could ensure that an individual could present antigens of most pathogen species encountered, but this comes at a cost, such as enhanced negative selection on lymphocytes leading to holes in T-cell receptor repertoire. Our simulations showed that evolution of the number of MHC genes in the genome is driven by a complex interaction between three factors we explored: pathogen richness, the intrinsic cost of expressing additional MHC variants, and pathogen mutation rate. In contrast to verbal arguments, our results indicate that pathogen richness does not always selects for MHC gene family expansion. Taking into account factors other than pathogen richness, in particular costs of expressing additional MHC variants which are still poorly understood, may help explain striking interspecific variation in the number of MHC genes. Counterintuitively, our results also demonstrated that opportunity for selection on immunocompetence should decrease with MHC gene family expansion.
generated_summary: MHC genes, code proteins responsible for presenting pathogen-derived antigens to the host immune system, have remarkable copy-number variation across species. However, the evolutionary forces driving variation are poorly understood. Here, we use computer simulations to investigate the evolution of the number of MHC variants in the genome shaped by number of pathogen species that a host population encounters (pathogen richness). We found that the proportion of pathogens recognised by the host is low, and pathogen richness was high. Furthermore, we found that pathogen mutation rates were faster and faster than mutation rates when selecting an increased host MHC copy number, while pathogen diversity was low. These results suggest that the evolutionary mechanisms driving variation in vertebrate species are not well understood.

abstract: recently developed analysis methods ( GREML ) estimate genetic variance complex trait / disease genetic correlation complex traits / diseases genome - wide single nucleotide polymorphism ( SNP ) data unrelated individuals . use analytical derivations simulations quantify sampling variance estimate proportion phenotypic variance captured SNPs quantitative traits case - control studies . derive approximate sampling variance estimate genetic correlation bivariate analysis , complex traits measured different individuals . sampling variance inversely proportional number pairwise contrasts analysis variance SNP - derived genetic relationships . bivariate analysis , sampling variance genetic correlation additionally depends harmonic mean proportion variance explained SNPs traits genetic correlation traits , depends phenotypic correlation traits measured individuals . provide online tool calculating power detecting genetic ( co)variation genome - wide SNP data . new theory online tool helpful plan experimental designs estimate missing heritability fully revealed genome - wide association studies , estimate genetic overlap complex traits ( diseases ) particular traits ( diseases ) measured samples .
plain language summary: Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have identified thousands of genetic variants for hundreds of traits and diseases. However, the genetic variants discovered from GWAS only explained a small fraction of the heritability, resulting in the question of “missing heritability”. We have recently developed approaches (called GREML) to estimate the overall contribution of all SNPs to the phenotypic variance of a trait (disease) and the proportion of genetic overlap between traits (diseases). A frequently asked question is that how many samples are required to estimate the proportion of variance attributable to all SNPs and the proportion of genetic overlap with useful precision. In this study, we derive the standard errors of the estimated parameters from theory and find that they are highly consistent with those observed values from published results and those obtained from simulation. The theory together with an online application tool will be helpful to plan experimental design to quantify the missing heritability, and to estimate the genetic overlap between traits (diseases) especially when it is unfeasible to have the traits (diseases) measured on the same individuals.
generated_summary: Genome-wide single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) data have been used to estimate the genetic variance of complex traits/diseases measured in unrelated individuals. However, the proportion of phenotypic variance captured in SNPs and quantitative traits in case-control studies has not been fully revealed. We derive an approximate sampling variance estimate of genetic correlation using bivariate analysis, which is inversely proportional to the number of pairwise contrasts between analysis of variance and SNP-derived genetic relationships. We provide an online tool for calculating the power of detecting genetic (co)variation in genome-wide SNP data. This new theory is helpful to plan experimental designs to estimate missing heritability fully revealed in genome wide association studies, estimate genetic overlap between complex traits (disease) and particular traits (degenerative diseases) measured in samples.

abstract: Cellular receptors act molecular switches , regulating sensitivity microbial proteins conformational changes promote cellular entry . activities receptor - based switches partially understood . paper , sought understand mechanism underlies activity ANTXR2 anthrax toxin receptor - based switch binds domains 2 4 protective antigen ( PA ) toxin subunit . Receptor - binding restricts structural changes heptameric PA prepore required pore conversion acidic endosomal compartment . transfer cross - saturation ( TCS ) NMR approach monitor changes heptameric PA - receptor contacts different steps prepore - - pore conversion . studies demonstrated receptor contact PA domain 2 weakened prior pore conversion , defining novel intermediate pathway . Importantly , ANTXR2 remained bound PA domain 4 following pore conversion , suggesting bound receptor influence structure and/or function newly formed pore . studies provide new insights function receptor - based molecular switch controls anthrax toxin entry cells .
plain language summary: The bacterium that causes anthrax produces a toxin called anthrax toxin that is largely responsible for causing disease symptoms. The first step in anthrax intoxication involves binding of the toxin to a specific protein, called a receptor, on the cell surface. Receptor-binding acts like a switch to prevent the toxin from forming a pore in a cell membrane until the toxin-receptor complex is taken up into cells and delivered to a specific location (called an endosome) where it is exposed to an “acid bath”. This acidic environment promotes structural changes in the toxin leading to pore formation in the endosomal membrane. In this report, we have studied how the receptor regulates pore formation by following the associated changes in toxin-receptor contacts. These studies have defined a new toxin-receptor intermediate in the pathway leading to pore conversion and demonstrate that the receptor remains bound after pore conversion. Our results provide important new insights into how the receptor regulates anthrax toxin pore formation, information that could be useful for designing new therapeutic strategies to treat this disease.
generated_summary: Cellular receptors act as molecular switches, regulating the sensitivity of microbial proteins to conformational changes that promote cellular entry. However, the activities of receptor-based switches are not fully understood. In this paper, we sought to understand the mechanism underlies the activity of ANTXR2, an anthrax toxin receptor that binds to domains 2 and 4 of the protective antigen (PA) toxin subunit. Receptor-binding restricts structural changes in the heptameric PA prepore required for pore conversion to the acidic endosomal compartment. We used a transfer cross- saturation (TCS) NMR approach to monitor changes in heptamic PA-receptor contacts during different steps of prepore-to-pore conversion. Our studies demonstrated that receptor contact with PA domain 2 weakened prior to pore transformation, defining a novel intermediate pathway. Importantly, we found that the receptor-binding domain 4 remained bound to PA domain 4 following pore-conversion, suggesting that the bound receptor influence the structure and/or function of the newly formed pore. These studies provide new insights into the function of a receptor-mediated molecular switch that controls anthrax toxins entry into cells.
