plain language summary: The memory component of acquired immune responses selects for distinctive patterns of polymorphism in genes encoding important target antigens of pathogens. These are detectable by surveying for evidence of balancing selection, as previously illustrated in analyses of genes encoding malaria parasite antigens that are candidate targets of naturally acquired immunity. For a comprehensive screen to discover targets of immunity in the major human malaria parasite Plasmodium falciparum, an endemic population in West Africa was sampled and genome sequence data obtained from 65 clinical isolates, allowing analysis of polymorphism in almost all protein-coding genes. Antigen genes previously studied by capillary re-sequencing in independent population samples had highly concordant indices in the genome-wide analysis here, and this has identified other genes with stronger evidence of balancing selection, now prioritized for functional study and potential vaccine candidacy. The statistical signatures consistent with such selection were particularly common in genes with peak expression at the stage that invades erythrocytes, and members of several gene families were represented. The strongest signature was in the msp3-like gene PF10_0355, so we studied the transcript and protein product in parasites, revealing an unexpected pattern of phase variable expression. Variation in expression of polymorphic antigens under balancing selection may be more common than previously thought, requiring further study to assess vaccine candidacy.
generated_summary: Plasmodium falciparum is the causative agent of malaria in the Gambian population. The parasite is transmitted to humans by the bite of an infected mosquito, which causes severe disease in humans and other vertebrates. In this study, we generated paired-end short-read sequences of parasites from clinical isolates from the endemic Gambian malaria population, and mapped them to a 3D7 strain reference genome to yield high-quality genome-wide coding sequence data from 65 isolates. We found that the majority of the genes map reliably, including hypervariable var, rifin, stevor families, 5,056 genes (90.9% of genome) > 70% sequence coverage and minimum read depth in 5 50 isolates, and 2,853 genes contained 3 single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) and analysis of polymorphic site frequency spectra. The overall background of negatively skewed frequencies was expected to be due to historical population expansion combined with purifying selection, outlying minority genes signatures indicating exceptionally intermediate frequencies were identified. Comparing genes with different stage-specific, signatures of the common peak expression of the merozoite stage invades erythrocytes were highly represented, with the strongest signature being the msp3-like gene PF10_0355. Our results suggest that the target of balancing selection is prioritized for a functional study.

plain language summary: Proteins are made up of well-packed structural units referred to as domains. Domain structure in proteins is responsible for protein function and is evolutionarily conserved. Here we report global patterns of protein domain gain and loss in the three superkingdoms of life. We reconstructed phylogenetic trees using domain fold families as phylogenetic characters and retraced the history of character changes along the many branches of the tree of life. Results revealed that both domain gains and losses were frequent events in the evolution of cells. However, domain gains generally overshadowed the number of losses. This trend was consistent in the three superkingdoms. However, the rate of domain discovery was highest in akaryotic microbes. Domain gains occurred throughout the evolutionary timeline albeit at a non-uniform rate. Our study sheds light into the evolutionary history of living organisms and highlights important ongoing mechanisms that are responsible for secondary evolutionary adaptations in the three superkingdoms of life.
generated_summary: Proteomes are modules of proteins that fold and function independently and are evolutionarily conserved. We compared the usage of the distribution of protein domain families in free-living proteomes in Archaea, Bacteria and Eukarya and reconstructed species phylogenies tracing the history of domain emergence and loss during proteome evolution. We found that the rate of domain discovery increased linearly over evolutionary time. Remarkably, gains generally outnumbered losses in gain-to-loss ratios higher in akaryotes compared to eukaryotes. Functional annotations of domain families revealed that Archaea and Bacteria gained lost metabolic capabilities over the course of evolution and that Eukaryotic bacteria acquired a number of diverse molecular functions including involved in extracellular processes, immunological mechanisms, and cell regulation. Our analysis highlighted significant contemporary sharing of informational enzymes between Archaea Eukari and metabolic enzymes in Bacteria Eukray. Finally, our analysis provided useful insights into the evolution and evolution of these two species.

plain language summary: The tropical disease lymphatic filariasis (LF) causes chronic swelling of the leg—lymphedema—in 14 million people worldwide. To stop the spread of LF, a program led by the World Health Organization (WHO) offers annual preventive drug treatment to affected communities. For people who already have lymphedema, WHO recommends simple hygiene-based measures that include skin care and limb movement. Yet only a small proportion of those with LF-related lymphedema have been trained in these measures. To determine the effectiveness of hygiene-based lymphedema management, we reviewed the scientific literature. Twenty-two studies were found that 1) used hygiene-based interventions to manage lymphedema; 2) measured the effect of these interventions; and 3) were done in an area where LF occurs. Overall, use of hygiene-based measures was associated with 60% lower odds of inflammatory episodes, known as “acute attacks,” in the affected limb. Acute attacks cause severe pain, fever, and disability, and they make lymphedema worse. Hygiene and sanitation are necessary for control of many tropical diseases. Hygiene is also effective for managing LF-related lymphedema and reducing suffering caused by acute attacks. Training people with lymphedema in hygiene-based interventions should be a priority for LF programs everywhere.
generated_summary: Lymphatic filariasis (LF) is a neglected tropical disease that affects more than 14 million people worldwide. The World Health Organization Global Program to Eliminate Lymphatic Filariasis (GFP) aims to reduce LF by providing care to persons who suffer from clinical manifestations, including lymphedema —-called morbidity management and disability prevention (MMDP). Scaling MMDP is slow, and lack of consensus on the effectiveness of recommended hygiene-based interventions for clinical lymphingema. We conducted a systemic review of meta-analysis to estimate the effectiveness and effectiveness of hygiene-related interventions for LF-associated morbidity and disability in LF-endemic areas. We systematically searched PubMed, Embase, ISI Web Knowledge, MedCarib, Lilacs, REPIDISCA, DESASTRES, and African Index Medicus databases from March 23, 2015 to date. We found that there was a lower incidence of acute dermatolymphagioadenitis (ADLA), (2) a lower percentage of patients reporting episode of ADLA follow-up, and (3) clinical outcomes were assessed comparable to those of other interventions for lympedema management. These findings highlight the potential of these interventions to significantly reduce LF-related morbidity, disability, and disability.

plain language summary: In areas where P. vivax and P. falciparum parasite species co-occur, immunity to P. vivax seems to be acquired more rapidly. This difference could be caused either by generic differences in the way immunity is acquired or by a relatively higher exposure to P. vivax blood-stage infections in early life. We found that children experienced an average of 14 new P. vivax blood-stage infections per year, and that the number of new infections acquired predicted how often children fell ill with vivax malaria by genotyping all P. vivax infections that occurred in a group of 264 children 1–4 years of age followed for 16 months. The burden of blood-stage infections caused by P. vivax was therefore at least twice as high as that caused by P. falciparum. This higher force-of-blood-stage infection (molFOB) caused by P. vivax is at least partially due to the ability of P. vivax hypnozoites to relapse from long-lasting liver stages. A high exposure to P. vivax blood-stage infection resulted in more rapid decrease in the incidence of P. vivax malaria. The high number of P. vivax clones that infect children in early childhood is thus likely to contribute substantially to the rapid acquisition of immunity against clinical P. vivax malaria.
generated_summary: Plasmodium vivax is a mosquito-borne parasitic disease that affects more than 1.5 million people in Papua New Guinea. It is the most common cause of morbidity and mortality in children, and it has been reported that the incidence of P. falciparum is higher in children living in highly endemic areas of Papua New Guinean. To identify the differences in the number of blood stage infections and the potential link between acquisition of immunity, we estimated the molecular force of blood-stage infection of malaria parasites. We found that the prevalence of malaria infection in children was higher in the high-risk group compared to those with low exposure. The incidence of malaria in children with high exposure was also higher in those who had low exposure to malaria. The high incidence of clinical malaria was strongly associated with molFOB (the incidence rate ratio (IRR) = 1.99, 95% confidence interval (CI95) [1.80, 2.19], and molFOBs did not change with age. This suggests that the high number of malaria parasite clones infecting children in early childhood may contribute to rapid acquisition immunity against clinical P. vivx malaria.

plain language summary: Although multiple lines of evidence suggest that vitamin D may play a role in host susceptibility to tuberculosis (TB) disease, the impact of low vitamin D on the risk of developing TB disease has not yet been firmly established.We conducted a study in Lima, Peru, in which we measured serum 25–(OH)D levels in individuals at high risk for TB disease and followed them for development of TB over 1 year.We pooled individual-level data from seven previously published prospective studies conducted worldwide and from our Lima cohort.We found that individuals with low levels of vitamin D were at higher risk of future progression to TB disease.These findings suggest that vitamin D deficiency is a risk factor for developing TB disease.Randomized control trials are needed to determine whether vitamin D supplementation reduces risk of TB disease.
generated_summary: Tuberculosis (TB) is the leading cause of morbidity and mortality in Latin America and the Caribbean. There are currently no randomized controlled trials to evaluate the impact of vitamin D deficiency on TB disease risk. In this study, we assessed the association between baseline vitamin D status and incident TB in a prospective cohort of 6,751 HIV-negative household contacts of TB patients enrolled from September 1, 2009, August 29, 2012, in Lima, Peru. We defined cases of household contacts who developed TB disease 15 days after the enrollment index of the patient. In each case, randomly selected controls who did not develop TB disease were randomly selected for the same gender year of age. We conducted a first-stage individual-participation data (IPD) meta-analysis searching PubMed Embase to identify prospective studies assessing vitamin D risk for TB disease. The Lima cohort included 180 cases of 709 matched controls. We estimated the association of baseline vitamin d status with incident TB risk in the Lima cohort. We compared the risk of TB in the highest HIV-positive individuals with severe vitamin D deficiencies with sufficient vitamin D. Our findings suggest that vitamin D is a dose-dependent manner for TB risk. Randomized control trials are needed to evaluate a possible role for vitamin D supplementation in reducing TB disease risks.

Monod - Wyman - Changeux model , determined sensing characteristics – dynamic range , Hill number , intrinsic noise , information transfer capacity , static gain , mean response time – function biochemical parameters individual sensors number sensors . found specifying characteristic strongly constrains . example , high dynamic range implies high Hill number high capacity , vice versa . surprisingly , constraints strong space characteristics inaccessible given biophysically plausible ranges parameter values . approximations , calculate probability distribution numbers input molecules maximizes information transfer population allosteric transcription factors principle distinguish bands input concentrations . results imply allosteric sensors unlikely selected high performance sensing characteristic compromise performance .
plain language summary: Sensing environmental changes is the first step in the process of cellular decision-making, but many different biochemical sensors exist and why one sensor is selected for a particular task over another is not known. Here we study the sensing properties of a simple and generic allosteric sensor to understand the effectiveness and limitations of its “design”. We begin by defining and calculating a set of six engineering-inspired characteristics of the sensor’s response and investigate how specifying a high performance in one characteristic constrains the sensor’s performance in others. We determine many such trade-offs and, perhaps surprisingly, that much of the space of characteristics is inaccessible given biophysically plausible ranges of parameters. Our results suggest that allosteric sensors are not under selection for high performance in one sensing characteristic but for a compromise in performance between many. Our approach provides both quantitative and qualitative insights about the function and robustness of allosteric sensors and as such is applicable to both the study of endogenous systems and the design of synthetic ones.
generated_summary: Sensing extracellular changes initiates the signal transduction stage of cellular decision-making. However, relatively little is known about how sensing biochemistry is selected. To gain insight into this question, we studied sensing characteristics of the biochemically simplest sensors: the allosteric transcription factor. We determined sensing characteristics that directly transduce the detection of sensed molecule changes in gene regulation. We found that sensing characteristics – dynamic range, Hill number, intrinsic noise, information transfer capacity, static gain, mean response time, and function of biochemical parameters—are strongly constrains. For example, high dynamic range implies high Hill number and high capacity, vice versa. We also found that the constraints of strong space characteristics are inaccessible given biophysically plausible ranges of parameter values. Our approximations, calculate the probability distribution of numbers of input molecules maximizes information transfer across the population. We conclude that high sensing characteristics are unlikely to compromise performance.

Calculations GDS / FAST stages 4–6 reveal standard deviations stage durations comparable mean values , indicating presence large variations AD progression patients . heterogeneity course progression AD consistent existence sub - groups AD patients , differ patterns decline .
plain language summary: In recent decades, our understanding of Alzheimer's disease (AD) has increased; however, some basic questions still remain unresolved. One of them is: how homogeneous is AD? Is the course of progression more or less the same for most patients, or are there large variations? Our paper studies a large cohort of AD patients which comes from a 23-year-long study, and performs a statistical analysis of progression speed. We quantify the amount of spread in GDS/FAST stage durations (a staging system widely used by clinicians). We arrive at an astonishing conclusion that the mean length of AD stages is comparable with their standard deviation! This means that individual courses of AD progression may differ very much from each other, and from the textbook mean values. This has implications both for clinical trials (how do we assess if a new drug is effective, if the amount of natural spread is so large in untreated patients?), and for our understanding of this disease, which appears to be comprised of sub-diseases with different patterns of decline.
generated_summary: Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) is the most common neurodegenerative disease in the United States. The disease is caused by a combination of genetic mutations in the brain that can lead to a variety of neurological disorders, including dementia. In this study, we used a global Deterioration Scale (GDS) and Functional Assessment Staging procedure (FAST) to characterize the seven stages of AD in patients with normal aging and severe dementia. The GDS/FAST stage has published mean duration, but the variance is unknown. We use statistical analysis to reconstruct the GDS and FAST stage durations in a cohort of 648 AD patients with an average follow-up time of 4.78 years. Calculations of GDS /FAST stages 4–6 reveal standard deviations in stage and durations comparable to mean values, indicating the presence of large variations in AD progression in patients. The heterogeneity in course progression in AD is consistent with the existence of sub-groups of AD patients, which differ in patterns of decline and decline.

abstract: Long - term memories thought depend coordinated activation broad network cortical subcortical brain regions . , distributed nature representation challenging define neural elements memory trace , lesion electrophysiological approaches provide narrow window appreciated global network . global mapping approach identify networks brain regions activated following recall long - term fear memories mice . Analysis Fos expression 84 brain regions allowed identify regions co - active following memory recall . analyses revealed functional organization long - term fear memories depends memory age altered mutant mice exhibit premature forgetting . importantly , analyses indicate long - term memory recall engages network distinct thalamic - hippocampal - cortical signature . network concurrently integrated segregated small - world properties , contains hub - like regions prefrontal cortex thalamus play privileged roles memory expression .
plain language summary: Memory retrieval is thought to involve the coordinated activation of multiple regions of the brain, rather than localized activity in a specific region. In order to visualize networks of brain regions activated by recall of a fear memory in mice, we quantified expression of an activity-regulated gene (c-fos) that is induced by neural activity. This allowed us to identify collections of brain regions where Fos expression co-varies across mice, and presumably form components of a network that are co-active during recall of long-term fear memory. This analysis suggested that expression of a long-term fear memory is an emergent property of large scale neural network interactions. This network has a distinct thalamic-hippocampal-cortical signature and, like many real-world networks as well as other anatomical and functional brain networks, has small-world architecture with a subset of highly-connected hub nodes that may play more central roles in memory expression.
generated_summary: Long-term memories are thought to depend on coordinated activation of a broad network of cortical subcortical brain regions. However, the distributed nature of representation is challenging to define neural elements of memory trace, and lesion electrophysiological approaches provide a narrow window to the appreciated global network. Here, we use a global mapping approach to identify networks of brain regions activated following the recall of long-term fear memories in mice. Our analysis of Fos expression in 84 brain regions allowed us to identify regions co-active following memory recall. Our analyses revealed that the functional organization of memory recall depends on memory age and altered mutant mice exhibit premature forgetting. Furthermore, our analyses indicate that long-lasting memory recall engages a distinct thalamic- hippocampal-cortex signature. This network is concurrently integrated into segregated small-world properties, and contains hub-like regions of the prefrontal cortex and thalamus that play privileged roles in memory expression.

plain language summary: Cells respond to elevated temperatures with the rapid activation of heat shock genes to ensure cellular survival. Heat shock gene activation involves the synthesis of poly-[ADP-ribose] (PAR) at heat shock loci, the opening of chromatin structure, and the coordinated recruitment of transcription factors and chromatin regulators RNA polymerase II and components of the RNA processing machinery. The molecular roles of PAR and and ATP-dependent chromatin remodelers in heat shock gene activation are not clear. We show here that the chromatin remodeler dMi-2 is recruited to Drosophila heat shock genes in a PAR–dependent manner. We provide evidence that recruitment involves direct binding of dMi-2 to PAR polymers and identify novel PAR sensing regions in the dMi-2 protein, including the chromodomains and a series of motifs rich in K and R residues. Upon HS gene activation, dMi-2 associates with nascent transcripts. In addition, we find that dMi-2 and its catalytic activity are important for heat shock gene activation and co-transcriptional RNA processing efficiency. Our study uncovers a novel role of PAR during heat shock gene activation and establishes an unanticipated link between chromatin remodeler activity and RNA processing.
generated_summary: Eukaryotic cells respond to genomic environmental stresses, such as DNA damage from heat shock (HS), synthesis of poly-[ADP-ribose] (PAR) specific chromatin regions, DNA breaks from HS genes, and PAR polymerases (PARP) are required for efficient transcriptional response. The nucleosome remodeler dMi-2 is recruited to active HS genes in a PARP–dependent manner, suggesting that physical interaction is important for recruitment. Here, we identified several regions of the chromatin that bind PAR independently in vitro, including chromodomains and regions near the N-terminus containing motifs rich in K R residues. In addition, we found that the binding of the nascent HS gene transcripts, which are catalytic activity required for the efficient transcription of co-transcriptional RNA processing, is a step in the recruitment process. We suggest that the initial recruitment of the locus of PAR interaction, followed by binding of nascent RNA transcripts, serves to rapidly attract factors required for an efficient timely transcriptional and RNA processing.

plain language summary: Dogs are a key definitive host of Echinococcus spp; hence, accurate diagnosis in dogs is important for the surveillance and control of echinococcosis. A perfect diagnostic test would detect every infected dog (100% sensitivity) whilst never giving a false positive reaction in non-infected dogs (100% specificity). Since no such test exists, it is important to understand the performance of available diagnostic techniques. We used the results of a study that used three diagnostic tests on dogs from the Tibetan plateau, where there is co-endemicity of E. granulosus and E. multilocularis. In this study opro-antigen ELISA and copro-PCR diagnostic tests were undertaken on faecal samples from all animals. The dogs were also purged with arecoline hydrobromide to recover adult parasites as a highly specific but relatively insensitive third diagnostic test. We used a statistical approach (Bayesian latent-class models) to estimate simultaneously the sensitivities of all three tests and the specificities of the copro-antigen and copro-PCR tests. We also analysed how some determinants of infection can affect parasite prevalence. This approach provides a robust framework to increase the accuracy of surveillance and epidemiological studies of echinococcosis by overcoming the problems of poor diagnostic test performance.
generated_summary: Dino echinococcosis is a neglected tropical disease caused by the bacterium Echinococcus multilocularis, which is transmitted by the dog Taenia spp. The disease is endemic in the Tibetan plateau, where it has been reported in a largely deterministic way. In this study, we used a set of faecal purge samples to explore the epidemiology and sensitivities of canine echinocytosis in Tibetan plateau. We used a latent-class model to examine the diagnostic performance of the genus specific copro-antigen ELISA, species-specific copro and arecoline purgation. The dependence of the structure of the diagnostic tests was analysed in a parsimonious manner, which indicated deviance-of-information criteria. We suggested that co-infection with Taenias spp was a significant covariate of Echinoccus infection. The diagnostic performance was 89% and 84% respectively, respectively, for the diagnosis of E. multilibocularis and E. granulosus. The specificities of copro-, ELISA and werecoline sensitivities were 55% and 57% respectively. The diagnosis of both E.multilibularis and the E.granulososus specificities were 71 and 69%, respectively. These results show that incorporating diagnostic uncertainty, words assuming the perfect gold standard, including potential covariates like sex and Taeniae co-infection epidemiological analysis, different results and diagnosis of infection status are assumed to be the most deterministic approach possible.

Finally , bioinformatic tools compare structure DNA foci DNA domains seen replicate discrete time intervals S phase genome - wide strategies . plain language summary: Eukaryotic DNA synthesis is regulated with exquisite precision so that genomes are replicated exactly once before cell division occurs. In simple eukaryotes, chromosomal loci are preferentially replicated at specific times of S phase, in part because of their differential sensitivity to cell cycle regulators and in part as a result of random choice. Mammals, with ∼250-fold larger genomes, have more complex replication programs, within which different classes of chromatin replicate at defined times. While the basic regulatory mechanisms in higher eukaryotes are conserved, it is unclear how their much more complex timing program is maintained. We use replication precursor analogues, which can be visualized in living or fixed cells, to monitor the spatial relationship of DNA domains that are replicated at different times of S phase. Analyzing individual chromosome, we show that a major mechanism regulating transitions in the S phase timing program involves the sequential activation of replication domains based on their genetic continuity. Our analysis of the mechanism of S phase progression in single cells provides an alternative to genome-wide strategies, which define patterns of replication using cell populations. In combination, these complimentary strategies provide fundamental insight into the mechanisms of S phase timing in mammalian cells.
generated_summary: DNA synthesis is performed with extreme precision to maintain genomic integrity. In mammalian cells, different genomic regions are replicated at different times, to preserve epigenetic information and cell differentiation status. However, the molecular principles that define the S phase program remain unknown. By analyzing the replication foci of discrete chromosome territories during interphase, we demonstrate that the spatial continuity of replication and foci correlates with genetic continuity of adjacent replicon clusters on chromosomes. Finally, bioinformatic tools compare the structure of DNA foci and DNA domains seen to replicate at discrete time intervals during S phase genome-wide strategies. Our data presented a major mechanism for S phase progression, which involves sequential synthesis of regions of the genome that maintain genetic continuity and chromosomal fiber.

Surprisingly , mice lacking CB1 GABAergic neurons responded THC similarly wild - type littermates , deletion receptor principal neurons abolished strongly reduced behavioural autonomic responses drug . , locomotor hypothermic effects THC depend cortical glutamatergic neurons , deletion CB1 majority striatal neurons subpopulation cortical glutamatergic neurons blocked cataleptic effect drug . data important pharmacological actions THC depend functional expression CB1 GABAergic interneurons , neuronal populations , pave way refined interpretation pharmacological effects cannabinoids neuronal functions .
plain language summary: Marijuana and its main psychoactive component, THC, exert a plethora of behavioural and autonomic effects on humans and animals. Some of these effects are the cause of the widespread illicit use of marijuana, while others might be involved in the potential therapeutic use of this drug for the treatment of several neuronal disorders. The great majority of these effects of THC are mediated by cannabinoid receptor type 1 (CB1), which is abundantly expressed in the central nervous system. The exact anatomical and neuronal substrates of each action are, however, not clearly known at the moment. We addressed this issue by using an advanced genetic approach. Control and conditional mutant mice, lacking CB1 expression in defined neuronal subpopulations but not in others, were treated with THC, and typical effects of the drug on motor behaviour, pain, and thermal sensation were scored. Our results show that different neuronal subpopulations mediate different effects of THC and could lead to a refined interpretation of the pharmacological actions of cannabinoids. Moreover, these data might provide the rationale for the development of drugs capable of selectively activating CB1 in specific neuronal subpopulations, thereby better exploiting cannabinoids' potential therapeutic properties.
generated_summary: The main psychotropic ingredient Δ9-tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) exerts a plethora of psychoactive effects through the activation of neuronal cannabinoid receptor type 1 (CB1), which is expressed in different neuronal subpopulations of the central nervous system. The exact neuroanatomical substrates underlying the effect of THC, however, is not known. We tested the locomotor, hypothermic, analgesic, and cataleptic effects of THC conditional knockout mouse lines, and found that CB1 was expressed in a wide range of neurons, including principal brain neurons, GABAergic neurons (release γ aminobutyric acid) and cortical glutamatergic neurons, and neurons expressing dopamine receptor D1, respectively. Surprisingly, mice lacking CB1 GABAergic and GABAergic neuron responded to THC similarly to wild-type littermates, but deletion of CB1 in principal neurons abolished strongly reduced behavioural and autonomic responses to the drug. Moreover, locomotor and hypothermic effects of the drug depend on the functional expression of GABAergic interneurons, which are important for neuronal function. These data pave the way for refined interpretation of the pharmacological effects of cannabinoids and neuronal functions.

Model results capture existence intrinsic evolutionary tradeoffs collectively prevent spread TIP - resistant HIV mutants population . , despite increased transmission rates TIP - treated sub - populations , unilateral TIP - resistant mutants shown reduced transmission rates TIP - untreated sub - populations . Second , TIP - resistant mutants shown reduced growth rates ( i.e. , replicative fitness ) TIP - treated TIP - untreated individuals . result tradeoffs , model finds TIP - susceptible HIV strains continually outcompete TIP - resistant HIV mutants patient population scales TIPs engineered express > 3 - fold genomic RNA HIV expresses . , results provide design constraints engineering population - scale therapies refractory acquisition antiviral resistance .
plain language summary: A major obstacle to effective antimicrobial therapy campaigns is the rapid evolution of drug resistance. Given the static nature of current pharmaceuticals and vaccines, natural selection inevitably drives pathogens to mutate into drug-resistant variants that can resume productive replication. Further, these drug-resistant mutants transmit across populations, resulting in untreatable epidemics. Recently, a therapeutic strategy was proposed in which viral deletion mutants—termed therapeutic interfering particles (TIPs)—are engineered to only replicate by stealing their missing proteins from full-length viruses in co-infected cells. By stealing essential viral proteins, these engineered molecular parasites have been predicted to reduce viral levels in patients and viral transmission events across populations. Yet, a critical question is whether rapidly mutating viruses like HIV can evolve around TIP control by reducing production of the proteins that TIPs must steal in order to replicate (i.e., by ‘starving’ the TIPs). Here we develop a multi-scale model that tests whether TIP-starving HIV mutants can spread across populations to undermine TIP therapy campaigns at the population-scale. Strikingly, model results show that inherent evolutionary tradeoffs prevent these TIP-resistant HIV mutants from increasing in frequency (i.e., these TIP-resistant HIV mutants are continually outcompeted by TIP-sensitive mutants in both patients and populations). Maintained by natural selection, TIPs may offer a novel therapeutic approach to indefinitely control rapidly evolving viral pandemics.
generated_summary: The rapid evolution of RNA-encoded viruses in HIV presents a major barrier to infectious disease control and conventional pharmaceuticals. Previously, it was proposed that defective interfering particles could be developed indefinitely to control the HIV/AIDS pandemic; individual patients, engineered molecular parasites predicted refractory HIV mutational escape (i.e., ‘resistance-proof’). However, the outstanding question is whether engineered interfering particles— termed Therapeutic Interfering Particles (TIPs)—would remain resistance-proof at the population-scale. Here, we develop a multi-scale model to test whether TIPs can maintain indefinite control of HIV at the HIV population-size. We find that TIP-resistant HIV mutants continually outcompete TIP resistant HIV mutants by limiting the production of viral proteins that are available to HIV mutants to parasitize. Our results capture the existence of intrinsic evolutionary tradeoffs that collectively prevent the spread of HIV mutants in the patient population scale. First, despite increased transmission rates in TIP treated sub- populations, unilateral TIP–resistant mutants have shown reduced transmission rates compared to TIP untreated sub-population. Second, TIP and resistant mutants have reduced growth rates and replicative fitness compared to those of TIP or untreated individuals. These results provide design constraints for engineering population-level therapies that can be used to prevent the acquisition of antiviral resistance.

plain language summary: Parvoviruses in cats and dogs have been studied as a model system to understand how viruses gain the ability to infect new host species. By studying the evolution of the transferrin receptor, which the virus uses to enter a cell, we discovered that the ancestors of dogs were likely infected by a parvovirus millions of years ago until they evolved and became resistant; this was caused by their transferrin receptor changing so it no longer bound the virus. When a variant virus that infects dogs emerged in the 1970s, it had adapted to overcome this block. This story suggests that diseases which were once eliminated from a species can evolve and regain the infectivity for that host, therefore having high potential to be emerging diseases. We identified features of the receptor that were important to the evolution of this host-virus interaction and confirmed their role in regulating virus binding in cell culture.
generated_summary: Parvoviruses exploit the transferrin receptor type-1 (TfR) for cellular entry into carnivores, where specific interactions are key to control the host range. Here, we show that key mutations acquired during TfR evolution in Caniforms (dogs related species) have modified interactions with parvovirus capsids reducing the level of binding. We show that these mutations are signatures of a positive selection for the TFRC gene, consistent with an evolutionary arms race between the TfRs and Caniform clade of parviviruses. We also show that a glycosylation site mutation in the TFR in dogs provided resistance to carnivore parvirus infection prior to the speciation of coyotes and dogs. Our results suggest that the evolution of canine parvvirus resistance in dogs prior to 1975 predates speciation by coyotes or dogs.

plain language summary: The arbovirus Tick-borne encephalitis virus (TBEV; genus Flavivirus) is transmitted by ticks of the Ixodes genus. TBEV causes febrile illness and encephalitis in humans in forested regions of Europe and Asia. The incidence of TBE is increasing across Central and Eastern European countries despite the availability of several licensed inactivated vaccines and appropriate vaccination programmes. Large-scale codon re-encoding, a recently developed attenuation method that modifies viral RNA nucleotide composition of large coding regions without alteration of the encoded proteins, has been successfully applied to a variety of RNA viruses. In contrast with previous empirical methods of generating live attenuated vaccines, large-scale codon re-encoding facilitates rapid generation of vaccine candidates using reverse genetics methods, by direct control of the attenuation phenotype. Additional benefits include reduced costs and induction of long-term immunity. Here, we have applied the large-scale codon re-encoding method to the TBEV to demonstrate the principle of developing a live attenuated virus vaccine which protects mice against subsequent infection with the wild type virulent virus. This study therefore illustrates that codon re-encoding is potentially an easily derived and effective method of producing live attenuated vaccine candidates against positive-stranded RNA viruses.
generated_summary: Tick-borne encephalitis virus (TBEV) causes febrile illness in humans and forested regions of Europe and Asia. The infectious clone of the Oshima 5–10 strain (the wild-type virus) was modified by randomly introducing 273 synonymous mutations (the "-encoded virus"). Whilst cellulo replicative fitness of the encoded virus was slightly reduced, the non-lethal virus displayed an attenuated phenotype in a laboratory mouse model of non-disease. Following intra-peritoneal inoculation with 2.105 and 2.106 TCID50 virus, the frequency of viraemia, neurovirulence ( measured weight loss and appearance of symptoms) and neuroinvasiveness (the detection of the virus in the brain) were significantly decreased compared to the wild-Type virus. Mice infected with the infected-type-encoding virus produced comparable amounts of neutralising antibodies. These results provide evidence that mammalian species have protected against infection with a virulent wild- type positive-stranded RNA virus following immunisation with a randomly-enriched strain.

According Receiver Operating Curve , LID-1 LID - NDO performed similarly . sensitivity MB cases 89 % LID-1 95 % LID - NDO ; specificity 96 % LID-1 88 % LID - NDO . 332 HHC followed , 12 ( 3.6 % ) diagnosed leprosy median time 31 ( 3–79 ) months recruitment . linear generalized model LID-1 LID - NDO predictor estimated 8.3 % 10.4 % HHC leprosy case , respectively . , findings support role LID-1 LID - NDO antigens diagnosing MB leprosy identifying people greater risk developing clinical disease . assays potential improve diagnostic capacity local health centers aid development strategies eventual control elimination leprosy endemic areas .
plain language summary: Despite the substantial decrease in its prevalence, leprosy continues to be a worldwide challenge. Early diagnosis and treatment are important to interrupt transmission. Currently, there is no gold standard for the diagnosis of leprosy. Bacilloscopy and histopathology studies are complementary exams that provide high specificity but low sensitivity. It is therefore important to seek alternative tools to achieve rapid and accurate diagnosis. The state of Rio Grande do Norte, in Brazil, has municipalities’ that are considered hyperendemic for leprosy, such as Mossoró, the one included in this study. This city presented an average of new case detection rate (NCDR) of 45.4/100.000 inhabitants per year from 2001 to 2013, much higher than Brazil’s NCDR, which is currently 15.3. Here, we show that the utility of the recombinant antigens LID-1 and LID-NDO to diagnose MB patients and detect asymptomatic M. leprae infection. In addition, we showed that antibody levels were related to the clinical form of leprosy as well as to the bacillary load. Interestingly, we observed that serum levels of LID-1/LID-NDO antibodies can be used to predict leprosy development among HHC. The assays have the potential to eventually be implemented as point of care at local health centers.
generated_summary: Leprosy is caused by Mycobacterium leprae infection and remains a major public health problem in many areas of the world. Challenges in timely diagnosis result in delay in treatment and usually associated with severe disability. The phenolic glycolipid (PGL)-I is a reported auxiliary diagnostic tool, currently used as a serological assay routinely for leprosy diagnosis. The aim of this study was to evaluate the effectiveness of one of the related reagents, LID-1, and its anti-LID-NDO, in the detection of M. lepera infection. Sera were collected from 98 patients, 365 household contacts (HHC) and 98 endemic controls in Rio Grande Norte, Brazil, and followed for 7–10 years. Antigen-specific antibody responses were highest in the multibacillary (MB) lepromatous pole (LL/BL) and lowest in the tuberculoid pole (TT/BT). A positive correlation between anti-lID-2 and anti-NOD antibodies was found between bacterial burden and bacterial burden. In the HHC followed, 12 (3.6%) of the patients were diagnosed with Leprosy at the median time of 31 (3–79) months after recruitment. The linear generalized model of Lid-1 and NDO was estimated to be an estimated 8.3% and 10.4% of each HHC and LPA case, respectively. Our findings support the role of LID–1 and LID-, NDO antigens in diagnosing MB and lepsy and identifying people at greater risk of developing clinical disease.

plain language summary: Certain proteins can misfold into β-sheet-rich, self-seeding aggregates. Such proteins appear to be associated with neurodegenerative diseases such as prion, Alzheimer's and Parkinson's. Yeast prions also misfold into self-seeding aggregates and provide a good model to study how these rogue polymers first appear. De novo prion appearance can be made very frequent in yeast by transient overexpression of the prion protein in the presence of heterologous prions or prion-like aggregates. Here, we show that the aggregates of one such newly induced prion are initially formed in a dot-like structure near the vacuole. These dots then grow into rings at the periphery of the cell prior to becoming smaller rings surrounding the vacuole and maturing into the characteristic heritable prion tiny dots found throughout the cytoplasm. We found considerable colocalization of two heterologous prion/prion-like aggregates with the newly appearing prion protein aggregates, which is consistent with the prevalent model that existing prion aggregates can cross-seed the de novo aggregation of a heterologous prion protein. However, we failed to find any physical interaction between another heterologous aggregating protein and the newly appearing prion aggregates it stimulated to appear, which is inconsistent with cross-seeding.
generated_summary: Prions are self-replicating conformational variants of particular proteins. In yeast, prions cause heritable phenotypic traits. In this study, we show that a prion form, Sup35, appears de novo at dramatically enhanced rates following transient overproduction of Sup35 in the presence of [PIN+]. We also show that Sup35 aggregates are overexpressed in relation to cellular proteins. We show that this is consistent with heterologous aggregates that colocalize in the absence of the PIN+. In addition, we demonstrate that the interaction between Mod5 and Sup35 is required for denovo appearance of these aggregates.

plain language summary: Genomes of newly emerging species restrict their gene exchange with related taxa in order to secure integrity. Hybrid sterility is one of the reproductive isolation mechanisms restricting gene flow between closely related, sexually reproducing organisms. We showed that hybrid sterility between two closely related mouse subspecies is executed by a failure of meiotic synapsis of orthologous chromosomes in F1 hybrid males. The asynapsis of orthologous chromosomes occurred in meiosis of male and female hybrids, though only males were sterile due to trans-acting male-specific hybrid sterility genes. We located one of the two major hybrid sterility genes to a 4.7 Mb interval on Chromosome X, showed that it controls male sterility by modulating the extent of meiotic asynapsis and using the inter-subspecific chromosome substitution strains we refuted the simple interpretation of dominance theory of Haldane's rule. A new working hypothesis posits male sterility of mouse inter-subsubspecific F1 hybrids as a consequence of meiotic chromosome asynapsis caused by the cis-acting mismatch between orthologous chromosomes modulated by the trans-acting hybrid male sterility genes.
generated_summary: Hybrid sterility (HS) is one of the most important reproductive isolation barriers to safeguard the integrity of species statu nascendi. While hybrid sterility occurs universally in animal and plant species, current knowledge comes from classical genetic studies of Drosophila interspecific crosses and introgressions. In the house mouse subspecies Mus m. musculus and Mus m., we used a mouse model to identify the molecular mechanisms underlying HS. Using QTL analysis, we identified a 4.7 Mb critical region of Chromosome X (Chr X) harboring the Hstx2 HS locus, which causes asymmetrical spermatogenic arrest of reciprocal intersubspecific F1 hybrids. Combination with immunofluorescent visualization of proteins and synaptonemal complexes-chromosome DNA from FISH pachytene spreads revealed that heterosubspecific, unlike consubspecific hybrids, homologous chromosomes are predisposed to asynapsis F1 hybrid male and female meiosis. We also found that trans-acting Hst1/Prdm9 and hybrid male sterility genes in pachynemas and male female hybrids resolved an apparent conflict between dominance theory and the Haldane rule.

ENCoM fast existing ENM methods outperforms methods generation conformational ensembles . introduce new application NMA methods use ENCoM prediction effect mutations protein stability . existing methods based machine learning enthalpic considerations , use ENCoM , based vibrational normal modes , based entropic considerations . represents novel area application NMA methods novel approach prediction effect mutations . compare ENCoM large number methods terms accuracy self - consistency . accuracy ENCoM comparable best existing methods . existing methods biased prediction destabilizing mutations ENCoM biased predicting stabilizing mutations .
plain language summary: Normal mode analysis (NMA) methods can be used to explore potential movements around an equilibrium conformation by mean of calculating the eigenvectors and eigenvalues associated to different normal modes. Each normal mode represents a global collective, correlated and complex, form of motion of the entire protein. Any conformation around equilibrium can be represented as a weighted combination of normal modes. Differences in the magnitudes of the set of eigenvalues between two structures can be used to calculate differences in entropy. We introduce ENCoM the first coarse-grained NMA method to consider atom-specific side-chain interactions and thus account for the effect of mutations on eigenvectors and eigenvalues. ENCoM performs better than existing NMA methods with respect to traditional applications of NMA methods but is the first to predict the effect of mutations on protein stability and function. Comparing ENCoM to a large set of dedicated methods for the prediction of the effect of mutations on protein stability shows that ENCoM performs better than existing methods particularly on stabilizing mutations. ENCoM is the first entropy-based method developed to predict the effect of mutations on protein stability.
generated_summary: Normal mode analysis (NMA) methods are widely used to study dynamic aspects of protein structures. The critical components of NMA methods are the coarse-graining level simplification of the protein structures and the choice between the potential energy and functional form. The trade-off between speed and accuracy is between different choices. The extreme, fast elastic network model (ENM) methods use Cα−only representations of simplified potentials based on geometry, oblivious to the protein sequence. We present ENCoM, an elastic network contact model that employs potential energy function and includes a pairwise atom-type non-bonded interaction term. We show that the fast existing ENM methods outperforms the methods for generation conformational ensembles. We introduce a new application of the new application to NMA. Our new application is to predict the effect of mutations on protein stability. The existing methods are based on machine learning and enthalpic considerations, whereas the new methods use ENCoMs, based on vibrational normal modes, based upon entropic considerations. This represents a novel area of application for NMA and a novel approach for prediction of effect mutations.

plain language summary: Essential tremor (ET) is acknowledged to be the most common movement disorder affecting 1% of the population. Although the underlying mechanisms remain elusive, the thalamus, cortex and cerebellum are implicated in the underlying pathology. More recently, it has been shown that ET can be successfully treated by deep brain stimulation (DBS). This clinical treatment involves the surgical implantation of electrodes into the brain, through which current is applied. However, the mechanisms of how DBS achieves clinical benefit continue to be debated. A key question is whether ET can be modeled as a pathological network behavior as has been suggested previously. If so, we can then ask how DBS would modulate this brain activity. Our study combines: (i) simultaneous electrophysiological recordings from the brain and muscle; (ii) computational modelling; (iii) mathematical analysis. We found that the network supports oscillations in the tremor range, and the application of high frequency DBS switches this to low amplitude, high-frequency activity. We propose that our model can be used to predict DBS parameter settings that suppress pathological network activity and consequently tremor. In summary, we provide the first population level model of essential tremor including the effect of DBS on network behaviour.
generated_summary: Essential tremor (ET) is a movement disorder characterised by uncontrollable shaking of the affected body, which is a common movement disorder affecting about 40% of adults over 40 years of age. The precise cause of ET is unknown, and pathological oscillations in the network of a number of brain regions are implicated in the leading disorder. Deep brain stimulation (DBS) clinical therapy has been shown to alleviate the symptoms of an increasing number of movement disorders. DBS involves surgical implantation of electrodes in specific nuclei of the brain. The ET is targeted to a region of the ventralis intermedius (Vim) of the nucleus thalamus. Although DBS is effective in treating ET, the mechanism of its therapeutic effect is not fully understood. To elucidate the mechanism underlying the pathological network activity and the effect of DBS activity, we developed a computational modelling approach that combined electrophysiological data and computational modelling. We modelled the network using intra-operatively implanted DBS electrodes, whilst simultaneously recording muscle activity in affected limbs. The modelled network was hypothesised to underlie the ET Wilson-Cowan approach. Our model showed that the dynamics of the ET network support oscillations of tremor frequency, and that application of a DBS-like input disrupts the activity, which may be the mechanism for its therapeutic benefit.

plain language summary: Salmonella are a group of bacteria that cause illnesses and death worldwide. There are two types of Salmonella–Typhi and non-typhoidal (NTS). In humans, the majority of illnesses caused by NTS are related to gastro-intestinal problems, though uncommonly, it also invades the bloodstream. On the other hand, typhoid fever caused by Salmonella typhi commonly invades the bloodstream. Since the treatment of the two types may differ, we wanted to compare the risk factors for each. We studied patients who had NTS or Typhi isolated from blood in a diarrheal hospital in Bangladesh. We observed that patients with NTS bloodstream infection frequently presented with severe malnutrition, clinically diagnosed sepsis and pneumonia compared to those with typhoid fever. We also found that NTS and Typhi differed in what antibiotics they were sensitive to. These observations may help our clinicians to initiate aggressive treatment from the very beginning of the illness in children with NTS bacteremia in order to attain better outcomes.
generated_summary: Non-typhoidal Salmonella (NTS) and Typhi bacteremia are the leading causes of morbidity and mortality worldwide. The paucity of data on NTS and typhoid in South Asia, the region with the highest incidence of typhoidal bactemia, has led to the need to determine the clinical predictors of outcomes associated with NTS and bactermia compared to typhoid bacters. We performed a retrospective age-matched case-control study of patients admitted to Dhaka Hospital International Centre for Diarrhoeal Disease Research, Bangladesh, between February 2009 and March 2013. We compared demographic, clinical, microbiological, and outcome variables in NTS bactera patients with age- matched S. Typhi and basteremic patients, and in separate comparison patients with NTS or typhoid gastroenteritis. We found that in NTS patients with severe acute malnutrition (SAM), clinical sepsis, pneumonia, and pneumonia were independent risk factors for NTS and S. typhoid. Furthermore, we found marked differences in antibiotic susceptibilities, including NTS strains resistant to antibiotics commonly used in empiric therapy for patients suspected of typhoid fever.

plain language summary: Almost all cellular mRNAs terminate in a 3′ poly(A) tail, the removal of which can induce both translational silencing and mRNA decay. Mammalian cells encode many poly(A)-specific exoribonucleases, but their individual roles are poorly understood. Here, we undertook an analysis of the role of PARN deadenylase in mouse myoblasts using global measurements of mRNA decay rates. Our results reveal that a discrete set of mRNAs exhibit altered mRNA decay as a result of PARN depletion and that stabilization is associated with increased poly(A) tail length and translation efficiency. We determined that stabilization of mRNAs does not generally result in their increased abundance, supporting the idea that mRNA decay is coupled to transcription. Importantly, knockdown of PARN has wide ranging effects on gene expression that specifically impact the extracellular matrix and cell migration.
generated_summary: PARN is a deadenylase enzyme that is present in mammalian cells, but its contribution to regulation of gene expression remains unclear. To address this issue, we performed global mRNA expression half-life analysis in mouse myoblasts depleted of PARN. PARN knockdown resulted in stabilization of 40 mRNAs, including the mRNA decay factor ZFP36L2. Additional experiments demonstrated that PARN-dependent regulation induced an increase in Zfp36l2 poly(A) tail length and increased translation. Surprisingly, changes in mRNA stability showed an inverse correlation with mRNA abundance; stabilized transcripts showed a change in mRNA abundance and reduced mRNA abundance. Our data provide compelling evidence that coupling mRNA decay and transcription buffer mRNA abundances has a larger effect on global gene expression. Furthermore, our data demonstrate that mRNA abundance reduced by PARN and that these genes encode factors that are required for cell migration and adhesion. These data provide new insights into the mechanisms by which PARN regulates gene expression and suggest that the function of these genes is important for cell movement.

plain language summary: Macrophages are one of the major target cells for HIV-1 infection and play an important role in viral pathogenesis. Previous studies indicated that the pathway of HIV-1 particle morphogenesis is distinct in primary human macrophages, and this has been suggested to play a role in viral persistence. Early reports indicated that HIV-1 accumulates within apparently intracellular vacuolar structures, which were later identified as being of late endosomal origin. Endosomes were therefore suggested to comprise the budding and storage compartment for HIV-1 in primary human macrophages, from which infectious virus can be released in a regulated manner. In the present study, we show that HIV-1 budding occurs predominantly at the plasma membrane also in primary human macrophages. Using electron microscopy, we observed that the cell surface of macrophages displays an unexpectedly complex morphology with many protrusions and deep invaginations. HIV-1 budding occurs primarily at these invaginations that are clearly connected to the cell surface and do not belong to the endocytic compartment. Mature virus particles can remain trapped within such invaginations giving the appearance of an intracellular budding compartment. These results suggest a general pathway of HIV-1 morphogenesis with the plasma membrane as viral budding site.
generated_summary: HIV-1 assembly is believed to occur in the plasma membrane of host cells, with the exception of primary macrophages. However, exclusive budding of late endosomes has been reported. Here, we applied a novel ultrastructural approach to assess HIV-1 budding in primary and secondary macrophage in an immunomarker-independent manner. We found that HIV budding profiles were virtually excluded from gold-filled endosome-positive membranes, but were frequently detected in ruthenium red–positive membranes. The composition of cellular marker proteins incorporated into HIV–1 was supported by a plasma membrane–derived origin of the viral envelope. Contrary to current opinion, plasma membrane is the primary site of HIV-2 budding in infected macrophaging.

abstract: Development function tissues organs powered activity mitochondria . humans , inherited genetic mutations lead progressive mitochondrial pathology manifest infancy lead death , reflecting indispensable nature mitochondrial biogenesis function . , describe zebrafish mutant gene mia40a ( chchd4a ) , life - essential homologue evolutionarily conserved Mia40 oxidoreductase drives biogenesis cysteine - rich mitochondrial proteins . report mia40a mutant animals undergo progressive cellular respiration defects develop enlarged mitochondria skeletal muscles ultimate death larval stage . generated deep transcriptomic proteomic resource allowed identify abnormalities development physiology endodermal organs , particular liver pancreas . identify acinar cells exocrine pancreas severely affected mutations MIA pathway . data contribute better understanding molecular , cellular organismal effects mitochondrial deficiency , important accurate diagnosis future treatment strategies mitochondrial diseases .
plain language summary: Mitochondrial pathologies which result from mutations in the nuclear DNA remain incurable and often lead to death. As mitochondria play various roles in cellular and tissue-specific contexts, the symptoms of mitochondrial pathologies can differ between patients. Thus, diagnosis and treatment of mitochondrial disorders remain challenging. To enhance this, the generation of new models that explore and define the consequences of mitochondria insufficiencies is of central importance. Here, we present a mia40a zebrafish mutant as a model for mitochondrial dysfunction, caused by an imbalance in mitochondrial protein biogenesis. This mutant shares characteristics with existing reports on mitochondria dysfunction, and has led us to identify novel phenotypes such as enlarged mitochondrial clusters in skeletal muscles. In addition, our transcriptomics and proteomics data contribute important findings to the existing knowledge on how faulty mitochondria impinge on vertebrate development in molecular, tissue and organ specific contexts.
generated_summary: The development of tissues and organs is powered by the activity of mitochondria. In humans, inherited genetic mutations lead to progressive mitochondrial pathology that manifest in infancy and can lead to death, reflecting the indispensable nature of mitochondrial biogenesis and function. Here, we describe a zebrafish mutant gene mia40a (chchd4a), a life-essential homologue of the evolutionarily conserved Mia40 oxidoreductase, which drives the biogenesis of cysteine-rich mitochondrial proteins. We report that mias40a mutant animals undergo progressive cellular respiration defects and develop enlarged mitochondria and skeletal muscles at the ultimate death of the larval stage. We also generated a deep transcriptomic proteomic resource that allowed us to identify abnormalities in the development of the endodermal organs, in particular the liver and pancreas. Our data contribute to better understanding of the molecular, cellular and organismal effects of mitochondrial deficiency, and will be important for the diagnosis of future treatment strategies for mitochondrial diseases.

plain language summary: In this study, we compared measures of entomological risk collected through routine household entomological monitoring by estimating an association with human DENV infection. Longitudinal entomological and human serology data from Iquitos, Peru, were used to test associations between Ae. aegypti indices and the 6-month risk of DENV seroconversion. Our analysis found no association between cross-sectional measures of Ae. aegypti abundance and the risk of DENV seroconversion. Longitudinal measures of Ae. aegypti were better proxies for DENV risk, primarily among adult stage mosquito indicators. DENV transmission is complex and time-varying; the relationship between vector density and risk is not static nor adequately characterized through periodic entomological surveillance. While entomological monitoring will continue to serve a role in the evaluation of vector control interventions (e.g., comparing pre- and post-intervention abundance), our analysis challenges the validity of most Ae. aegypti indicators as adequate proxies for true DENV exposure risk.
generated_summary: Dengue fever (DENV) is a mosquito-borne disease that is transmitted by the mosquito Ae. aegypti. It is transmitted to humans by the bite of the mosquito, which can be transmitted by mosquitoes. In this study, we measured the abundance of Ae. Aegyptis in two longitudinal cohort studies in Iquitos, Peru, linked to 8,153 paired serological samples taken approximately six months apart. We found that Ae.Ae.A. a. densities were associated with increased risk of DENV seroconversion. We also found that higher cross-sectional and longitudinal entomological data was associated with an increased risk for DENV infection. These findings are consistent with previous studies that have shown that increased cross-sectional and longitudinal data are associated with a higher risk of infection.

abstract: Infectious diseases primary healthcare problems worldwide , leading millions deaths annually . develop effective control prevention strategies , need reliable computational tools understand disease dynamics predict future cases . computational tools policy makers informed decisions . study , developed computational framework based Gaussian processes perform spatiotemporal prediction infectious diseases exploited special structure similarity matrices formulation obtain efficient implementation . tested framework problem modeling Crimean – Congo hemorrhagic fever cases years 2004 2015 Turkey . showed Gaussian process formulation obtained better results frequently standard machine learning algorithms ( i.e. , random forests boosted regression trees ) temporal , spatial , spatiotemporal prediction scenarios . results showed framework potential important contribution public health policy makers .
plain language summary: Infectious diseases cause important health problems worldwide and create difficult challenges for public health policy makers. That is why they need reliable computational tools to better understand disease and to predict case counts. They will benefit from such computational tools to make more informed decisions in developing control and prevention strategies. We formulated a computational framework that can be used to model spatial, temporal, or spatiotemporal dynamics of infectious diseases. We showed the utility of our framework on the problem of modeling Crimean–Congo hemorrhagic fever in Turkey.
generated_summary: Infectious diseases are primary healthcare problems worldwide, leading to millions of deaths annually. To develop effective control and prevention strategies, we need reliable computational tools to understand disease dynamics and predict future cases. In this study, we developed a computational framework based on Gaussian processes to perform spatiotemporal prediction of infectious diseases. We used a special structure similarity matrices formulation to obtain efficient implementation. We showed that the Gaussian process formulation obtained better results than frequently used machine learning algorithms (i.e., random forests boosted by regression trees) in temporal, spatial, and spatiotemeporal prediction scenarios. Our results showed that this framework has potential as an important contribution to public health policy makers.

plain language summary: There are many examples of recent emergence of mosquito-borne viruses, such as chikungunya virus outbreaks throughout the Caribbean in 2013, Zika virus outbreaks throughout Southern and Central America in 2015, and yellow fever virus in Brazil in 2017. Each outbreak draws attention to the limits associated with predicting future outbreaks. This study expands our understanding of risk factors for exposure to two common genera of mosquito-borne viruses, alphaviruses and flaviviruses. Risk factors identified include simple demographic factors, such as age or sex, and behaviors associated with occupation or livelihood around the home. Behaviors enhancing or limiting contact with mosquitoes are also significant predictors, as mosquitoes drive transmission. More clearly defining the epidemiology of these infections within a population can elevate the accuracy and efficacy of public health initiatives that fuel community education and awareness, and outbreak prediction and monitoring can be elevated to a new level of accuracy and efficacy.
generated_summary: Alphaviruses, chikungunya virus, and flaviviruses are re-emerging arboviruses in endemic tropical environments. In many parts of Africa, alphavirus infections are undiagnosed, unreported, and febrile illnesses are assumed to be caused by malaria. In this study, we aimed to characterize seroprevalence of alphovirus flavivirus seropositivity among children (ages 5–14, n = 250) and adults (ages 15 ≥ 75, n= 250) in western Kenya. We found that children aged 10–14 were more likely to seropositive than adults (p < 0.001), suggesting a recent transmission period. Alphavirus flavvirus seropicivity was detected among the youngest participants (age 5–9) and was also detected among those aged 15–75, providing evidence of inter-epidemic transmission. Demographic variables significantly different between previous infection versus infection included age, education level, occupation, and environmental variables. Behavioral environmental variables that were significantly different from previous infection infection included taking animals grazing, fishing, and recent village flooding. Experience of recent fever was found to be a significant indicator of infection (p = 0.027). Our results confirm that alphirus is a major public health concern in the western Kenya, illustrating significantly higher alphivirus transmission compared to previous studies.

Taken , results suggest possibility tumor segmental aneuploidy makes significant contributions variation lactic acidosis / hypoxia gene signatures human cancers demonstrate latent factor analysis powerful means uncover linkage .
plain language summary: Gene signatures are a powerful tool to investigate biological processes in human cancer. However, it is clear that these gene signatures do not fully reflect the complexity of human cancer. Here we demonstrate how a latent factor model can improve the in vivo relevance of these pathway-associated gene signatures by dissecting them into co-regulated transcriptional components which better represent the structure in human cancer. We use this approach to analyze hypoxia and lactic acidosis gene signatures to identify latent factors that represent distinct, interacting components of the various biological processes which are in the initial gene signatures but poorly dissected. Some factors are clustered in small chromosomal regions and their expression values are highly correlated with their DNA copy number in both cancer cell lines and human tumors. Therefore, the gene dosage at the DNA levels may explain the differences in gene expression. Several factors contain genes which are known to directly modulate the hypoxia response and allow us to generate testable hypotheses regarding particular copy number changes and hypoxia signatures. Therefore, the use of latent factor analysis is a powerful means to identify pathway-associated changes in the DNA copy number and gene dosage.
generated_summary: Tumor microenvironmental stresses, such as hypoxia and lactic acidosis, play important roles in tumor progression. However, gene signatures reflecting the influence of these stresses are powerful approaches to link expression phenotypes, and fully reflect the complexity of human cancers. Here, we describe the use of latent factor models to dissect stress gene signatures in a breast cancer expression dataset. We found that the genes that are coordinately expressed in tumors depict distinct, interacting components of biological processes. These genes are highly enriched in chromosomal locations, and their expression values are highly correlated with copy number alterations (CNAs) corresponding to BAC clones in cell lines and tumors. Furthermore, we found that variation in expression of pathway-associated factors is partially caused by variation in gene dosage and CNAs in breast cancers. We also found that expression of latent factors with chromosomal enrichment is highly associated with 12q CNA, likely the only instance in which “trans”-variations in CNA leads to variations in gene expression outside the CNA region. Our results suggest that tumor segmental aneuploidy makes significant contributions to variation in lactic and acidosis/hypoxia gene signatures and demonstrate latent factor analysis as a powerful means to uncover linkage.

plain language summary: Understanding how proteins recognize each other is central to deciphering the inner workings of living things and for biomedical research. It has long been known that the sequence of a protein, which is a string of different amino acids, can dictate how a protein molecule folds into a well-defined shape required for biological tasks. Many folded proteins recognize and bind with each other by a tight geometric fit similar to that between a lock and its key. Recently, however, it has become clear that some proteins function as a flexible string, in constant motion, without forming a stable shape. Understanding how such “disordered” proteins work is challenging. To gain insight, we studied a disordered protein region that causes a large family of human cancers. Employing an innovative combination of experimental and theoretical techniques, we describe a new mode of protein interaction based on multiple simple contacts between one type of amino acid (aromatic) in the disordered protein and another type (positively charged) on the partner protein. Because this mechanism also underlies the ability of the disordered protein to cause cancer, further investigation of this unprecedented mode of protein-protein interaction may open up new avenues for cancer therapy.
generated_summary: Molecular recognition of intrinsically disordered proteins (IDPs) commonly involves specific localized contacts in target-induced disorder and order transitions. However, IDPs remain in a disordered bound state, a phenomenon coined “fuzziness”, characterized by IDP polyvalency, sequence-insensitivity and dynamic ensemble disordered and bound-state conformations. In general, specific biophysical models of fuzzy interactions are lacking. Here, we show that the transcriptional activation domain of the Ewing Sarcoma oncoprotein family (EAD) IDP exhibits features of fuzziness, including multiple EAD aromatic chains driving molecular recognition. Considering the prevalent role of cation-π interactions in protein-protein interfaces, we hypothesized that EAD-target binding involves polycation- π contacts in the disordered EAD basic residues of the target. We evaluated this hypothesis in a functional theoretical interrogation of EAD variants. Our experimental effects range from EAD sequence variations, including aromatic number, aromatic density, and charge perturbations, support the cation–pi� model. Moreover, the activity trends observed were captured in a coarse-grained EAD chain model corresponding to an analytical model based on interaction between EAD aromatics and surface cations of the generic globular target. Our results provide a general conceptual framework for promiscuous target recognition of polyvalent IDPs.

abstract: choice situations require imagining potential outcomes , capacity shown involve memory brain regions hippocampus . reasoned quality hippocampus - mediated simulation condition subjective value assigned imagined outcomes . developed novel paradigm assess impact hippocampus structure function propensity favor imagined outcomes context intertemporal choices . ecological condition opposed immediate options presented pictures ( directly observable ) delayed options presented texts ( requiring mental stimulation ) . avoid confounding simulation process delay discounting , compared ecological condition control conditions temporal labels keeping constant presentation mode . Functional MRI data confirmed hippocampus activity account subjects assigning higher values simulated options .
