Testing 132 candidate protein complexes fluorescence resonance energy transfer assay confirmed formation tight selective heterodimers designed peptides targets . approach inhibitors native proteins , develop novel peptides applications synthetic biology nanotechnology .
plain language summary: Protein interactions are important for all life processes, and an ability to rationally control or selectively inhibit protein complexes would impact studies of cellular structure, biological information processing, molecular regulatory processes and other phenomena. Rational protein design has applications in developing biotherapeutics and in advancing synthetic biology and nanotechnology. Rational protein-interaction design has been approached in many ways over the past decades, but it remains a challenge. Computational methods require models to predict binding and tools for applying predictive models in design. Many such methods are based on modeling and evaluating protein structure using physical or semi-physical energy terms. In this work, we used a different strategy, deriving a binding model that describes the protein-protein interactions of basic-region leucine-zipper (bZIP) transcriptions factors directly from a large body of experimental interaction data. Our model showed much better performance than previously published predictors. We used our model, in conjunction with a protein-design strategy that builds new proteins from modular parts of known proteins, to successfully design novel bZIP-like protein domains. We demonstrated experimentally that the designed proteins bind tightly and specifically to a number of human bZIPs that regulate important processes including stress responses and oncogenesis.
generated_summary: Selective dimerization of basic-region leucine- zipper (bZIP) transcription factors presents a vivid example of the high degree of interaction specificity achieved by a family of structurally similar proteins. The coiled-coil motif mediates homo- and hetero-dimerization of bZIP proteins and has been intensively studied, and a variety of methods have been proposed to predict interactions with sequence data. In this work, we develop a predictive model that exploits the knowledge of the structurally conserved residue-and residue interactions of the coiled coil motif. The model, which expresses the interaction energies in sum of interpretable residue-pair triplet terms, achieves correlation between experimental binding free energies and R = 0.68 significantly-performs scoring functions. We use the model to develop novel synthetic peptides for assembling and assembling 7- residue native-protein heptad modules into new combinations. We find that the optimal combination of heptads can bind selectively to human bZip domains, and target paralogs. Our approach, which is based on a fluorescence resonance energy transfer assay, confirmed the formation of tight selective heterodimers for the designed peptides.

abstract: fundamental understanding behavior requires predicting individual choose . , actual temporal sequential dynamics successive choices multiple alternatives remain unclear . current study , tested hypothesis general bursting property timing sequential patterns foraging decisions . conducted foraging experiment rats chose different foods continuous - week time period . choices , found bursts rapidly occurring actions , separated time - varying inactive periods , partially based circadian rhythm . chosen , found sequential dynamics affective choices characterized key features : ( ) highly biased choice distribution ; ( b ) preferential attachment , animals likely choose previously chosen . capture temporal dynamics , propose dual - state model consisting active inactive states . introduce satiation - attainment process bursty activity , non - homogeneous Poisson process longer inactivity bursts . sequential dynamics , propose dual - control model consisting goal - directed habit systems , based outcome valuation choice history , respectively . study provides insights bursty nature behavior emerges interaction different underlying systems , leading heavy tails distribution behavior time choices .
plain language summary: To understand spontaneous animal behavior, two key elements must be explained: when an action is made and what is chosen. Here, we conducted a foraging experiment in which rats chose among four different foods over a continuous two-week time period. With respect to when, we found bursts of rapidly occurring responses separated by long inactive periods. With respect to what, we found biased choice behavior toward the favorite items as well as repetitive behavior, reflecting goal-directed and habitual responding, respectively. We account for the when and what components with two distinct computational mechanisms, each composed of two processes: (a) active and inactive states for the temporal dynamics, and (b) goal-directed and habitual control for the sequential dynamics. This study provides behavioral and computational insights into the dynamical properties of decision-making that determine both when an animal will act and what the animal will choose. Our findings provide an integrated framework for describing the temporal and sequential structure of everyday choices among, for example, food, music, books, brands, web-browsing and social interaction.
generated_summary: A fundamental understanding of behavior requires predicting how an individual will choose. However, the actual temporal sequential dynamics of successive choices of multiple alternatives remain unclear. In this current study, we tested the hypothesis of a general bursting property of timing and sequential patterns of foraging decisions. We conducted a foraging experiment in rats that chose different foods over a continuous three-week time period. We found bursts of rapidly occurring actions, separated by time- varying inactive periods, partially based on the circadian rhythm. When chosen, we found that sequential dynamics were characterized by key features: (a) highly biased choice distribution; (b) preferential attachment, animals were more likely to choose previously chosen than animals that were previously chosen. To capture temporal dynamics, we propose a dual-state model consisting of active inactive states and bursty activity, and a non-homogeneous Poisson process with longer inactivity bursts. We propose that the bursty nature of behavior emerges from the interaction between different underlying systems, leading to heavy tails of the distribution of behavior during time choices.

RNH proteins Thermus thermophilus ( ttRNH ) Escherichia coli ( ecRNH ) share similar structures differ melting temperature ( Tm ) 20 ° C . ttRNH greater stability caused presence residual structure unfolded state , results low heat capacity unfolding ( ΔCp ) relative ecRNH . characterized RNH proteins variety extant bacteria found Tm correlates species ' growth temperatures , consistent environmental selection stability . ancestral sequence reconstruction statistically infer evolutionary intermediates lineages leading ecRNH ttRNH common ancestor , existed approximately 3 billion years ago . Finally , synthesized experimentally characterized intermediates . shared ancestor melting temperature ttRNH ecRNH ; Tms intermediate ancestors ttRNH lineage increased gradually time , ecRNH lineage exhibited abrupt drop Tm followed relatively little change . determine underlying mechanisms thermostability correlate changes Tm , measured thermodynamic basis stabilization — ΔCp thermodynamic parameters — ancestors . observed , Tm changes smoothly , mechanistic basis stability fluctuates evolutionary time . , overall stability appears strongly driven selection , proteins explored wide variety mechanisms stabilization , phenomenon “ thermodynamic system drift . ” suggests lineages strong selection increase stability , proteins wide latitude explore sequence space , generating biophysical diversity potentially opening new evolutionary pathways .
plain language summary: The biophysical properties of proteins must adjust to accommodate environmental temperatures because of the narrow range over which any given protein sequence can remain folded and functional. We compared the evolution of homologous bacterial enzymes (ribonucleases H1) from two lineages: one from Escherichia coli, which live at moderate temperatures, the other from Thermus thermophilus, which live at extremely high temperatures. Our aim was to investigate how these structurally homologous proteins can have such different thermostabilities, unfolding at temperatures that are 20°C apart. We used bioinformatics to reconstruct the sequences of ancestral proteins along each lineage, synthesized the proteins in the lab, and experimentally traced the evolution of ribonuclease H1 stability. While thermostability appears to have been strongly shaped by selection, the biophysical mechanisms used to tune protein stability appear to have varied throughout evolutionary history; this suggests that proteins have wide latitude to explore different mechanisms of stabilization, generating biophysical diversity and opening up new evolutionary pathways.
generated_summary: Bacterial ribonuclease H1 (RNH) proteins are thermophiles that are generally thermostable and mesophilic homologs, but little is known about the evolutionary process driving these differences. Here, we show that RNH proteins from Thermus thermophilus (ttRNH), Escherichia coli (eCNH) share similar structures but differ in melting temperature (Tm) at 20°C. Tm is a thermodynamic parameter that correlates with growth temperatures, consistent with environmental selection and stability. Finally, we synthesized experimentally characterized intermediates of the two lineages leading to the same ancestor. We found that the thermodynamic basis of stability was strongly driven by selection, and that the overall stability of the RNH system was strongly influenced by the phenomenon of “thermodynamic system drift.” This suggests that lineages of strong selection increase stability, and proteins wide latitude explore sequence space, generating biophysical diversity and potentially opening new evolutionary pathways.

Parameter estimation system indicated capita basis , infected pDC secretes sufficient type IFN protect 103 104 Mφs cytopathic viral infection . extremely high protective capacity pDCs secures spleen capability function ‘ sink ’ virus produced peripheral organs liver . Furthermore , results suggest pDC population spleen ensures robust protection virus variants substantially - modulate IFN secretion . , ability pDCs protect severe disease caused virus variants exhibiting enhanced liver tropism higher replication rates appears limited . Taken , systems immunology analysis suggests antiviral therapy cytopathic viruses primarily limit viral replication peripheral target organs .
plain language summary: Human infections with highly virulent viruses, such as 1918 influenza or SARS-coronavirus, represent major threats to public health. The initial innate immune responses to such viruses have to restrict virus spread before the adaptive immune responses fully develop. Therefore, it is of fundamental practical importance to understand the robustness and fragility of the early protection against such virus infections mediated by the type I interferon (IFN) response. Because of the inherent complexity of the virus-host system, we have used mathematical modeling to predict the sensitivity of the kinetics and severity of infection to variations in virus and host parameters. Our results suggest that the spleen represents a robust sink system for systemic virus infection and that this system is able to cope with substantial variations in IFN secretion and virus production. However, the system is very fragile to only minor increases in the virus growth rate in peripheral tissues. Collectively, the mathematical approach described in this study allows us to identify the most robust virus and host parameters during early cytopathic virus infection and can serve as a paradigm for systems immunology analyses of multiscale virus-host interaction of many life-threatening cytopathic virus infections.
generated_summary: Plasmacytoid dendritic cell (pDC)-mediated protection against cytopathic virus infection involves molecular, cellular, and tissue-scale, organism-scale events. In order to better understand these multiscale interactions, we implemented a systems immunology approach focusing on the structure, dynamics, and operating principles of virus-host interactions to constrain the initial spread of the pathogen. Using high-resolution experimental data sets from the coming-described mouse hepatitis virus (MHV) model, we calibrated basic modules including MHV infection primary target cells, i.e. pDCs and macrophages (Mφs), to generate an integrative mathematical model of the in vivo infection dynamics. Parameter estimation system indicated that on a per capita basis, infected pDC secretes sufficient type of IFN to protect 103 104 Mφ’s from cytopathsic viral infection. Furthermore, the extremely high protective capacity of infected pdcs secures the spleen capability to function as a ‘ sink’ for virus produced in the peripheral organs of the liver. These results suggest that the pDC population in the liver ensures robust protection against virus variants exhibiting enhanced liver tropism and higher replication rates.

plain language summary: Impaired acrosomal reaction (IAR) of sperm causes male subfertility in humans and animals, and currently the molecular causes of the condition are not known. Here we report the mapping, identification, and functional analysis of a susceptibility locus for IAR in stallions. The candidate region was mapped to horse chromosome 13 by SNP genotyping and GWAS of 7 IAR affected and 44 control Thoroughbred stallions. Re-sequencing and case-control analysis of functionally relevant candidate genes in the region identified FKBP6 gene as a significantly associated locus. The association was confirmed by genotyping 265 male horses of multiple breeds. FKBP6 belongs to the immunophilins FKBP family known to be involved in meiosis, calcium homeostasis, clathrin-coated vesicles, and membrane fusions. We showed that the equine FKBP6 is exclusively and monoallelically expressed in testis and sperm and has 5 different transcripts, of which 4 were novel. Overall, FKBP6 was considered a susceptibility gene of incomplete penetrance for IAR in stallions and a candidate gene for male subfertility in other mammals. Successful use of sperm as a source of DNA and RNA propagates non-invasive sample procurement for fertility genomics in animals and humans.
generated_summary: Impaired acrosomal reaction (IAAR) sperm causes male subfertility in humans and animals. Despite compelling evidence of genetic control of acrosome biogenesis and function, genomics of IAR is poorly understood, providing molecular tools for diagnostics. We conducted Equine SNP50 Beadchip genotyping of GWAS 7 IAR–affected 37 control Thoroughbred stallions. We found that a significant (P<6.75E-08) genotype–phenotype association was found in horse chromosome 13 FK506 binding protein 6 (FKBP6). This gene belongs to the immunophilins FKBP family and is known to be involved in meiosis, calcium homeostasis, clathrin-coated vesicles, membrane fusions, and membrane fusion. Direct sequencing of FKB6 exons in cases of controls and controls identified SNPs g.11040315G > g.10940379C > (p.166H > N) and exon 4 significantly associated with IAR phenotype in a GWAS cohort (n  =  44) of a large multi-breed cohort of 265 horses. We conclude that FKP6 is considered a susceptibility gene for incomplete penetrance of the IAR stallions candidate for a gene for male subferrance in mammals.

Furthermore performance entire system incremental improvements offered individual components , indicating beneficial non - linear interactions processing stages . algorithms underlying model implemented digital analog hardware , including neuromorphic analog VLSI , defy analytical solution dynamic non - linear operation . successful application algorithm applications development miniature autonomous systems defense civilian roles , including robotics , miniature unmanned aerial vehicles collision avoidance sensors .
plain language summary: Building artificial vision systems that work robustly in a variety of environments has been difficult, with systems often only performing well under restricted conditions. In contrast, animal vision operates effectively under extremely variable situations. Many attempts to emulate biological vision have met with limited success, often because multiple seemingly appropriate approximations to neural coding resulted in a compromised system. We have constructed a full model for motion processing in the insect visual pathway incorporating known or suspected elements in as much detail as possible. We have found that it is only once all elements are present that the system performs robustly, with reduction or removal of elements dramatically limiting performance. The implementation of this new algorithm could provide a very useful and robust velocity estimator for artificial navigation systems.
generated_summary: Self-motion information is an important feature of the visual world, but it is difficult to solve efficiently in biological organisms utilizing non-linear processing. Previous bio-inspired models of motion detection based on a correlation mechanism have been dogged by sensitivity and undesired properties of image, which can vary widely widely across images. Here we present a computational model of the motion detection process based on the known suspected responses of neurons in the visual motion pathway in the fly brain. We show that the model is robust to a large variety of images, velocities accelerations and accelerations. Furthermore, the entire system is incremental improvements offered by individual components, indicating beneficial interactions between the processing stages. The algorithms underlying the model are implemented on digital analog hardware, including neuromorphic analog VLSI, and defy the analytical solution for dynamic non-locus operation. This is a successful application algorithm for applications in the development of miniature autonomous systems for defense and civilian roles, including robotics, miniature unmanned aerial vehicles and collision avoidance sensors.

plain language summary: Tungiasis is a parasitic skin disease caused by the sand flea Tunga penetrans. After penetration into the skin, the flea grows and reaches the size of a pea. The disease is a neglected public health problem in endemic areas in Latin America, the Caribbean and Africa, and causes considerable morbidity in the affected communities. We performed a study in a rural community in Nigeria to detect factors associated with tungiasis. People were examined for the presence of sand flea lesions, and a questionnaire was applied. Of the 643 individuals examined, 252 (42.5%) had tungiasis. The most important factors independently associated with the disease were: presence of pigs on the compound (adjusted odds ratio [OR] = 17.98), sand or clay floor inside house (OR = 9.33), and having the common resting place outside the house (OR = 7.14). The regular use of closed footwear (OR = 0.34) and the use of insecticides indoors (OR = 0.2) were protective factors. Our data show that tungiasis in this community is determined to an important extent by some variables that may be a target for interventions.
generated_summary: Parasitic skin disease tungiasis (causing flea Tunga penetrans) affects resource-poor communities in Latin America, Caribbean and sub-Saharan Africa. Prevalences in endemic areas are high, and severe pathology occurs commonly. In this study, a cross-sectional study was conducted in Erekiti, a rural community in Lagos State, Nigeria, to assess the risk factors for tungiasis. We found that there were 252 (42.5%) infested with T. penetrans. The presence of pigs compounds (adjusted odds ratio  = 17.98; 95% confidence interval: 5.55–58.23) and sand clay floor inside houses (9.33; 5.06–17.19) and having a common resting place outside house (7.14; 4.0–14.29) were the important risk factors identified. The use of closed footwear (0.34; 0.18–0.62) and use of insecticides indoors were the most important factors for protective infestation. Effective sustainable intervention measures addressing these factors need to be implemented in West African communities with high disease burden.

plain language summary: The activity of ‘place cells’ in hippocampal area CA3 systematically changes as a function of the animal's position in an arena as well as contextual variables like the color or shape of enclosing walls. Large changes to the local environment, e.g. moving the animal to a different room, can induce a complete reorganization of place-cell firing locations. Such ‘global remapping’ reveals that memory for different environments is encoded as separate spatial maps. Smaller changes to features within an environment can induce a modulation of place cell firing rates without affecting their firing locations. This kind of ‘rate remapping’ is still poorly understood. In this paper we describe a computational model in which discrete memories for contextual features were stored locally within a spatial map of place cells. This network structure supports retrieval of both positional and contextual information from an arbitrary cue, as required by an episodic memory structure. The activity of the network qualitatively matches empirical data from rate remapping experiments, both on the population level and the level of single place cells. The results support the idea that CA3 rate remapping reflects content-addressable memories stored as multimodal attractor states in the hippocampus.
generated_summary: Episodic-like memory is thought to be supported by attractor dynamics in the hippocampus. However, the spatial map of place cells encodes contextual information and firing rate variability. To test whether memories stored in multimodal attractors populations in place cells, recent experiments morphed into a familiar context by observing responses in CA3 cell ensembles. The average population activity of CA3 cells showed a mix of gradual and abrupt transitions between different points in the morph sequence, which displayed a hysteresis signature of attractors dynamics. To understand seemingly conflicting results and commensurate attractor network theory, we developed a neural network model to model CA3 attractors position-dependent in discrete contexts. We found that when memories were stored in overlapping neural networks, the positions-dependent context of the attractors transitions at different points of morph sequence. Smooth transition curves arose averaging the population, and heterogeneous set of responses were observed at single unit level. In contrast, orthogonal memories led to abrupt coherent transitions at population single unit levels. Strong recurrent feedback entailed a hysteretic effect that diminished the overlap of stored memories. These results suggest that context-dependent memory is supported by overlapping local attractors in the temporal map of CA1 place cells. Similar mechanisms are found in regions of the cerebral cortex.

Similarly , early presence basement membrane ( BM ) extracellular matrix ( ECM ) proteins exudates reflects rapid microvascular damage hemorrhage induced snake venom metalloproteinases . presence fragments type IV collagen perlecan hour envenoming suggests hydrolysis mechanically / structurally - relevant BM components plays key role genesis hemorrhage . hand , increment ECM proteins exudate later time intervals likely consequence action endogenous matrix metalloproteinases ( MMPs ) de novo synthesis ECM proteins tissue remodeling inflammatory reaction . results offer relevant insights integrative systematic understanding time - course dynamics muscle tissue damage induced B. asper venom possibly viperid venoms .
plain language summary: The local pathology induced by viperid snakes is characterized by a complex of alterations as consequence of direct and indirect effects of the toxins present in the venom, as well as the host response to tissue damage, and constitutes a dynamic process of degenerative and reparative events. The pathogenesis of local effects induced by Bothrops asper venom has been studied by traditional methodologies. Recently, proteomic analysis of wound exudates collected in the vicinity of affected tissue has become a powerful tool to study the pathogenesis of local envenoming from a more integrative perspective. Thus, in the present study we analyzed the dynamics of the local effects induced by B. asper venom in the gastrocnemius muscle of mice through a proteomic and immunochemistry approach in order to identify biomarkers of tissue damage and repair during the course of envenoming. Our results showed an early presence of cytosolic and mitochondrial proteins in exudates as compared to cytoskeletal proteins, which reflect the rapid cytotoxic effect of venom, followed by the action of endogenous proteinases in the cytoskeleton of damaged muscle fibers later on in the course of envenoming. On the other hand, the early presence of extracellular matrix components and the increment of some of them in exudates, reflect the rapid microvascular damage and hemorrhage induced by the venom, followed by the action of endogenous matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs) during tissue remodeling as part of the inflammatory response. Overall our study allowed the identification of key biomarkers of tissue damage and repair as part of the pathological effects induced by B. asper venom in skeletal muscle, which offer relevant insights for a better understanding of the complex dynamics of local pathology induced by viperid snakebite envenoming.
generated_summary: The time-course pathological effects of venom of snake Bothrops asper in muscle tissue are investigated using a combination of histology, proteomic analysis of exudates collected in the vicinity of damaged muscle, and immunodetection of extracellular matrix proteins. Proteomic assays are an excellent new methodological tool to detect key biomarkers of tissue alterations from an integrative perspective of snake venom-induced pathology. In this study, we show that the early presence of cytosolic and mitochondrial proteins in exudate reflects a rapid cytotoxic effect of venom, especially on muscle fibers, followed by action of proteinases in the cytoskeleton and damaged muscle fibers. Similarly, the presence of basement membrane (BM) and extracelellular matrix (ECM) proteins in intracellular proteins reflects rapid microvascular damage and hemorrhage induced by snake venom metalloproteinases. The presence of fragments of type IV collagen perlecan hour envenoming suggests that hydrolysis of mechanically/structurally-relevant BM components plays a key role in the genesis of hemorrhage. On the other hand, the increment of ECM proteins exudated at later time intervals is likely consequence of the action of endogenous matrix metallopeases (MMPs) in the de novo synthesis and the tissue remodeling of the inflammatory reaction. These results offer relevant insights into the integrative and systematic understanding of the time- course dynamics of muscle tissue damage induced by B. asper venom and possibly viperid venoms.

plain language summary: Soil-transmitted Helminths potentially reduce physical growth and retard cognitive development in school-age children (SAC) with great implications for national control programs in Africa. In Uganda, baseline investigations between 1998 and 2002, indicated STH prevalence was over 60.0% in most districts, the commonest worms infections were Hookworms, Ascaris and Trichuris. Twice a year national deworming campaign was initiated in 2003 targeting aged 1–14 years. Over ten years of deworming campaigns, has reduced the overall STH prevalence to 8.8% in 2016. The findings suggest routine deworming campaigns reduce STH exposure and infections. Periodic program evaluations are key to determining the progress made in order to achieve the elimination targets by 2020.
generated_summary: Soil-transmitted Helminths Anemia (STH) is a serious health problem affecting children in developing countries. Deworming has been shown to reduce the level of STH infection in school-age children in Uganda. However, it is unclear whether deworming interventions are effective in reducing the prevalence and intensity of the STH infections. In this study, we conducted a cross-sectional study in four regions of Uganda, districts randomly selected to be based on ecological zones in the country. In the study districts, Mpigi Nakasongola Central; Nakapiripirit Kotido Karamoja; Arua Yumbe West Nile; Gulu Alebtong North; Kaliro Mbale East; and Hoima Bundibugyo West. We found that 4,285 children were assessed including 719 (16.82%) in the central region, 718(16.80%), and 50 children aged 6–14 years randomly selected. Stool samples were taken from each child and examined for the presence of helminthic infections. A short pretested questionnaire was administered to the participant to obtain knowledge, attitude, and practice relating to STH, control, and prevention. General observations of environmental sanitation and hygiene were also taken. The average age of children was 12.6 years standard deviation, SD 1.8 years minimum age 6 years and upper age limit 12 years. The percentage of boys (50.1%) and girls (49.9%) was comparable to those of girls. The prevalence of infection was 8.8% (95% CI; 8.0–9.7) infected with STH species. Hookworm was the most prevalent (7.7% ; 95% CI: 6.9–8.5) followed by whipworms (Trichuris trichiura) and roundworms (Ascaris lumbricoides). The children Schistosoma mansoni, 13.0% and 13.5% were comparable to girls. We also found that children knew more about soil transmitted helminths (62.8%) and common knowledge information (39%.8%), and media (39.1–40.8), media ( radio & newspaper)(11.7%), and friends(11.5%. We conclude that children are more likely to get infected with soil transmitted worms; eating contaminated food (77.5%), walking barefoot (59.6%), eating contaminated water (52.9% and CI: 57.8

plain language summary: Humans are able to report a sense of confidence in decisions that we make. It is widely hypothesized that confidence reflects the computed probability that a decision is accurate; however, this hypothesis has not been fully explored. We use several human behavioral experiments to test a variety of models that may be considered to be distinct hypotheses about the computational underpinnings of confidence. We find that reported confidence does not appear to reflect the probability that a decision is correct, but instead emerges from a heuristic approximation of this probability.
generated_summary: Humans use a variety of cognitive tasks to assess their ability to make decisions. However, it is widely believed that these reports reflect a Bayesian probability of a decision to be correct, a hypothesis that has not been rigorously tested in non-Bayesian alternatives. Here, we show that the perceptual categorization tasks that use Bayesian confidence reporting require subjects to account for sensory uncertainty in a specific way. We find that subjects with sensory uncertainty account for reporting confidence, suggesting that the brain areas involved in reporting confidence access to low-level representations of sensory uncertainty, a prerequisite for Bayesian inference. Our results suggest that the behavior is fully consistent with the Bayesian hypothesis better described by simple heuristic models that use uncertainty in the non- Bayesian way.

plain language summary: Most sexual eukaryotes require recombination between homologous chromosomes for the proper formation of haploid gametes from diploid germ cells. Evolutionarily, recombination increases the effectiveness of selection in natural populations, thus explaining the pervasiveness of recombination and sex. Recombination is also a central parameter in population genetic studies designed to detect the presence of selection acting across genomes. Current evolutionary analyses are hindered, however, by the use of imprecise recombination rates that can influence the results and skew their interpretation. This limitation is associated with the lack of detailed characterization of natural variation in recombination across genomes and within species. Our study in Drosophila melanogaster represents the first integrated, whole-genome description of recombination that alleviates these deficiencies in any organism. Our results and conclusions will help to characterize the molecular basis of the observed variation in recombination across genomes and have an immediate impact on population genetic analyses of selection, laying the foundation for a new generation of population models that will better capture natural variation in recombination and its consequences.
generated_summary: Recombination is a fundamental biological process that has profound evolutionary implications. The theory predicts that recombination increases the effectiveness of selection in natural populations. However, direct tests of this prediction are restricted to qualitative trends and lack detailed characterization of recombination rate variation in genomes of species. In this report, we use a high-resolution description of genomic population variation and recombination rates to assess the presence of mode of selection within species. We use a new generation of population genetic models to estimate recombination. We show that high levels of variation in recombination in individuals exhibit extreme highly punctuated variation in chromosomes, hot coldspots, and hotspots in the low frequency sample. GC rates are uniformly distributed across genome CO rates, but detectable regions are reduced in regions absent of CO. At the local scale, recombination events associated with numerous sequence motifs tend to occur in transcript regions, suggesting chromatin accessibility favors double-strand breaks. These non-independent layers of variation within recombination genomes in individuals need to be taken into account in order to obtain relevant estimates of recombinations rates.

plain language summary: Malaria-parasites invade and multiply in hepatocytes and erythrocytes. The human parasite P. falciparum transports proteins encoded by multigene families onto the surface of erythrocytes, mediating interactions between infected red blood cells (iRBCs) and other host-cells and are thought to play a key role in parasite survival during blood-stage development. The function of other exported Plasmodium protein families remains largely unknown. We provide novel insights into expression and cellular location of proteins encoded by three large multigene families of rodent malaria parasites (Fam-a, Fam-b and PIR). Multiple members of the same family are expressed in a single iRBC, unlike P. falciparum PfEMP1 proteins where individual iRBCs express only a single member. Most proteins we examined are located in the RBC cytoplasm and are not transported onto the iRBC surface membrane, indicating that these proteins are unlikely to mediate interactions between iRBCs and host-cells. Unexpectedly, liver stages also express many of these proteins, where they locate to the vacuole surrounding the parasite inside the hepatocyte. In support of a role of these proteins for parasite growth within their host cells we provide evidence that Fam-A proteins have a role in uptake and transport of (host) phosphatidylcholine for parasite-membrane synthesis.
generated_summary: Plasmodium falciparum is the causative agent of malaria in humans and rodents. The parasite is transmitted to humans through the blood of infected red blood cells (RBC). The RBC is the host cell of the parasite, which is responsible for the development of liver and erythrocytes. In this study, we have analysed the expression of the Plasmodia multigene families exported from the RBC. We show that the family members are expressed in the liver stage, and are transported to the hepatocyte via a parasitophorous vacuole. Furthermore, we show that these family members have a history of functional differentiation and are unique to the RMP. We demonstrate that these families are mutually exclusive and that the tagged proteins are transported from the iRBC cytoplasm to the plasma membrane, indicating that they are unlikely to play a direct role in the cellular and host cell interactions. Unexpectedly, family members expressed in liver stages, and were transported via the parasite to the liver. Our results suggest that these protein families may promote parasite development in liver and blood, supporting parasite development of hepatocytes and the host immune response. These observations indicate that these proteins may transfer phosphatidylcholine in vitro.

plain language summary: Tularemia is a zoonotic disease that is widely disseminated throughout the Northern Hemisphere and is caused by different strain types of bacteria belonging to the genus Francisella. In general, Francisella tularensis subspecies are able to infect a wide range of mammals including humans and are often transmitted via insect vectors such as ticks. Depending on the strain and route of infection the disease may be fatal in humans. In order to better understand F. tularensis as an etiological agent as well as its potential as a biological weapon, we have completed draft sequence assemblies of five globally diverse strains. We have performed a comparative analysis of these sequences with other available public Francisella sequences of strains of differing virulence. Our analysis suggests that genome rearrangements and gene loss in specific Francisella subspecies may underlie the evolution of niche adaptation and virulence of this pathogen.
generated_summary: Francisella tularensis is a gram-negative bacterium that causes tularemia in humans. It is caused by infection with the gram-positive bacterium, Francisella mediasiatica. In order to better understand the potency of this etiological agent as a potential biological weapon, we have completed draft assemblies to report complete genomic characterization of strains belonging to the following different Francisella subspecies (subsp. FSC033 and FSC022). We find significant enrichment in the ORFs proximal to predicted breakpoints in the FSC025 strain, including a genetic component of the Type III restriction-modulator defense system. We also find that several pseudogenes were disrupted in this FSC147 strain. These findings suggest that the acquisition of individual loci, adaptation to gene loss, and adaptation of gene loss recently emerged from the two subspecies may have occurred in distinct evolutionary events, supporting previous proposals that phylogenetic subdivisions between the Type I and Type IV secretion systems (T4SS) are likely.

Individuals suspected intra - couple transmission ( 97 couples ) similar viral load set - points ( p   =   0.054 single factor model , p   =   0.0057 adjusted ) couple effect explained 16 % variance viral loads ( 23 % adjusted ) . analysis repeated subset 29 couples strong genetic support transmission . couple effect major determinant viral load set - point ( p   =   0.067 single factor , p   =   0.036 adjusted ) size effect 27 % ( 37 % adjusted ) . Individuals epidemiologically linked couples genetic support transmission similar viral load set - points . parsimonious explanation shared characteristics transmitted virus , finding sheds light role viral factors HIV-1 pathogenesis evolution virus .
plain language summary: During the long period of asymptomatic infection with HIV-1 there is considerable variability in viral load set-point between infected individuals. Higher viral load set-points increase infectivity and decrease survival. Previous work has shown that the most commonly observed viral load set-points are those intermediate viral load set-points which lead to the largest number of opportunities to transmit HIV-1 in an infectious person's lifetime, balancing survival and infectiousness. This coincidence between the most common viral load set-points and the optimum for lifetime transmission could be the result of population-level selection acting on HIV-1. However, this could only have happened if viral load set-point is a heritable characteristic of the virus, i.e. if viral load set-points are similar between both partners of transmitting couples. By studying viral load set-points amongst heterosexual couples, we show that viral load set-points are similar in these couples. When we study only those couples with strong genetic support for transmission, their viral loads are even more similar than when we study the whole group. These results suggest that there are viral factors which are passed from one infected individual to the next which play a role in determining viral load set-point and that population-level selection could act upon these viral factors.
generated_summary: The HIV-1 viral load set-point is a surrogate measure of viral virulence, which is subject to natural selection by the human host population. The key test hypothesis is that viral load sets-points are correlated with transmitting individuals acquiring infection. We retrospectively identified 112 heterosexual HIV- discordant couples enrolled in a cohort in Rakai, Uganda, and found that HIV transmission was suspected to occur in 57 couples. We also used sequence data available to establish transmission genetic linkage between 57 couples with strong genetic support for transmission. We estimated the proportion of variance between viral load and set-points explained by similarity between couples (‘couples effect’). Individuals suspected intra-pair transmission (97 couples) were similar to those suspected to transmit HIV. We found that the couple effect explained 16% of the variance in viral loads (23% adjusted). Our findings shed light on the role of viral factors in the pathogenesis and evolution of the virus.

plain language summary: Crohn's Disease (CD) is to date incurable and is characterized by severe, reoccurring inflammations that can affect different intestinal locations. The complicated and multifactorial pathogenesis is not completely understood but involves disturbed epithelial barriers and immune reactions against the commensal flora in genetically predisposed individuals. Some inherited disease mechanisms are specific for small intestinal CD and are often connected to impaired Paneth cells. These specialized cells are critical for epithelial defences in the small intestine, and their most abundant antimicrobials (HD-5 and HD-6) are primarily diminished in patients who suffer from CD at this location. In this context, we previously identified a primary role of the Wnt pathway factor TCF7L2, which regulates the expression of both these antimicrobial peptides. We have now studied a functional mutation in the Wnt co-receptor LRP6 that was more frequent in early onset ileal CD. It was also associated with severe penetrating behaviour and linked to especially low HD-5 expression in ileal CD patient biopsies. Independently, we found that a reduced epithelial expression likely represents an additional impairment of the Wnt co-receptor in the disorder. LRP6 is a new player in small intestinal CD and underlines the importance of Paneth cell antimicrobial defences in the disease pathogenesis.
generated_summary: Ileal Crohn Disease (CD) is a chronic small intestinal inflammatory disorder characterized by reduced levels of antimicrobial peptides DEFA5 (HD-5) and DEFA6 ( HD-6) in Paneth cells (PCs). Different ileal CD–associated genes including NOD2, ATG16L1, and recently β-catenin–dependant Wnt transcription factor TCF7L2 have been linked to impaired PC antimicrobial function. Here, we investigated the role of the Wnt factor, a co-receptor of low density lipoprotein receptor-related protein 6 (LRP6), in the development of CD. We found that LRP6 was associated with early onset of CD, colonic CD and ulcerative colitis. Moreover, we identified a non-synonymous SNP (SNP2302685; Ile1062Val) in early onset and late onset of the disease. This SNP is associated with low levels of HD-5/6 gene expression in PCs, suggesting that it may be a potential target for new therapeutic approaches.

plain language summary: In many virus-infected plants, the development of viral symptoms on the upper leaves gradually decline, until finally the top leaves appear normal and become resistant to secondary infection. Many documented cases suggest that symptom recovery is accompanied with antiviral RNA silencing. Most plant viruses encode viral suppressors of RNA silencing (VSRs) that can facilitate transient viral entry into meristems by blocking host RNA silencing defenses. However, the mechanisms of the following longer-term viral exclusion and modulation of VSRs functions remain elusive. Our studies with a substitution mutation in the CP gene demonstrate that the CMV CP has a negative role in SAM invasion. The studies suggest that during late infections, increasing CP concentrations induce potent RDR6/SGS3-dependent antiviral silencing by down-regulating accumulation of the 2b protein and induction of efficient siRNA amplification. Here, we propose a new evolutionary strategy in which the CMV CP has a role mediating viral self-attenuation and long-term symptom recovery.
generated_summary: The ability of plant viruses to suppress RNA silencing (VSRs) has been shown to facilitate the transient viral invasion of SAM. However, the underlying mechanisms are poorly understood. Here, we show that a wild-type Cucumber mosaic virus (CMVWT) invaded SAM transiently, subsequently eliminated meristems. Unexpectedly, CMVRA harbors an alanine substitution of the N-terminal arginine-rich region coat protein (CP) and persistently invaded SAM, resulting in visible reductions of apical dominance. Notably, CMVWT virus elicited potent antiviral silencing by infecting Arabidopsis mutants lacking host RNA-DEPENDENT RNA POLYMERASE 6 (RDR6) and SUPPRESSOR GENE SILENCING 3 (SGS3). Our findings suggest that the CMV CP acts as a central hub for antiviral RNA-silencing and that it may be a mechanism that mediates viral self-attenuation and long-term symptom recovery.

abstract: Tyrosine kinases regarded excellent targets chemical drug therapy carcinomas . , strong purifying selection , drug resistance usually occurs cancer cells short term . cases drug resistance found associated secondary mutations drug target , lead attenuated drug - target interactions . example , recently , acquired secondary mutation , G2032R , detected drug target , ROS1 tyrosine kinase , crizotinib - resistant patient , responded poorly crizotinib short therapeutic term . supposed mutation located solvent hinder drug binding . , different fact uncovered simulations reported study . , free energy surfaces characterized drug - target distance phosphate - binding loop ( P - loop ) conformational change crizotinib - ROS1 complex advanced molecular dynamics techniques , revealed rigid P - loop region G2032R - mutated ROS1 primarily responsible crizotinib resistance , hand , impaired binding crizotinib directly , hand , shortened residence time induced flattened free energy surface . , binding affinity drug residence time emphasized rational drug design overcome kinase resistance .
plain language summary: Cancers can eventually confer drug resistance to the continued medication. In most cases, mutations occurred in a drug target can attenuate the binding affinity of the drugs. Here, we studied the drug resistance mechanisms of the mutations G2032R in the ROS1 tyrosine kinase in fusion-type NSCLC. It is well known that the phosphate-binding loop (P-loop) plays a vital role in the binding of competitive inhibitors in tyrosine kinases, and numerous mutations have been found occurred around the P-loop, which may affect the binding/unbinding process of a drug. Free energy surfaces were constructed to characterize the impact of the mutation to the binding/unbinding process of a well-known NSCLC drug, crizotinib. Two advanced free energy calculation methods, namely funnel based well-tempered metadynamics and umbrella sampling based absolute binding free energy calculation achieved consistent results with the experimental data, suggesting that the rigid P-loop of the mutated target was mainly responsible for the crizotinib resistance to ROS1 tyrosine kinase.
generated_summary: Tyrosine kinases are important targets of chemical drug therapy in carcinomas. However, due to their strong purifying selection, drug resistance usually occurs in cancer cells in the short term. In some cases, drug drug resistance is found associated with secondary mutations in the drug target, which can lead to attenuated drug-target interactions. For example, recently, a secondary mutation, G2032R, was detected in a cancer cell. The drug target of this mutation, ROS1, was a crizotinib-resistant patient, and the drug binding affinity was shortened by the shortened residence time induced by the flattened free energy surface. In addition, the binding affinity of the drug was emphasized by rational drug design to overcome kinase resistance.

Furthermore , Candidate BMCs found lack core metabolosome components , including predicted represent entirely new paradigm BMC - associated metabolism , joining carboxysome metabolosome . placing results phylogenetic context , provide framework understanding horizontal transfer loci , starting point studies aimed understanding evolution BMCs . comprehensive taxonomy BMC loci , based constituent protein domains , foregrounds functional diversity BMCs provides reference interpreting role BMC gene clusters encoded isolate , single cell , metagenomic data . loci encode ancillary functions transporters genes cofactor assembly ; expanded vocabulary BMC - related functions useful design genetic modules introducing BMCs bioengineering applications .
plain language summary: Some enzymatic transformations have undesirable side reactions, produce toxic or volatile intermediates, or are inefficient; these shortcomings can be alleviated through their sequestration with their substrates in a confined space, as in the membrane-bound organelles of eukaryotes. Recently, it was discovered that bacteria also form organelles–bacterial microcompartments (BMCs)–composed of a protein shell that surrounds functionally related enzymes. BMCs long evaded detection because they typically form only in the presence of the substrate they metabolize, and they can only be visualized by electron microscopy. A few BMCs have been experimentally characterized; they have diverse functions in CO2 fixation, pathogenesis, and niche colonization. While the encapsulated enzymes differ among functionally distinct BMCs, the shell architecture is conserved. This enables their detection computationally, as genes for shell proteins are typically nearby genes for the encapsulated enzymes. We developed a novel algorithm to comprehensively identify and categorize BMCs in sequenced bacterial genomes. We show that BMCs are often encoded adjacent to genes that play supporting roles to the organelle's function. Our results provide the first glimpse of the extent of BMC metabolic diversity and will inform design of genetic modules encoding BMCs for introduction of new metabolic functions in a plug-and-play approach.
generated_summary: Bacterial microcompartments (BMCs) are proteinaceous organelles involved in autotrophic and heterotrophic metabolism. BMCs share homologous shell proteins that differ in complement enzymes; typically encoded adjacent to shell protein genes are genetic loci, operons, and operons. To enable the identification of functional (sub)types of BMCs, we developed LoClass, an algorithm that finds putative BMC loci inventories, weights, and compares constituent pfam domains to construct locus similarity networks to predict locus (sub)-types. In addition, LoClass was able to analyze sequences from seven candidate bacterial phyla (single-cell genomic studies) in the LoClass taxonomy. Our analyses resulted in identification of 23 different BMCs encoded by 30 distinct locus and subtypes found in 23 of the 23 candidate phyla. These BMCs include carboxysome types and a divergent set of metabolosomes, which share a common catalytic core process and distinct substrates for specific signature enzymes. Furthermore, Candidate BMCs found to lack core metabolosome components, including predicted to represent an entirely new paradigm of BMC-associated metabolism, joining the carboxyome and metabolosomal metabolism. Our results provide a framework for understanding the horizontal transfer of loci and provide a reference for interpreting the role of BMC gene clusters encoded in isolate, single cell, and metagenomic data.

abstract: Post - translational modifications ( PTMs ) add layer complexity proteome regulate wide range cellular protein functions . increasing number known PTM sites , imperative understand functional interplays . study , proposed novel analytical strategy explore functional relationships PTM sites testing tendency modified ( co - occurrence ) condition , applied proteome - wide human phosphorylation data collected 88 different laboratory physiological conditions . Comparison existing methods suggests co - occurrence analysis useful complement uncover novel functional associations PTM sites .
plain language summary: In addition to gene expression and translation control, post-translational modifications (PTMs) represent another level to regulate proteins functions. Different PTM sites within a protein usually co-operate to fulfill their functional roles. Recent advances in high-throughput mass spectrometry (MS) technologies have facilitated the proteome-wide identification of PTM sites, giving rise to both challenge and opportunity to understand their functional relationships. Previously, several data mining approaches have been developed to explore the global PTM interplays. In this study, we proposed to infer functional associations between PTM sites from the correlation of their modification status across many biological conditions, which was not exploited before. In practice, we tested if a pair of sites are modified together under the same condition significantly more often than expected (co-occurrence). As a proof of principle, we applied this analytical strategy to human phosphorylation because we could collect data sets of proteome-wide coverage under 88 different conditions. We demonstrated that sites with co-occurring phosphorylation status are functionally associated from several lines of evidence. The co-occurrence analysis can also uncover functionally connected phosphosites with clear biological evidence which are missed by other approaches. With increasing proteome-wide data for other types of PTMs under different conditions, the co-occurrence analysis can be integrated with other methods to identify novel PTM associations.
generated_summary: Post-translational modifications (PTMs) add a layer of complexity to the proteome and regulate a wide range of cellular protein functions. However, there is an increasing number of known PTM sites, and it is imperative to understand functional interplays. In this study, we proposed a novel analytical strategy to explore the functional relationships between PTM and the tendency to modified (co-occurrence) condition. We applied proteome-wide human phosphorylation data collected from 88 different laboratory physiological conditions. We found that co-accurrence occurs significantly more frequently than randomly expected and include known examples of cross-talk and functional connections. In addition, we found that phosphoprotein interacting partners, likely sequence and structural proximity, phosphorylated kinases, participate in similar biological processes, including residue co-evolution in vertebrates. In contrast, we also found that the co-occurring states tend to be conserved in orthologous phosphosites of the mouse proteome. These results support the hypothesis that the propensity to modified is likely to be functionally associated with PTM.

abstract: mammals , circadian periodicity described gene expression hypothalamus multiple peripheral tissues . accepted 10%–15 % genes oscillate daily rhythm , regulated intrinsic molecular clock . Combined statistical tests periodicity , method identifies circadian baseline oscillation 100 % expressed genes . Consequently , circadian oscillation gene expression evaluated study related biological pathways . Changes gene expression caused mutations regulation environmental factors ( photic stimuli feeding ) considered context changes amplitude phase genetic oscillations .
plain language summary: Prior studies have reported that ~15% of expressed genes show a circadian expression pattern in association with a specific function. A series of experimental and computational studies of gene expression in various murine tissues has led us to a different conclusion. By applying a new analysis strategy and a number of alternative algorithms, we identify baseline oscillation in almost 100% of all genes. While the phase and amplitude of oscillation vary between different tissues, circadian oscillation remains a fundamental property of every gene. Reanalysis of previously published data also reveals a greater number of oscillating genes than was previously reported. This suggests that circadian oscillation is a universal property of all mammalian genes, although phase and amplitude of oscillation are tissue-specific and remain associated with a gene's function. We hypothesize that the cell's metabolic respiratory cycle drives the oscillatory pattern of gene expression. These findings imply that biological pathways should be considered as dynamic systems of genes oscillating in coordination with each other.
generated_summary: In mammals, the circadian periodicity is described by gene expression in the hypothalamus and multiple peripheral tissues. It is accepted that 10%–15% of genes oscillate in a daily rhythm, regulated by the intrinsic molecular clock. However, statistical analyses of periodicity are limited to small size datasets with high levels of stochastic noise. We propose a new approach applying digital signal processing algorithms to separately group genes oscillating in a phase. Combined with statistical tests for periodicity, our method identifies circadian baseline oscillation in 100% of the expressed genes. Consequently, circadian oscillation gene expression is evaluated in the study of related biological pathways. Changes in gene expression caused by mutations in the regulation of environmental factors (photic stimuli or feeding) are considered in the context of changes in amplitude and phase of genetic oscillations.

abstract: Chromosome replication Escherichia coli initiated DnaA. DnaA binds ATP essential formation DnaA - oriC nucleoprotein complex promotes strand opening , helicase loading replisome assembly . Following initiation , DnaAATP converted DnaAADP primarily Regulatory Inactivation DnaA process ( RIDA ) . RIDA deficient cells , DnaAATP accumulates leading uncontrolled initiation replication cell death accumulation DNA strand breaks . Mutations suppress RIDA deficiency dampen overinitiation permit growth despite overinitiation . characterize mutations group common distinct metabolic routes rewired resulting redirection electron flow cytochrome bd-1 . propose model cytochrome bd-1 lowers formation reactive oxygen species oxidative damage DNA general . increases processivity replication forks generated overinitiation level sustains viability .
plain language summary: In most bacteria chromosome replication is initiated by the DnaA protein. In Escherichia coli, DnaA binds ATP and ADP with similar affinity but only the ATP bound form is active. An increased level of DnaAATP causes overinitiation and cell death by accumulation of DNA strand breaks. These strand breaks often result from forks encountering gapped DNA formed during repair of oxidative damage. We provide evidence that cell death in overinitiating cells can be prevented by rewiring the metabolism to favor the micro-aerobic respiratory chain with the cytochrome bd-1 as terminal oxidase. Cytochrome bd-1 is found in aerobic as well as anaerobic bacteria. Its role is to reduce O2 in micro-aerobic conditions and work as an electron sink to prevent the formation of reactive oxygen species. Our results suggest that bacteria can cope with replication stress by increasing respiration through cytochrome bd-1 to reduce the formation of reactive oxygen species, and hence oxidative damage to a level that does not interfere with replication fork progression.
generated_summary: Chromosome replication in Escherichia coli is initiated by the DnaA-O oriC nucleoprotein complex, which promotes strand opening, helicase loading and replisome assembly. Following initiation, DNAAATP is converted into DnaADP primarily by the Regulatory Inactivation of DnaAs process (RIDA). In RIDA deficient cells, RIDA accumulates leading to uncontrolled initiation of replication and cell death and accumulation of DNA strand breaks. Mutations that suppress RIDA deficiency dampen the overinitiation and permit growth despite overiniation. We characterize mutations in a group of common metabolic routes that are rewired resulting in redirection of electron flow to cytochrome bd-1. We propose that this redirection lowers the formation of reactive oxygen species and oxidative damage in DNA in general. This increase in processivity and replication forks generated at the level that sustains the viability of the cell.

Immune - responsive miR-181 levels - regulated biofluids ferrets horses infected Hendra virus , suggesting host innate immune response promote henipavirus spread exacerbate disease severity . study genome - wide screen miRNAs influencing infection clinically significant mononegavirus nominates select miRNAs targets future anti - viral therapy development .
plain language summary: The henipaviruses Hendra and Nipah are bat-borne paramyxoviruses that are highly pathogenic in humans. Until recently the constraints of working at biosafety level 4 had hindered the large scale study of host factors associated with henipavirus infection. MicroRNAs are a class of single-stranded non-coding RNAs that regulate biological processes in eukaryotes. An emerging body of evidence suggests that host microRNAs may favour infection of vertebrate RNA viruses. We have performed high-throughput agonist and antagonist screens at biosafety level 4 to identify host-encoded microRNAs impacting henipavirus infection in human cells. Members of the miR-181 and miR-17~93 families strongly promoted Hendra virus infection and appear to suppress multiple antiviral host molecules. Infection promotion is primarily mediated via the ability of miR-181 to repress Eph receptors that negatively regulate henipavirus glycoprotein-mediated cell-cell fusion. This study is the first large-scale screen of host-encoded microRNAs influencing infection by a clinically significant mononegavirus, and of a BSL-4 virus, and supports the emerging notion that host miRNAs can play a role in supporting infection of RNA viruses.
generated_summary: Hendra Nipah viruses (family Paramyxoviridae, genus Henipavirus) are bat-borne viruses that cause fatal disease in humans and a range of mammalian species. Gaining deeper understanding of the host pathways exploited by henipaviruses infection will identify targets for new anti-viral therapies. We performed a genome-wide high-throughput agonist antagonist screen at biosafety level 4 to identify host-encoded microRNAs (miRNAs) that are important for infection and infection in human cells. Members of the miR-181 family strongly promoted Hendra virus infection, but did not affect infection with paramyxoviruses and other genera, indicating the specificity of virus-host interaction. Infection promotion was primarily mediated by the ability of miRs-181 to significantly enhance henipovirus-induced membrane fusion. Cell signalling receptors for ephrins, EphA5 and EphB4, were identified as novel negative regulators of henipvirus fusion, suggesting that simultaneous inhibition of Ephs and miRNA contributes to enhanced infection and fusion. Immune-responsive miRNA levels were also regulated in biofluids of ferrets and horses infected with Hendra viruses, suggesting a host innate immune response that may promote henipivirus spread and exacerbate disease severity. Our study provides the first comprehensive screen of miRNAs influencing infection in a clinically significant mononegavirus.

plain language summary: The Federal Republic of Sudan has had at least 12 outbreaks of febrile illness of unknown cause associated with symptoms of haemorrhage and high case fatality rates since 2012. Outbreaks without clear diagnosis are concerning, particularly in countries such as Sudan where a range of high consequence diseases, including viral haemorrhagic fevers, are endemic or epidemic, and local laboratory capacity is limited. We transferred historical samples stored in the National Public Health Authority from one of these outbreaks that occurred in Darfur 2015–2016 to the Public Health England Laboratory at Porton, UK, and tested them against a wide range of infectious diseases to try to identify the cause, and to help the Sudanese Federal Ministry of Health to develop and target their limited laboratory capacity. We found that Crimean-Congo Haemorrhagic Fever was an important cause but not the only source of cases in this outbreak. This has implications for prevention and control as well as for treating cases. Our study also highlighted the need for future studies to explore other possible causes, including new pathogens, and reinforced the need to boost surveillance, lab and investigative capacity for more timely and complete outbreak response.
generated_summary: Undifferentiated febrile illness (UFI) is one of the most common reasons for people seeking healthcare in low-income countries. UFI is often associated with haemorrhage and high case fatality rates (CFR). A number of high consequence infectious diseases, including Ebola virus, are endemic in the Federal Republic of Sudan. In 2015/2016, 594 cases and 108 deaths were reported. The aetiology of these outbreaks remains unknown. In this retrospective cohort study, a subset of 65 263 outbreak samples received from the National Public Health Laboratory met selection criteria for sufficient sample volume and epidemiological data. Clinical features included fever (95.8%), bleeding, headache (51.6%) and arthralgia (42.2%). The epidemiological patterns were indicative of person-to-person transmission of health-worker cases reported. Samples tested from the Public Health England Rare Imported Pathogens Laboratory were tested with a bespoke panel of likely pathogens including haemorrrhagic fever viruses, arboviruses Rickettsia, Leptospira Borrelia spp. Seven (11%) of the samples were positive for Crimean-Congo haemoral fever virus (CCHFV) real-time reverse transcription PCR. The remaining samples tested negative for CCHFVs. Prospective studies are needed to explore aetiologies, including novel pathogens.

plain language summary: Rift Valley fever virus (RVFV) is a zoonotic virus affecting livestock and people. Periodic outbreaks in Kenya are associated with greater than average rainfall, although outbreaks have not previously been reported in western Kenya. The virus is spread between animals and to people by mosquitos. Contact with infected animal tissues and products are also risk factors for transmission of RVFV to people. This study investigated the seroprevalence of RVFV in 1861 residents of western Kenya and compared this to the seroprevalence in 553 ruminant slaughterhouse workers. The seroprevalence of RVFV in people in western Kenya was less than 1%, which is consistent with previous reports from the region. Slaughterhouse workers were shown to be a higher risk group for RVFV seropositivity, with seroprevalence of 2.5%. The identification of plausible risk factors including slaughtering is consistent with reports from other regions. The results suggest that it is plausible that RVFV virus is circulating in western Kenya. Improved surveillance in low risk areas is recommended particularly during countrywide outbreaks.
generated_summary: Rift Valley fever virus (RVFV) is a zoonotic arbovirus affecting livestock and people. In western Kenya, RVFV outbreaks have been previously reported. This study aims to document seroprevalence and risk factors of RVFVs in a community-based sample of western Kenya. We compare the seroprecvalence of ruminant slaughterhouse workers in a region considered to be considered a high-risk group for RVV exposure. The study was conducted in western Kenya between July 2010 and November 2012. Individuals were recruited from randomly selected homesteads and census slaughterhouses. Structured questionnaire tools were used to collect information on demographic data, health, risk factors, and zoonosis disease exposure. Indirect ELISA serum samples were determined to determine seropositivity of RVFsV in the community. Risk factor analysis was conducted with multi-level logistic regression. A total of 1861 individuals were sampled from 384 homesteaders. The seropresvalence was 0.8% (95% CI 0.5–1.3) and was 2.5% for slaughterman, person who cuts animal throat (3.5; 95% CI 1.1–12.1, p = 0.047). These data demonstrate that slaughtering animals is a risk factor for RVFFV seroposiveness in slaughterhouses and that slaughterhouses are considered to have a high risk group. These risk factors were previously reported in other studies providing evidence for the presence of the virus in the environment.

plain language summary: The mosquito Aedes aegypti is the major vector of the Dengue virus in human populations and is responsible of serious outbreaks worldwide. In most countries, vector control is implemented by the use of insecticides to reduce mosquito populations. During epidemics, insecticides of the pyrethroid family (blocking the voltage gated sodium channel protein in the nerve sheath) are used by space spraying with vehicle mounted thermal foggers to kill adult mosquitoes. Unfortunately some populations of Ae. aegypti have become resistant to these insecticides, leading to operational challenges for public health services. In Martinique (French West Indies), resistance to pyrethroids was detected in the 1990s. The present study assessed the impact of this resistance on the efficacy of vector control operations in 9 localities of Martinique. Here we showed that the resistance strongly reduces the efficacy of pyrethroid-based treatments, thus emphasizing the urgent need for alternative insecticides or tools to reduce dengue transmission.
generated_summary: Dengue fever is a mosquito-borne disease that is transmitted by the mosquito Aedes aegypti. In Martinique, dengue vector control has been implemented in order to rapidly reduce transmission. Unfortunately, vector control programs are facing operational challenges due to the emergence of pyrethroid resistant Ae. ae.i populations. In order to assess the impact of pyrethroids on vector control and efficacy of treatments, applications of deltamethrin and natural pyrethrins were performed in 9 localities of Martinique. In the presence of pyrthroids, the mortality rates of naturally resistant laboratory susceptible mosquitoes were assessed. In addition, larval adult densities were estimated. Results showed high mortality rates and that susceptible sentinel mosquitoes treated with deltamsethrin resistant mosquitoes exhibited low mortality rates. The reduction in larval and adult Ae. Ae.a.i population densities was also observed. These results emphasize the need for alternative tools to strategies to control and control vector control.

plain language summary: A key function of MΦ is to recognize, phagocytose and mount an antimicrobial response against microbial pathogens to defend the host. In humans, monocytes are recruited to the site of infection and differentiate into MΦ upon the onset of microbial infection. The MΦ phenotype and function are determined by the cytokine profile of the microenvironment in which the monocyte enters. Additionally, vitamin D is known to trigger direct antimicrobial responses against invading pathogens in MΦ, but also disrupts the differentiation of immune subsets within the myeloid lineage. Therefore, we investigated whether vitamin D status during MΦ differentiation influenced either phenotype or function. Here, we found that the IL-15 MΦphenotype is sustained regardless of vitamin D status. In contrast, antimicrobial MΦ differentiated in the presence of vitamin D exhibited a robust expression of an antimicrobial peptide, relative to MΦ differentiated in the absence of vitamin D. The antimicrobial MΦ armed with cathelicidin prior to M. leprae challenge demonstrated a strong antimicrobial response against the invading pathogen. Our study reveals that the presence of sufficient levels of vitamin D prior to microbial infection contributes to effectively reduce the viability of the pathogen in MΦ.
generated_summary: Macrophages (MΦ) are innate immune cells that are able to kill intracellular microbes. However, the physiological levels of vitamin D and MΦ differentiation affect phenotype function and are unknown. In this study, we show that the human innate immune system consists of divergent mΦ subsets that serve distinct functions in vivo. IL-15 and IL-10 induce primary human monocytes to differentiate into antimicrobial MΥ (IL-15 MΤ) and robustly express the vitamin D pathway. In addition, we found that adding 25-hydroxyvitamin D3 (25D3) to IL-5 induced differentiation of monocytes into Mζ and increased expression of the antimicrobial peptide cathelicidin, including CAMP mRNA encoded by the protein cathelyidin in dose-dependent manner. These data suggest that the presence of vitamin d and IL in M�Φ led to a significant vitamin D-dependent antimicrobial response against intracele Mycobacterium leprae infection.

abstract: Regulated protein secretion required malaria parasite life cycle progression transmission mammalian host mosquito vector . transmission host vector , exocytosis highly specialised secretory vesicles , osmiophilic bodies , key dissolution red blood cell parasitophorous vacuole membranes enabling gamete egress . positioning adhesins TRAP family , micronemes sporozoite surface , essential gliding motility parasite transmission mosquito mammalian host . identify conserved role putative pantothenate transporter PAT Plasmodium berghei vesicle fusion distinct classes vesicles gametocytes sporozoites . PAT membrane component osmiophilic bodies gametocytes micronemes sporozoites . Despite normal formation trafficking osmiophilic bodies cell surface activation , PAT - deficient gametes fail discharge contents , remain intraerythrocytic unavailable fertilisation development mosquito . Sporozoites lacking PAT fail secrete TRAP , immotile unable infect subsequent rodent host . , P. berghei PAT appears regulate exocytosis distinct populations vesicles different life cycle forms acting pantothenic transporter parasite transmission .
plain language summary: Transmission of the malaria parasite between mosquito and host requires two different life cycle stages—the gametocyte and the sporozoite. In both parasite forms, transmission is dependent on exocytosis of stage-specific vesicles. In gametocytes these vesicles release proteins allowing egress from red blood cells and fertilization, and are hence needed to establish an infection in the mosquito. In contrast, proteins are secreted into the membrane of the sporozoite, where they play distinct roles during adhesion and motility, both crucial for transmission back into the mammalian host. Here we show that parasites lacking the putative small solute transporter PAT are still able to form vesicles in both parasite forms but are unable to fuse and secrete their contents. This results in impaired parasite transmission into and from the mosquito. Our work shows that a single protein can regulate the function of functionally distinct classes of vesicles in different life cycle forms of a parasite.
generated_summary: Malaria is a neglected tropical disease caused by the mosquito Plasmodium berghei. It is transmitted to humans by the bite of a mosquito mosquito. The mosquito is responsible for the transmission of the malaria parasite to the mammalian host. During the life cycle of the mosquito, exocytosis of highly specialised secretory vesicles, osmiophilic bodies, is key for the dissolution of red blood cell and parasitophorous vacuole membranes enabling gamete egress. The positioning of adhesins in the TRAP family, micronemes on the sporozoite surface, is essential for gliding motility during parasite transmission to the mosquito and mammalian hosts. Here, we identify a conserved role for the putative pantothenate transporter PAT in the transmission process of malaria. PAT is present in distinct classes of vesicle membranes, including gametocytes and sporozoites. PAT-deficient gametes fail to discharge their contents, and remain intraerythrocytic and unavailable for fertilisation during development in the mosquito. Sporozoites lacking PAT fail to secrete TRAP, rendering them immotile and unable to infect the subsequent rodent host. Our results suggest that P. bergi PAT appears to regulate exocytic secretion of distinct populations of Vesicles in different life cycle forms acting as pantothensic transporter of parasite transmission.
